description:
CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA
On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.

***

PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK 🩷 LA VITA IN ROSA 🩷 LEVEN IN ROZE 🩷 LA VIDA EN ROSA 🩷 LA VIE EN ROSE 🩷 ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO 🩷 AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.

***

CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.

What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.

Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!

Dress Code: PINK!

Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!

Suggested Koha/Donation: $5

Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!

EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.

Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:

02-0343-0003801-007

ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.

Please give generously.

LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.

NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.

RAIN DATE: TBC

***

This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.

#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban

Today 8 women will be diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening

This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer

And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump

Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness

Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.

To find out more about CUBAN☆FUSION, its dance classes and upcoming dance and music event please visit our website.

CUBAN☆FUSION © 2005 - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists | www.cubanfusion.co.nz | | 021-621-245

Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:
02-0343-0003801-007
ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.
Please give generously.
LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.
NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.
RAIN DATE: TBC
***
This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.
#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban
Today 8 women will be diagnosed with Breast Cancer
Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening
This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer
And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump
Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness
Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.
To find out more about CUBAN☆FUSION, its dance classes and upcoming dance and music event please visit our website.

description:
Celebrating 132 years of women’s suffrage — special lunchtime tour and kōrero, Join our kaimahi for a special lunchtime tour and kōrero, highlighting the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition | Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine, which paved the way for women’s suffrage in Aotearoa.
Tour and kōrero
Mark your calendars for 19 September, the anniversary of the 1893 Electoral Act that granted New Zealand women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.
To celebrate Suffrage Day, join a 45-minute kōrero and tour of the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
Tours are open to visitors of all ages (age 6+). Booking is not required.
Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the start of the tour.
The ongoing struggle for equal rights
Come along to the National Library to learn about the journey New Zealand women took to gain the right to vote and about the ongoing struggle for equal rights.
View the 1893 petition that led to the creation of the Electoral Act 1893, which was signed into law on 19 September 1893.
Hear stories about wāhine toa like Meri Te Tai Mangakāhia (Te Rarawa) and suffragists Kate Sheppard, Ada Wells and maybe an ancestor of your own.

description:
Cafe Fund Raiser Event for SPCA with Puppy Cuddles, Hi, I’m Daniela, proud owner of Greta Point Cafe in Evans Bay and a passionate animal lover! I’m thrilled to announce a special SPCA fundraiser at my cafe on Saturday, 30 August 2025 to support animals in need.

Join us for a fun-filled day featuring :
**Special bakery treats for dogs and humans alike,
**Puppy cuddles (10am- 2pm) from puppies currently living at the SPCA shelter
** Opportunities to donate to the SPCA.

In the lead-up to the event, we’re also collecting donations like pet food, blankets, and other supplies—feel free to drop them off at Greta Point Cafe, and we’ll deliver them to the SPCA on the day.

This fundraiser is a tribute to the memory of my beloved dog, who I got from SPCA when I first moved to Wellington and is also a way to help animals still waiting for their forever homes.

Let’s come together to make this fundraiser a success and give animals the love and care they deserve!

description:
Celebrating Mahuru Māori: He wheako reorua o He Tohu and Pipitea walking tour — Mahuru Māori 2025, This Mahuru Māori, join a reorua (bilingual) He Tohu experience and hīkoi around Pipitea to celebrate te reo Māori and the unique hītori (history) of Pipitea. Deepen your understanding about ingoa tūturu (original place names) and the wāhi where He Tohu currently sits.
A reorua | bilingual tour of He Tohu and Pipitea
Join us and embark on a haerenga (journey) together to connect to the ancestors and our shared past. The tour will begin at He Tohu — a permanent exhibition of three iconic constitutional taonga that shape Aotearoa New Zealand.
* 1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
* 1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
* 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
These taonga are significant because they shaped who we are as a nation and will shape what we become in the future.
"Ka mua, ka muri | Walking backwards into the future"
A hīkoi around Pipitea
After the He Tohu tour, join us on a half-hour bilingual hīkoi (walk) around key sites in Pipitea of cultural significance.
There are slight inclines in places, but we will be walking on the pavement for the tour. If the huarere (weather) is looking inclement, please bring warm clothing, a raincoat, or an umbrella. If the weather is too bad, we will postpone the event, so please register so that we can notify you about the cancellation.
Shared kai
During the kaupapa, knowledge, pātai (questions), and reflections will flow between us. At the end we’ll have kai timotimo (snacks). You are welcome to bring snacks to share.
This event is suitable for all ages. Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the tour starts.
Nau mai, haere mai!
Book your spot
Places are limited so email us to book your spot.
Please include your contact details and the number of people in your party.
Email — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz
Celebrate te reo Māori
Reorua (bilingual) speaking kaimahi will host your taenga mai ki te whare, visit. Some will be kaimahi tangata whenua and some will be kaimahi Pākehā, Tauiwi rānei. Like us all, this mahi (work) is for us and our descendants — mō tātou, me ō tātou uri, haere ake nei.
Toi te kupu, toi te mana, toi te reo Māori! | Hold fast to the word, to the mana and to the Māori language!
Image: Kaiārahi leading the hīkoi through Pipitea. Photo by Mark Beatty
label: Community & Culture

description:
Community Evening Trimester 2 2025, About Ignite:
Ignite Consultants is a student-run charitable organisation that provides free and creative advice to charities and social organisations across Aotearoa. All of our consultants are passionate and talented student-volunteers who are driven by their desire to foster social change. Our vision is to help organisations to maximise their impact through harnessing the fresh perspectives of university students. 
We run two project cycles per year which coincide with the university semesters, each lasting for a duration of 9 weeks. Each team consists of a local charity, 5-6 students, a project manager (a person who has been through the Ignite Consultants experience before) and a professional mentor who has experience in consulting and/or the industry the organisation works in. 
About the Event:
Ignite's Community Evening is a special occasion where our consultants share what they have learnt, created and experienced over the past nine weeks. This event is an opportunity to learn about the remarkable charities we have collaborated with this semester, to enjoy delicious food and to extend our heartfelt thanks to all our supporters. 
This semester, attendees will get to hear presentations from the teams who have worked with WELLfed, Take10, Orange Sky, PACE and The Charitable Recycling Trust. 
To join us virtually, please click on the link below:

description:
Startup Weekend Ōtaki, Startup Weekend Ōtaki
Creatives, Haututu, Techpreneurs!

Ever had a business idea sitting on the shelf or wanted to launch a Kaupapa Māori initiative? Passionate about a challenge your whānau or community are ready to tackle?



Start up weekend Ōtaki is back for its second year!

Join us for a 54-hour sprint (over a full weekend) where you'll learn how to think, build and collaborate like a start-up.

Come and join a mix of community change makers with a mix of experienced mentors who will help guide you through the journey.

Our aim is to turn your idea from a tiny spark into a buzzing start-up!



Registrations can be found at www.wananga.com/swotaki
label: Business & Networking

description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour
Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.

Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
Genealogy - Basics of Ancestry.com DNA Tests, Have you done a DNA test with Ancestry.com? Don't know what to do next? This course will cover the basics of what your DNA results mean. We'll look at the tools available on Ancestry.com and other DNA websites to help you use DNA for your family's history.

Got your test results back and still wondering what a centiMorgan or a shared match is? Find out what the size of your match means and the tools available to help you work out possible family relationships.

We'll start by looking at Clustering and how the Grouping tool on Ancestry.com can help with this. We'll also look at the ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools to see how they can provide suggestions for knocking down brick walls in your research.

Also covered during this course are other websites you can upload your results to, how to manage other family member's DNA test results and other tools available when you get a bit more advanced - and just in case you need help in the future, we'll look at some of the places you could get this from.

Please note: This course will only cover DNA tests taken through Ancestry.com

Bring a USB stick and your Ancestry.com login details.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Understand the information provided by Ancestry.com about your DNA matches
- Use the Grouping, ThruLines and Common Ancestors tools on Ancestry.com
- Use the Shared CentiMorgan tool on DNAPainter.com
- Understand where to find other tools
- Understand the options for using other DNA websites
- Understand where to get further help

Prerequisites
For those who have already done a DNA test through Ancestry.com
You will need good computing and internet skills.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Presented by Sarah Hewitt.

description:
DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp 2025, Kia ora DEBRA New Zealand whanau !
Save the dates - DEBRA NZ Conference and Family Camp, Wellington, Friday 22 - Sunday 24 August 2025.
We are very happy to announce that we are planning a get-together for the NZ EB whanau and a few Aussie families in Wellington in August. We really hope you can join us - it will be wonderful to see you!
This event is a great opportunity to meet other families, connect with old friends and make wonderful new ones, learn from each other and from valuable talks about EB issues, and have time to relax and enjoy a couple of days in Wellington city - the creative capital! We're keen to hear about any particular topics you would like to hear about.
Everyone is welcome including extended family and friends, caregivers, and healthcare professionals.
Dates: Friday 22nd August (check-in from 3pm with informal meet and greet from 5.00pm), to Sunday 24th August (finishing 2pm after a farewell lunch)
Event location: Wellington City, venue to be confirmed
Registration will be launched in early May - please stay tuned for further details!
Your registration fee will cover the conference, meals and children’s activities from Friday evening to Sunday lunch time, but it does not cover accommodation (amount to be confirmed), travel or airport transfers.
DEBRA NZ will provide some limited assistance with accommodation and travel costs if needed, subsiding flights for the person attending with EB.
Please contact debra@debra.org.nz if you would like to apply for this support.
There will be more information soon.
We need an idea of numbers so please get in touch as soon as possible!
Email: debra@debra.org.nz with any questions and let us know if you are interested in attending.
Nga mihi nui,
Anna, Lea and the DEBRA NZ team
debra@debra.org.nz

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
(door sales will be available)
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/

Where big brains meet bigger wigs

description:
Healing Trauma and the Nervous System- Ancient wisdom for modern resilience, Tuesday Wellbeing Seminars
Healing Trauma and the Nervous System- Ancient wisdom for modern resilience
Stress and struggle leave their mark on both body and mind, sometimes in ways we can’t easily undo. Just as knots form in the body, impressions and tensions accumulate in the mind. While we can’t change the past, the Bhagavad-gita teaches that we can shape our future—what we choose to cultivate now carries us forward.
In this one-hour workshop, we’ll explore how philosophical and spiritual wisdom can help us rise above the tangles of trauma and anxiety. Through practical insights, open discussion, and guidance from the Gita’s philosophy, we’ll look at how to build resilience—not only by steadying the nervous system, but by exploring the deeper self beyond the changing body and mind.
Meet your host, Sivananda
Sivananda’s background is in both science and music, holding a Master's Degree in Data Science, a Bachelor of Science in Physics and a long history of playing and performing on the double bass. His passion for philosophy, music, good food and community attracted him to the bhakti lifestyle. Having studied and practiced the science of the ‘self’ for six years now, he thrives on drawing insights from contemporary science and combining it with yoga wisdom to encourage others to explore new perspectives.
6.15pm Tuesday 28th of October
End the session on a high note with a delicious plant-based dinner, dessert, and good conversation.

Tuesday , 2 September 2025

Hunter Council Chamber, Hunter Building, Kelburn Parade, Wellington
Free Entry | All Welcome
In celebration of 80 years of Vietnam’s National Day (2/9), join us for a powerful evening of music, memory, and connection.
Through traditional and contemporary Vietnamese songs, Echoes of Home takes you on a heartfelt journey — honouring the past, embracing the present, and looking to the future. Performed by a diverse group of community members, this special event celebrates identity, culture, and the spirit of resilience.
What to expect:
• A beautifully curated musical programme honouring Vietnam’s story

description:
Data Governance in the Pacific - Challenges and Opportunities, Our Data Governance Wellington events tend to focus on the great work, challenges and opportunities members have experienced in their own organisations around Wellington and New Zealand. However, this time we are very lucky to have a presentation from two members of the Pacific Community (SPC) that add an international dimension to our data governance conversations.
This talk will spotlight unique Pacific experiences—building federated data ecosystems, navigating data sovereignty, and fostering cross-regional collaboration—while drawing connections and insights that may be relevant to New Zealand’s own data governance community.
Our speakers for this event are:
Malcolm Fraser - Malcolm is a data governance and digital innovation specialist focused on unlocking the value of data across public, private, and social sectors. Currently leading the Pacific Data Hub Team at Pacific Community (SPC), based in New Caledonia, he is committed to advancing ethical data practices and building integrated data ecosystems that benefit society, the environment, and the economy.
Kevin Sweeney - Kevin is the Data Governance Advisor for SPC – Pacific Community, the preeminent international development organisation for the Pacific. He is currently leading an initiative to implement and improve Data Governance within SPC, across its Pacific Island nation members, and amongst its international partners. Prior to joining SPC, Kevin served as the Principal Advisor for the Data System Leadership branch of Stats NZ, advising the Government Chief Data Steward, helping strengthen data capability across the government data system, while serving as the New Zealand delegate on international data forums. With several decades of experience scoping and implementing data and information strategies and systems, Kevin has worked in numerous capacities in New Zealand and the United States, including as Director of the New Zealand Geospatial Office, founding partner of a strategic consulting firm, and independently through his own management consulting practice.
Event Details
This event will be an in-person event and online.
Online
The link to the Teams meeting is here.
In Person
If you wish to attend to in person, please email emailforhugh@gmail.com to register before Wednesday the 5th of November. Pre-registering helps speed up the event! The event will be held in the Kāinga Ora offices, 7 Waterloo Quay in Wellington. Please enter at the end of the building closest to the new BNZ building and go to Level 5 where the Kāinga Ora reception is.
When registering, please OPT IN to following us so we can keep you updated of more events in the future!

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Our Fair Ladies (April 2025), Our Fair Ladies Tour
Embark on a captivating journey through the history buried in Karori Cemetery with our tour showcasing the remarkable lives of Wellington's women.
This tour offers a unique opportunity to celebrate the resilience, creativity and empowerment of women at a time when a woman couldn't have a bank account in her own name.  You'll hear the stories of women who had a range of interesting occupations. 
Be inspired by the incredible impact of these women's lives in early Wellington.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page.

Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We will meet before the tour at the Shelter (listed as Historic chapel on the map)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

ENM/Poly Speed Dating, Are you looking to meet like-minded people who embrace polyamory? Join us for an exciting evening of Poly Speed Dating! This event is for those who practice or are interested in consensual non-monogamy, offering a safe and inclusive environment to connect and potentially spark new friendships/relationships.

Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

We will have a private function space for this event.

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Join us for a belated celebration of the fathers and father figures in our lives. We welcome everyone to join us, including students and mothers, so make sure to get everyone a ticket.
Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 6:30pm-9pm
Cost: $25 per person, which includes a pizza dinner and a drink
Please bring gold coins for some exciting games to be played throughout the evening.
This event is part of the 2025 Middle School Challenge fundraiser for Blind Low Vision NZ. Our Middle School Leaders have the unique opportunity to sponsor the development and training of a Guide Dog named Cooper, which costs about $25,000. This tour traverses some of the older parts of the story where historic headstones mark the stories of lives lost too soon: accidents, murder, misadventure and those who fell by their own hand.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.

Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.

If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets

description:
Gender Attitudes Survey Launch 2025, Kia ora koutou,
The National Council of Women of New Zealand / Te Kaunihera Wāhine o Aotearoa (NCWNZ) warmly invites you to the launch of our Gender Attitudes Survey, sharing the latest perceptions of gender equality in Aotearoa.
Join us on Wednesday, 17 September at the Tiakiwai Conference Centre at the National Library where we will present the key findings from our 5th biannual survey. The Gender Attitudes Survey measures New Zealanders’ views on gender roles in the home, education, workplaces, and in the wider community. We will explore how attitudes have changed since our first baseline survey in 2017, and what these results mean for advancing gender equality in Aotearoa New Zealand.
We will be hosting an amazing group of speakers on the day to talk about the Survey results and what that means for gender equality in New Zealand. More information will be available on this page when speakers are confirmed. Watch the space!
Speakers
Host, Suzanne Manning, President, NCWNZ
Suzanne Manning is the current President of NCWNZ, having been involved for 20 years as a member. She has a background in education and social research, and is passionate about progress towards gender equality.
Keynote speaker: Professor Gail Pacheco
Professor Gail Pacheco is the Equal Employment Opportunities (EEO) Commissioner at the Human Rights Commission. A leading economist, she has previously been the Director of the NZ Policy Research Institute at AUT and a Commissioner at the NZ Productivity Commission. She has an extensive track record of social policy-focused research, often leading large-scale collaborations between academia, community organisations, and the public sector.
Gail has been the recipient of numerous awards. These include: the 2018 NZIER Economics Award for outstanding contributions to the advancement of economics and its applications in NZ; the AUT Medal in 2019 in recognition of her use of integrated data to inform social policy and wellbeing; and most recently, in 2025, she was awarded Life Membership of the New Zealand Association of Economists, an honour reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to both the association and the economics profession in NZ.
Emanuel Kalafatelis, Research New Zealand
Emanuel has been involved in the social and marketing research industry in Aotearoa New Zealand for over 40 years. For most of those years, he has managed a wholly independent research company, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, based in Wellington and mainly servicing clients in the public sector. In addition to the Gender Attitudes Survey, Emanuel has led and been involved in several ‘landmark’ research projects, including projects aimed at measuring New Zealanders’ attitudes to subject topics such as changing the New Zealand flag, New Zealand becoming a republic, the sale of public assets, genetic modification and the impact of COVID-19. Emanuel is a Fellow and current member of the Research Association of New Zealand Inc.
Dellwyn Stewart, CE YWCA Auckland, Board member NCWNZ
Dellwyn Stuart is a leader with a track record of developing and executing transformational strategy, successfully influencing decision makers and stakeholders, and finding solutions in complex, ambiguous environments. Currently as CEO of YWCA, she is passionate about contributing to a future for Aotearoa that is more equitable for all, and finds joy and optimism in her work with young women. Her career spans the commercial and not for profit sectors with a depth of knowledge and experience in philanthropy, fundraising, stakeholder engagement and gender issues.
Youth speaker (name and bio to come)
In-person and virtual attendance
If you’re joining us in person, there will be light refreshments after the launch when you can enjoy conversation with other attendees. Online tickets are also available. Please note that this event will be live streamed from 6pm and recorded for sharing after the launch.
Acknowledgments
The Gender Attitudes Survey and launch are generously supported by the Manatu Wahine Ministry for Women, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, YWCA Auckland.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: National Monuments (Dec 2025), The two main stops on the tour are the Cemeteries’ two national Monuments – the Tangiwai disaster and Prime Minister Peter Fraser.  We will review what happened at Tangiwai and especially the bravery of the trains crew and in addition, what the court of inquiry found about the safety of the bridge. 
Peter Fraser is generally regarded as one of NZ’s best Prime Ministers of the 20th century, and we explore his initiatives in public health and education and also his leadership during WW2.
These are just two of the several stops we will make.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
This tour requires reasonable physical fitness and sadly is not suited for those with limited mobility. 
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you 1 hour before the tour start time by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Wellington Foraging for Wild Edible Weeds Workshop, Join Felicity of Wild Botanica for a wander around the edges of the Innermost Community gardens to learn about commonly found, wild, edible weeds. Build a relationship with a natural world that is overflowing with abundant, wild, edible, nutritious, medicinal plants. Learn their names & get to know them, along with folklore & stories from the past.

By the end of the workshop you will:
- understand the basic principles of foraging, including sustainable harvesting
- feel confident in identifying 10-15 wild edible plants
- know about their nutritional & medicinal benefits
- know about common toxic/dangerous plants to avoid when foraging
- know about the best ways to prepare your foraged greens for maximum nutritional benefit & flavor
- feel empowered to include foraged greens in your everyday diet

Walk away with hands on, practical skills & knowledge that you can use in your own life.

Investment includes hands on wild weed walk & discussion, cup of foraged herbal tea & wildly delicious foraged snack.

To learn more about Felicity and her offerings,
visit @wildbotanica.nz on social media
or www.wildbotanica.co.nz.
For any queries, please email felicity@wildbotanica.co.nz.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
NZIFF: Young Mothers, The Dardenne brothers return with a deeply affecting drama exploring the lives of five teen mothers. Hopes and fears steer the young women towards bettering their lives for themselves and their children.

Young Mothers examines the lives of underprivileged teenagers as they come to terms with motherhood for the first time. Living together temporarily in a group home, they are taught how to care for their babies, while grappling with very different personal circumstances. The Dardenne brothers treat the characters with delicate respect while humanising the tumultuous reality that often comes with teenage motherhood.

Jessica, raised in an orphanage, cannot imagine abandoning her child and desperately seeks closure from her birth mother. Julie considers giving up her daughter for adoption, yet her own troubled mother wishes to raise the child to atone for her past mistakes. Brought up by an alcoholic mother, Perla dreams of a stable family, but her delinquent boyfriend wants nothing to do with her or their child. While Ariane has the privilege of a loving partner, both are recovering drug addicts which presents its own challenges.

This is a story of hope told through characters looking for a future free from their past. — Madison Marshall

Helpful tools for searching NZ historical records, Helpful tools for searching NZ historical records
The Wellington Branch of the NZ Society of Genealogists hosts a demonstration of online tools that make searching for your New Zealand families easier.

JETAA Wellington’s monthly Japanese conversation evening. JKaiWa welcomes language learners and native speakers to come and enjoy casual conversation in Japanese with like-minded people!
This month JKaiWa will be held on Thursday 9th October from 5:30pm - 7:00pm, at the usual place, the Japan Information and Cultural Centre, Level 18, Majestic Centre, 100 Willis Street Wellington CBD.

https://forms.gle/fernCvWAwM9hhG3M7

description:
John Campbell’s Destiny Church Investigation: Part 2 Under His Command, John Campbell investigated Destiny Church in a five-part documentary screened in April this year.
Join us to watch Part 2 of John Campbell’s Destiny Church investigation. John Campbell highlights some consistent themes of Brian Tamaki's Destiny Church: far-right prejudices, manifest anger, and hatred.
In Auckland on 21 June, Destiny Church organised a march to take "a bold public stand for Christian values, Kiwi identity and the future of this nation".
On Saturday, 13 September, Brian Tamaki attended the London “Unite the Kingdom” protest organised by far-right political activist Tommy Robinson that claimed to celebrate 'free speech', but also contained chants of hate, racist conspiracy theories, and Christian nationalist slogans. Among disturbing scenes, some people in the crowd ripped up a flag that read 'Secular Humanism'. To them, the very idea that people of all backgrounds and beliefs can live together with equality and respect is something to fear and destroy. For decades, the far right in the USA has painted humanism as a bogeyman, blaming it for liberal values, the rights of women, and the rights of LGBT people. It shows that those who thrive on fear are deliberately targeting the very values that underpin human rights and human dignity. Humanism is not a fringe or ‘woke’ idea. It is about fairness. It is about reason. It is about believing in the good that people are capable of when they are free to live their lives without fear or prejudice. These protests, which Brian Tamaki is supporting, are a show of force from those who wish to undo progress, to divide communities, and to undermine cherished freedoms.
We have a growing concern for secular values in our community. We cannot be silent. It is essential to keep compassion alive in public life and politics. After watching the documentary, we will discuss our concerns and how we might respond.
Time: Oct 6, 2025 06:30 PM Auckland, Wellington
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/88183700512...
label: Community & Culture

description:
Michelin Star to Martinborough, Join celebrated Chef and Union Square owner Adam Newell for a once-in-a-lifetime culinary experience. Take a journey through four decades of his exceptional career, including his Michelin-starred tenure at the renowned Fulham Road Restaurant in London. This exclusive event will offer an intimate exploration of Chef Newell's evolution as a chef and restaurateur, showcasing iconic dishes from four pivotal periods in his career.

Set in the elegant Napoleon dining room inside the historic Martinborough Hotel, each course represents a defining moment in Chef Newell’s career. Paired with fine wines selected by in-house Sommelier Carl Fraser, this evening is designed to be a feast for both the palate and the mind.

Course 1: 1980s – Claridge’s Hotel, London
A taste of the refined sophistication from one of London’s most prestigious hotels.
Course 2: 1990s – Le Gavroche, London
A nod to the classic French techniques that helped shape Chef Newell's early career.
Course 3: 2000s – Zibibbo, Wellington
A celebration of New Zealand’s finest ingredients and a significant step in his culinary journey.
Course 4: 2010s – Union Square Bistro, Martinborough
Reflecting his achievements at Union Square, the course that represents his current culinary vision.

This evening offers guests a unique chance to experience the evolution of one chef's journey through extraordinary dishes paired with wines that elevate each moment.
label: Food & Drink

description:
International Day of the Girl - 2025, You are Invited to our inaugural International Day of the Girl Fundraising to celebrate the work of Heartprint Cambodia.

The AquaPura Project is raising funds for a new Safe Water installation, and an Emergency Rapid Response Kit for Heartprint in Cambodia.
Heartprint is wholly aligned with AquaPura's mission to educate and provide technical training for girls to be safe water system installers and maintenance leads, so they are provided an opportunity to succeed in a male-dominated industry of essential water provision services.

The theme of International Day of the Girl Child 2025 is:
"The Girl I Am, the Change I Lead: Girls on the Frontline of Crisis". 

This theme was developed in consultation with girls' organisations, UN partners, and girls themselves.

This theme emphasise the leadership potential of girls and their role in driving positive change, particularly in the face of crisis. 

The International Day of the Girl, observed annually on 11th October, aims to highlight the challenges girls face globally, and promote their rights and empowerment. 

The 2025 theme specifically acknowledges the unique experiences and contributions of girls during times of crisis, recognising them as agents of change. 

This fundraiser will be led by Girls, who deeply understand the importance of delivering Safe Water for Every Child.
Heartprint is a not for profit organisation committed to improving living standards of underprivileged families in Cambodia. Heartprint takes a holistic approach to charity by building the Heartprint Community Centre. They are able to provide the support that looks at the whole family structure, not just the basic living needs, but also addressing their overall physical, emotional, social, and spiritual wellbeing.

SCHEDULE: Sat 4 October InPerson Venue
10-12pm: Room 2
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)
1 - 3 pm: Room 1
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table:
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: More Catholic Tales (Nov 2025), Further Catholic Tales - new tour
Hear about a poet, a writer, soldiers and stories of Wellington history. Further Catholic Tales tells the stories of the wide range of people interred in the section known as Catholic 2.
The tour duration is 1 hour 30mins. The tour mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness.

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Gender Attitudes Survey Launch 2025, Kia ora koutou,
The National Council of Women of New Zealand / Te Kaunihera Wāhine o Aotearoa (NCWNZ) warmly invites you to the launch of our Gender Attitudes Survey, sharing the latest perceptions of gender equality in Aotearoa.
Join us on Wednesday, 17 September at the Tiakiwai Conference Centre at the National Library where we will present the key findings from our 5th biannual survey. The Gender Attitudes Survey measures New Zealanders’ views on gender roles in the home, education, workplaces, and in the wider community. We will explore how attitudes have changed since our first baseline survey in 2017, and what these results mean for advancing gender equality in Aotearoa New Zealand.
We will be hosting an amazing group of speakers on the day to talk about the Survey results and what that means for gender equality in New Zealand. More information will be available on this page when speakers are confirmed. Watch the space!
Speakers
Host, Suzanne Manning, President, NCWNZ
Suzanne Manning is the current President of NCWNZ, having been involved for 20 years as a member. She has a background in education and social research, and is passionate about progress towards gender equality.
Keynote speaker: Professor Gail Pacheco
Professor Gail Pacheco is the Equal Employment Opportunities (EEO) Commissioner at the Human Rights Commission. A leading economist, she has previously been the Director of the NZ Policy Research Institute at AUT and a Commissioner at the NZ Productivity Commission. She has an extensive track record of social policy-focused research, often leading large-scale collaborations between academia, community organisations, and the public sector.
Gail has been the recipient of numerous awards. These include: the 2018 NZIER Economics Award for outstanding contributions to the advancement of economics and its applications in NZ; the AUT Medal in 2019 in recognition of her use of integrated data to inform social policy and wellbeing; and most recently, in 2025, she was awarded Life Membership of the New Zealand Association of Economists, an honour reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to both the association and the economics profession in NZ.
Emanuel Kalafatelis, Research New Zealand
Emanuel has been involved in the social and marketing research industry in Aotearoa New Zealand for over 40 years. For most of those years, he has managed a wholly independent research company, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, based in Wellington and mainly servicing clients in the public sector. In addition to the Gender Attitudes Survey, Emanuel has led and been involved in several ‘landmark’ research projects, including projects aimed at measuring New Zealanders’ attitudes to subject topics such as changing the New Zealand flag, New Zealand becoming a republic, the sale of public assets, genetic modification and the impact of COVID-19. Emanuel is a Fellow and current member of the Research Association of New Zealand Inc.
Dellwyn Stewart, CE YWCA Auckland, Board member NCWNZ
Dellwyn Stuart is a leader with a track record of developing and executing transformational strategy, successfully influencing decision makers and stakeholders, and finding solutions in complex, ambiguous environments. Currently as CEO of YWCA, she is passionate about contributing to a future for Aotearoa that is more equitable for all, and finds joy and optimism in her work with young women. Her career spans the commercial and not for profit sectors with a depth of knowledge and experience in philanthropy, fundraising, stakeholder engagement and gender issues.
Youth speaker (name and bio to come)
In-person and virtual attendance
If you’re joining us in person, there will be light refreshments after the launch when you can enjoy conversation with other attendees. Online tickets are also available. Please note that this event will be live streamed from 6pm and recorded for sharing after the launch.
Acknowledgments
The Gender Attitudes Survey and launch are generously supported by the Manatu Wahine Ministry for Women, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, YWCA Auckland.

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE, Kapiti Crop Swap WAIKANAE
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE WAIKANAE SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
2-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
2.15-2.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
2.45-3pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Live & Work in Japan! Q&A Evening with JET Programme Alumni, Have you ever wanted to live and work in Japan?
Come talk
to some people who've done it!
Every year, a diverse range of New Zealanders representing a variety of backgrounds, ages, interests, and cultures start a life-changing adventure in Japan-and next year that could include you!
With applications for the New Zealand JET Programme around the corner, you may have questions about what it's actually like to be sent off to live and teach in Japan for a year or more!
The JET Alumni Association of Wellington, in coordination with The Embassy of Japan, have organised a casual evening event for prospective applicants to ask those questions, and hear some stories to help you make a better decision about if the JET Programme is right for you.
Q&A event details
Date: 6th October 2025
Time: 17:30 - 19:30
Location: Yoshi Sushi & Bento (Press Hall, Willis Street)
Doors open from 5:30, with Q&A starting from 6:00.
Enjoy free
courtesy of Yoshi Sushi & Bento.
(Drinks, including Japanese
will also be available for purchase).
Admission to the event is FREE!
So come along and bring your friends
to this great opportunity to meet a handful of the thousands of Kiwis who've taken part in this programme over the past 40 years
Anyone interested in applying is welcome to attend!

What is the Japan Exchange Teaching (JET) Programme, you ask?
The JET Programme is an overseas employment opportunity to live and work in Japan for a year or more! You could soon head abroad on the adventure of a lifetime, and get paid for it!
Programme criteria includes the following-are you:
A New Zealand citizen?
Already graduated?
Or will have your Bachelor's Degree/Teaching Diploma conferred by early July 2026?
Interested in international activities?
Interested in teaching English to young people and living in Japan?

Positions available:
Assistant Language Teacher (ALT)
ALTs help the Japanese foreign language teachers in class and help prepare teaching materials and class activities. They may assist in English language clubs and other extra-curricular activities. Knowledge of Japanese is not required to be an ALT.
Coordinator for International Relations (CIR)
CIRs work in local government offices and are involved in international activities, which might include editing publications, translation work, advising on the planning and implementation of exchange programmes, and interpreting at international events. A functional knowledge of written and spoken Japanese is required to be a CIR.
For more information about the New Zealand JET Programme, visit:
https://www.nz.emb-japan.go.jp/itpr_en/jet.html
https://www.facebook.com/JETProgrammeNZ/
We hope to see you there!

description:
Opening Floor Talks, Opening Floor Talks
Join us as we walk you through two exciting and vibrant new shows here at The Dowse.

About this Event

Wing and a Prayer blends humour with reverence, with fast food fountains and a holy water vending machine. Featuring works by Isabella Lepoamo, Sacha Lees, Scott Eady, Sian Torrington and Sophia Smolenski, join curators Chelsea Nichols and Milly Mitchell-Anyon as they explore the tension between adaptation and authenticity alongside some of the artists.
SOFTY is an exhibition of textile works from The Dowse’s permanent collection, including recent acquisitions, revealing The Dowse’s softer side, and our steadfast commitment to collecting craft. Milly and Chelsea will talk you through the pieces in the show, as well as give a wider view on how these pieces fit into The Dowse Collection. With works by Gordon Crook, Malcolm Harrison, Areez Katki, Maungarongo Te Kawa, Turumeke Harrington, Jakob Rowlinson, Daegan Wells and Steven Junil Park, SOFTY showcases the variety of textiles collected by The Dowse.
Alongside the opening of these new shows we are celebrating the creativity of local arts in the Lower Hutt Art Trail this weekend.

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20

The Sunday 19 October session is fully booked.
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.
label: Community & Culture

description:
The Lighthouse Trio at Inverlochy Art School, Join us as we explore some new interpretations of familiar melodies and unheard compositions! The trio will play original arrangements of favourite tunes as well as come brand new original songs. Expect mysterious ballads, soulful blues, and exhilarating bop.
The Lighthouse Trio is made up of three of Wellington's busiest players; Alex Trask, Jeremy Grant, and Elijah Mulheron. Alex is a highly regarded alto saxophonist who is seen all around town leading bands and playing for some of the leading musical organisations, including the RNZAF band and formerly the Rodger Fox Big Band. Elijah is the busiest bassist in town and often appears with Wellington legends such as Callum Allardice and John Rae. Jeremy is an extremely captivating guitarist and the creative force behind the arrangements you will hear.
The trio is celebrating the release of their debut EP with a tour of their own backyard, playing for the first time in Pito-one and Raumati, and finishing with a gig in central Wellington. Come along for an evening of fresh music presented in a relaxed setting, we hope to see you there!
Door sales available
label: Music & Concerts

description:
National Library 60th Birthday Open Home, Here’s to 60 years! Your National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa is turning 60 and we’re opening our doors in Wellington to invite you, your whānau and communities to celebrate with us.
Come along to view our collections up close, take part in activities and join guided tours of the He Tohu exhibition and our collection stores.
Our curators, librarians, archivists and conservators will share some of their favourite collection items and take visitors behind the scenes of the Library. There will be tours of He Tohu, a chance to help build a replica waka and a kids’ corner to keep the whānau entertained. At 2pm, we’ll be celebrating with cake.
Our friends at City Gallery Wellington will be open from 1pm to 4pm.
Experience your taonga
View a display of our collections from the National Library and the Alexander Turnbull Library, featuring taonga from books, comics, manuscripts, photos and more.
Learn about what we collect, how we collect and how you can make the Library your whare through making the most of our services and connecting with our collections. Drop in to chat with Library staff, learn more about our work and get up close with the collections.
Build a waka with friends
Help build the replica voyaging waka Whakaura and learn how Māori and Pacific peoples used their knowledge and navigational expertise to sail their amazing waka across one-third of the earth’s surface.
***Join a guided tour***
Explore our back of house — Take a special guided tour of our collection repositories and learn more about how we preserve the cultural heritage of Aotearoa New Zealand. Don’t miss out on this very rare opportunity to take a peek behind the scenes and see some exciting taonga in our collection stores.
Tours are 45 minutes and booking is essential as spaces are limited. Please email us to reserve your place — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz.
***Take a tour of He Tohu***
No booking required. Join our friendly kaiārahi for a guided tour of our exhibition He Tohu and view the three iconic constitutional documents that are shaping Aotearoa New Zealand:
*1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
*1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
*1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
History of the National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa: The National Library was formed in 1965 when the General Assembly Library, the Alexander Turnbull Library and the National Library Service (comprising the Country Library Service and the School Library Service) were brought together by the National Library Act 1965. For the past 60 years, we’ve continued to grow and evolve our collections and services.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Ngāwi Community Emergency Response Planning, Come along to the Ngāwi Community Hall on 27 September to learn more about your community’s emergency response plans.

At this session you will:

- Learn how making your own household plan beforehand will make a positive difference in an emergency.
- Learn more about Community Emergency Hubs and the type of help that is needed after an emergency.
- Learn more about and provide feedback on Ngāwi Community Emergency Plans.

Food will be provided. We look forward to seeing you there!

For more information, please email info@wremo.nz

We aim to make our community events inclusive to all people. If you are attending the event and have specific accessibility requirements, you can send us an email at info@wremo.nz with the event name and we will get in touch to see how we can meet your needs as best we can.

We’re here to fix and advise on:

description:
NAWIC 2025 Annual General Meeting, Join us for NAWIC’s 2025 AGM on Wednesday, 15 October.
The AGM is your opportunity to:
Hear about NAWIC’s progress and plans for the year ahead
Have your say on key decisions shaping our organisation
Connect with fellow members and industry peers
Celebrate 30 years of NAWIC and the collective impact we’ve made
Whether you’re a long-time member or new to NAWIC, your voice matters. Together, we’re shaping an equitable construction sector where women are empowered to thrive.
We look forward to seeing you there.
If you are unable to attend in person, please register your apology here:
NAWIC AGM 2025 Apology
Start time: 5.30pm arrival for a 6.00pm AGM kick-off.
Venue: Aoraki Construction, L1, 74 Cambridge Terrace, Wellington
 Come as you are - snacks will be provided
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organization, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015. Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20

The Sunday 19 October session is fully booked.
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
October Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Pacific Peoples and the Underclass of Aotearoa New Zealand: Repositioning the Narrative, In 2018, over 380,000 people in Aotearoa New Zealand identified with at least one Pacific ethnicity. Despite being a youthful and growing community, Pacific peoples are statistically entrenched in a cycle of disadvantage that cannot be ignored.
In almost every measure—health, education, income, home ownership, and justice—Pacific people are overrepresented in poor outcomes.
We are not just facing a Pacific problem; we are looking at the face of New Zealand’s underclass—systemic, intergenerational, and largely invisible in mainstream policy conversations. Despite progress for some groups, the Pacific population remains on the wrong side of the statistical ledger.
Pacific peoples experience:
• The highest rates of avoidable hospitalisations and chronic conditions.
• Worst material deprivation across nearly every indicator.
• Persistently low home ownership rates.
• A widening education achievement gap, often masked by ethnic averages.
• Underrepresentation in decision-making, leadership, and governance roles.
While initiatives for Māori advancement are critical and must continue, Pacific peoples require their own distinct policy lens. A “one-size-fits-all” approach under a pan-ethnic umbrella risks making the Pacific experience invisible.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55

description:
Pride In Place: Creating a Community Walk Tour, Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.
Please sign-up here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).
label: Community & Culture
