description:
Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour
Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.

Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
Pottery for Tweens & Teens - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, Join us for this fun and relaxing two hour pottery where you'll handcraft your own garden orb from clay with experienced ceramicist, Christine Winbush. You will have the option of creating your orb into a hanging planter or a unique decoration for your room or garden. Teens will learn basic hand-building techniques to create with clay.

The pieces will be decorated with underglaze and fired. All art will be ready for pickup approximately 3 weeks later depending on drying times.

Recommended age for this workshop is tweens & teens ages 10 and above.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.
label: Family Friendly

description:
Kotahitanga: Artist Series - Te KuraHuia, Known for her lively performances infused with Mātauranga Moana, emerging multidisciplinary artist Te KuraHuia will spark the mauri, inspired by He Kura Toi Tangata.

Te KuraHuia brings a next generation Māori-Pacific and Two-Spirit lens to their confronting and hopeful response.

5:30pm Doors open, bar open
6pm Artist response begins
6:30pm Interval
6:45pm Artist Q&A
7pm Closing Karakia and time to explore He Kura Toi Tangata exhibition
8pm Bar closes, event ends

About Te KuraHuia

Also known as Thee Bad Mana Wahine, Te KuraHuia pours positive energy into her beats to empower rangatahi to chase their dreams and inspire all to love themselves.


This event has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
Open Mic Night at Eva, Eva Pub's Open Mic Night: A Celebration of Wellington's Finest Musicians!

Join us every Thursday night at Eva Pub for an unforgettable celebration of Wellington's vibrant music scene!
With an electrifying array of local talent and plenty of opportunities for you to shine, there's no better place to experience the magic of live music than your favorite local hangout.
When: Every Thursday
Time: 8:00 PM Onwards with DJ set from DKav after the open mic
Where: Eva Pub, 35 Dixon Street, 6011
What to Expect:
Local Talent Showcase: Our stage is open for musicians of all genres, offering a platform for both seasoned performers and emerging artists.
Supportive Atmosphere: Hosted every week, our Open Mic Night is more than just an event; it's a community. Our friendly host will help you settle in, assist with setup, and organize the sets to ensure a seamless and enjoyable experience.
Community of Creatives: Experience the warmth of a community that appreciates and supports local and new performances. Whether you're a regular or a first-timer, our stage welcomes you with open arms.
Why You Should Be Here:
Discover Hidden Gems: Uncover the hidden musical gems that Wellington has to offer. Our Open Mic Night is a melting pot of diverse talents waiting to be discovered.
Join In or Enjoy as a Spectator: Whether you're a performer or a music enthusiast, our Open Mic Night is the perfect place to share your talent or simply enjoy a night of entertaintment.
Secure Your Spot:
Don't miss out! Reserve your spot now for Eva Pub's Open Mic Night
Let's make Thursday nights at Eva Pub the highlight of your week as we come together to celebrate the incredible music that our city has to offer. See you there!

Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour, Pride in Place: creating a community walk tour
Join the team from Walk Tours NZ for a free and inspiring presentation on how to create and run your own non-profit community walk tour.

Over the past seven years, Walk Tours NZ has delivered more than 100 community tours around central Wellington, focusing on the city’s rich LGBTQIA+ Rainbow heritage.

This event goes behind the scenes of creating a walk tour and is perfect for anyone passionate about bringing place-based history to light – whether it’s Rainbow histories or a topic of your own choosing.

Hosts Roger Smith and Gareth Watkins will guide you through the key ingredients of a successful non-profit walk tour – including identifying interesting stops, crafting compelling narratives, and being an engaging host – even if you’ve never done it before!

The presentation will cover both traditional methods of researching and writing, as well as demonstrate some off-the-shelf Artificial Intelligence applications that can help support your storytelling.

Bring your curiosity, enthusiasm and ideas, and discover why walk tours offer a unique form of living history – and how the experience can build community and connect people. No previous walk tour experience is necessary, and all are welcome.

The Queen Elizabeth II Pukeahu Education Centre (formerly the Home of Compassion Crèche) in Pukeahu Park has limited space, so registration is essential.

Please register here: https://walktours.nz/book

This free community event is part of the Aotearoa Festival of Architecture 2025, organised by Walk Tours NZ in collaboration with the New Zealand Institute of Architects (Wellington Branch).

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55

description:
Sapphic Speed Dating Dinner Party, This 4-course sapphic experience is more like a big gay dinner party than a traditional speed dating event (it even features fabulous local performer, Ginger Velour, as the MC to guide you through the evening!) With each course in the meal, you’ll switch tables and sit with a new group of 4-6 cute strangers—although it’s Wellington, so no guarantees it won’t be your ex. There will be conversation question cards on the tables if you get stuck on what to say, but your best chats will come from just being yourself!

And don’t stress about asking a hottie for their number if you’re shy—we’ve designed this experience to be as easy and low-stakes as possible. Each attendee will have a paper bag “mailbox” that you can slip a note into at the end of the night to avoid any awkward face-to-face interactions. Whether you both want to connect after that is up to you, but this is the time to shoot your shot!

After purchasing a ticket, you will be sent a short questionnaire. Please fill it out promptly! This helps the organisers place you in groups with similar interests so you have the best chance at finding what you’re looking for.

No TERFs no SWERFs. This event is open to all people 18+ who identify as sapphic/lesbian/queer. Bi, pan, questioning, and ace folks are all welcome.

Additional info:
- Most dietary requirements can be accommodated by the amazing chefs at Everybody Eats. Please include your dietaries when prompted in the questionnaire.
- Accessibility: Everybody Eats is up a flight of stairs and does not have wheelchair access. There are gender neutral bathrooms inside the restaurant and all chairs have backs. If you'd prefer not to stand up and move around the space after each course, please email the organiser with any mobility requests at goldenhourgigz@gmail.com

description:
Erskine Chapel Market & Open Day, Erskine Chapel Market & Open Day
✨ Erskine Chapel Open Day & Craft Market ✨
📅 Sunday, 2 November 2025 | 10:00am – 3:00pm
📍 Erskine Chapel, 31 Avon Street, Island Bay, Wellington

Nestled high on the hillside in Island Bay, Erskine Chapel is a breathtaking and iconic landmark, with sweeping views across the hills and ocean, and a gothic charm that has captured hearts for generations.

Now in its third year, this much loved annual event returns as part of Heritage Month, celebrating the beauty, history, and cultural significance of one of Wellington’s most treasured buildings.

Foxtail Events and The Wellington Company are once again partnering to open the chapel’s doors for the community, inviting everyone to experience this remarkable space brought back to life.

Join us for a special Community Open Day and Craft Market, where you can:

* Explore a curated market of local artisans and makers
* Discover the chapel’s rich history and stunning architecture
* Enjoy live music, freshly brewed coffee, and delicious baked goods

Whether you're drawn by the history, the creativity, or the peaceful atmosphere, this is a day to celebrate local talent and honour the legacy of a true Wellington landmark.

🗓️ Mark your calendar and don’t miss this enchanting day at Erskine Chapel. A place of stories, memories, and timeless beauty, reawakened for a new generation to enjoy.

description:
Shady Nasty, Debut Aotearoa Shows, Following the release of their debut album TREK and a string of sold-out shows across Sydney (Eora), Brisbane (Meanjin), and Melbourne (Naarm), Sydney post-punk trio Shady Nasty announce their debut tour in Aotearoa/New Zealand this September.

A world bound by modding cars, immigrant heritage and digital obsessions, Kevin Stathis, Haydn Green and Luca Watson, together play a left-field breed of punk that recalibrates their formal training to its most uncustomary extremes.

Wherever they play and no matter the room size, devout adherents clammer to propel a heaving mosh. Experience TREK live as Shady Nasty debut the record with an all-new live show, with special guests to be announced.

description:
Speed Dating 30-43, 40-55, Speed Daters will be split into 2 age groups which will run simultaneously. There will be opportunity to mix with the other group during the break. We will have a private area of the venue for this event. Price includes a drink and delicious food at the break!

When you arrive you will get a name label and your complimentary first drink, and will have time to settle in and mingle a little.

You will be Speed Dating with around 10 people over the course of the evening. You will have 7 minutes to chat to each person.
You then decide if you want to meet your Speed Dates again and tick interested on your form if you do. Only if the feeling is mutual will we email you each other’s contact details.

There will be an intermission where platters of food will be served, and you can buy yourself another drink if you like.

Speed dating does not have to be stressful or frightening; you will be pleasantly surprised how fun and positive it is.

Our event is designed to respect all boundaries and foster open, honest communication. Not everyone you meet will be your type, but we expect you to be polite. You only have to chat to them for seven minutes!

description:
Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band, Spring Céilí Dance with The Great Beag Céilí Band
Spring has sprung, the days are getting longer, the rain is falling sideways. Must be about time we had another céilí! Join The Great Beag Céilí Band at St Michael’s Hall in Kelburn for a rousing evening of dancing to foot-stomping celtic tunes. Our Autumn céilí sold out so make sure you get your tickets early!

If you’ve never been to a céilí (or ceilidh) before, fear not - céilí dancing is very easy! No fancy moves or any previous experience required: our caller will explain each dance, and we’ll all walk it through a couple of times before adding the music.

This is social dancing so bring all your friends! No need to bring a specific partner - there’ll be lots of friendly people to dance with.

Discounted online tickets are available on Humanitix until midnight on September 26th: $24 / $16 concession
https://events.humanitix.com/beag-ceili-spring-ceili-2025

Some door sales may be available on the day: $30 / $20 concession (cash only)

—

Doors open 7:30pm

Adults and age 10+ welcome. Under 16s accompanied by an adult.

Light refreshments will be available. We recommend bringing a water bottle to grab a quick drink between dances - hydration is key!
This is an alcohol-free event.

Getting here: St Michael’s Hall is located at 81 Upland Road in Kelburn Village, just behind the church.
There is very limited on-street parking in the village. We recommend public transport: the 4, 18, 21, and 22 buses stop regularly right outside coming up from Te Aro or down from Northland and Karori.

Be safe online: Tickets are only available online from the Humanitix event. Do not buy tickets from other sources such as Facebook comments or resale sites - these are always scams. If you can no longer attend, please contact us via Humanitix, our socials, or email to discuss refunds.

Health notice: Céilí dancing is a great way to meet lots of people. If you are feeling unwell then please stay home and rest this time, we will see you at the next one.

description:
Site Visit - Holcim Readymix Wellington, Ever wondered how concrete is made?
Join us on Thursday 4th September, for an exclusive NAWIC members-only site tour of the Holcim Readymix NZ plant. Grab a behind the scenes look at:
 🏗️ The Process: How raw materials like cement, aggregates & water are mixed to create concrete
⚙️ Batching & Mixing: How mix designs are selected and adjusted
📏 Quality: Quality controls & production oversight, including testing & slumping
🚚 Dispatch:  Loading, scheduling & delivery coordination
🌱 Sustainability: Low carbon products and how Holcim is approaching driving a circular economy
 The Details:
🕒 DATE and TIME: Thursday, 4th September, 1pm
📍 LOCATION: 121 Centennial Highway, Ngauranga Gorge
🚗PARKING: Parking is tricky! Please carpool if possible, limited parking is available at the front of the Holcim offices (2 car parks) and one more at the top car park. Alternatively, bus route #1 stops off at Ngauranga Gorge (Kiwi Point) stop and is a short walk away
🎟️ COST: Free to NAWIC members, with a maximum of 10 people on the tour, so please book your space consciously. Get in quick! You can join NAWIC here.
👷‍♀️PPE: Hard hat, hi-vis, steel-capped boots, glasses (Spare hard-hats/hi-vis are available if required, please make sure you advise us of what you need on your RSVP.)
 ABOUT HOLCIM: Holcim is a global company across Europe, Asia, Pacific, Latin America, Middle East and Africa.  Holcim NZ  is a leading supplier of cement, aggregates and ready-mix concrete in New Zealand dating back to 1888. You may have noticed their big silos on the Centre Port (near the Interislander). Holcim have a network of plants throughout New Zealand, and one of their main missions is around sustainability, where they actively promote low-carbon concrete solutions, including their premium range ECOPact ECOplanet.

description:
September Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising

description:
Behind the Scenes with VicASA: BDO Wellington, 🔥 Behind the Scenes with VicASA x BDO 🔥
Exams are coming - so why host events now?
Because your future doesn’t wait for finals.
Exams test your memory, but these events sharpen your career. While exams last weeks, the connections you’ll make at BDO last a lifetime.
Here’s the truth: top firms don’t just recruit; they provide support, advice, and insider tips to help you thrive as a student and future professional. These events aren’t distractions - they’re an investment in your success.
Therefore the VicASA exec made sure these events (just like the rest) are taking you beyond the lecture halls and giving you exclusive access inside the most influential firms in the accounting world. And yes, it’s all completely free.
Wednesday 24 September – BDO Open Office & LinkedIn Headshots from 2:30pm to 3:30pm! Arrive at 2:15pm to get the full experience!
Join us for an hour long experience to talk one-on-one with the most professional bodies from both the capital and international offices. And of course, 🍴 free food — because good conversations happen best over kai.
✨ What makes this event different from any other?
Most student events stop at surface-level networking. This goes further:
At BDO, you’ll step into an open-office tour led by BDO reps, chat one-on-one with professional buddies, and even get a professional LinkedIn headshot for free by selecting the "BDO - LinkedIn Headshot" option alongside your ticket (first in, first served!) to boost your personal brand.
⚡ Why you can’t miss this:
First-in, first-served — spaces are extremely limited
Genuine behind-the-scenes exposure you won’t find at standard info sessions
Practical takeaways: real answers, real connections, and a polished LinkedIn profile
💡 These are not your average student events. They’re designed to give you an authentic inside look at the top firms, preparing you for your next steps in a way that’s practical, personal, and powerful.

description:
Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse (8th & 9th Nov 2025), Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse (8th & 9th Nov 2025)
This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm.

About this Event

This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm!
Come visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse between 11am-1pm as part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025.
"The Upper Hutt Blockhouse is one of the few remaining buildings associated with the New Zealand wars, as well as a monument to Pākehā settler anxiety, built in fear of an attack by Māori that never came. Visit today and you’ll get a sense of the defensive ‘last stand’ mindset. On both floors you’ll find a series of balistraria, tightly angled gun slots through which members of the militia would defend their posts. Keep an eye out, too, for an exposed panel where you can see the fine gravel that was packed between the exterior weatherboards and inch-thick interior boards to absorb the impact of answering gunfire. Don’t be fooled by the windows – they were added later. Originally, the loop holes you’ll spy on the walls were the only way to see out."
Inside the Blockhouse, there’s an exhibition from Whirinaki Whare Taonga, telling the early story of Upper Hutt and its Blockhouse.
We will have some knowledgeable people available to share stories, answer questions and some light refreshments. Drop in between 11-1pm and stay as long as you like!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Harmonic Sound Journey at Space with Claudio, Harmonic Sound Journey at Space with Claudio
We invite you to a special evening of Sacred Harmonic Sound with multi-instrumentalist Claudio Escutia. This immersive sound journey offers a deeply restorative experience that invites you to settle into stillness, reconnect with the heart, and explore a sense of inner spaciousness through vibration and tone.
Claudio skilfully layers the sounds of gongs, crystal and Tibetan singing bowls, Native American flutes, and other traditional instruments, enhanced through high-quality audio equipment so the sound can be both heard and felt throughout your body.
Harmonic sound and vibration offer the nervous system a chance to truly rest. In this state of relaxation, the thinking mind softens, and we find connection to citta — the heart-mind. From this place, silence arises naturally through the vehicle of sound.
This experience is open to everyone. No previous yoga or meditation practice is needed.

What to bring:
You are welcome to bring your own yoga mat, though studio mats are also available. We will provide bolsters, blankets, and eye pillows for your comfort.

Booking is essential — spaces are limited and this event often fills quickly.

About Claudio
Claudio is a multi-instrumentalist musician originally from Mexico City and now based in Wellington. Born into a family of musicians, he began playing music at a young age and later studied classical guitar. His journey led him to Montreal, where he explored jazz, world music, and spiritual sound traditions.

Extensive travels in Asia and Europe deepened his connection with Indian music and yogic philosophy. He studied Tibetan singing bowls in Kathmandu and Varanasi, and has since worked with a wide range of instruments including the sitar, esraj, bansuri, harmonium, flutes, gongs, and voice.

Claudio’s work blends technical skill, deep presence, and a profound respect for the healing power of sound.

Learn more or listen to Claudio’s music here:
SoundCloud https://soundcloud.com/claudioescutiasounds
Instagram https://www.instagram.com/claudio_yoga_sound_healing
Facebook https://www.facebook.com/soundhealingyogamusicclaudio

description:
2025 Annual South Coast Cleanup, Welcome to the 16th annual South Coast Cleanup, 10:30AM-12:00PM 13th September 2025.
As well as caring for our coasts and oceans, it’s all about community! Join us at any of our cleanup locations for a morning of litter collection and family fun.

WHEN
We kick off at 10:30am on the 13 September. We host clean up sites at 12 locations between Owhiro Bay to Breaker Bay on the Wellington South Coast. All rubbish will be gathered up around 12.15pm and taken to Lyall Bay by the playground to form one huge rubbish mountain that will be collected by the council.

Pitch in for a rubbish pile up at 12:30 at Lyall Bay playground where we will mound up our rubbish and admire our collective efforts! Then we will head to Parrotdog for a drink / kai after!

WHERE
Our fantastic friendly volunteer groups will be scattered along the coastline between Owhiro Bay and Breaker Bay. You can turn up at any of our volunteer sites:

Site 1 - Owhiro Bay hosted by Project Jonah
Site 2 - Dive Wellington hosted by Dive Wellington
Site 3 - Island Bay West hosted by Mountains to Sea and Island Bay Residents Association
Site 4 - Island Bay Snorkel Trail hosted by Friends of Taputeranga
Site 5 - Houghton Bay hosted by Houghton Valley School
Site 6 - Te Raekkaihau Point hosted by Ghost Diving
Site 7 - Lyall Bay West hosted by Underwater Club Wellington
Site 8 - Lyall Bay Central hosted by Lyall Bay Coastal Care
Site 9 - Lyall Bay East hosted by Earth Science NZ (formerly NIWA)
Site 10 - Moa Point hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 11 - Tarakena Bay hosted by Places for Penguins
Site 12 - Breaker Bay hosted by Breaker Bay Residents Association

description:
AlterCOP30: Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd.
Donations are welcome to support climate education and action!
In solidarity with AlterCOP30, this November we’re running a series of climate events across Aotearoa - bringing communities together to learn, connect, and take action for a just and sustainable future.
AlterCOP is a Global Initiative founded by The Matcha Initiative and The Transmutation Principle, locally brought to you by Climate Club, Climate Crew, and Climate Training Co.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
NZIFF: Went Up the Hill, An unsettling, sinister slow-burn thriller, Samuel Van Grinsven unites rising star Dacre Montgomery with Phantom Thread’s Vicky Krieps and New Zealand’s own Sarah Peirse for a supernatural chiller like no other.

In the icy, shadow-stricken world of Went Up the Hill’s Christchurch, it would seem that the death of Elizabeth, wife of Jill (Vicky Krieps), has taken with it warmth itself. The unexpected suicide of her partner has left her a hollowed-out shell – that is, until Jack (Dacre Montgomery), Elizabeth’s long-absent son, arrives at the funeral, apparently invited by Jill herself, though she does not remember doing so.

The circumstances of Jack’s long absence are unclear – all that is known is that Jack was given up for adoption at a very young age. Staying the night at Jill and Elizabeth’s oppressive, concrete-clad mountain abode, it quickly becomes clear that the spirit of Elizabeth has not yet departed – instead, she has gained the ability to possess both wife and son and is utilising this ability to linger and address the needs of either relationship. What initially seems to be a gift from beyond, however, begins to sour when long-hidden secrets of the past begin to emerge, and lines between the two begin to be crossed.

The sophomore feature of Samuel Van Grinsven, Went Up the Hill is a wintry, gothic affair, and a showcase for the untapped talents of Montgomery, who most will recognise as the golden-haired, ill-fated muscle mutt Billy from Stranger Things. Essentially a two-hander (with occasional, welcome interjection from Kiwi legend Sarah Peirse as Jack’s frosty, mystery-shrouded aunt), Van Grinsven tracks the trajectory of these two adrift people and the spirit between them – from unexpected refuge, to joy, to dread – with a purposeful, drip-fed escalation of tension. Questions of control, abuse and the lingering weight of past scars take hold, all while the usually pleasantly scenic Christchurch landscape is transformed into a suffocatingly claustrophobic ice prison. Van Grinsven’s muscular direction bears none of the flashy excesses of an emerging filmmaker – his vision emerges, stately, imposing and fully-formed. — Tom Augustine
label: Film & Media

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Community Agency - a conversation with Markus Luczak-Roesch and Gerhard Reese, Two scholars share their perspectives on Community Agency and discuss the links between the Global environmental and global mental health crises.
  Gerhard Reese
Gerhard Reese works as Associate Professor for Climate Change at Te Herenga Waka - Victoria University Wellington in Aotearoa / New Zealand. Before, he was Professor and head of the Environmental Psychology Research Unit at the University Kaiserslautern-Landau in Germany since 2016. He got his PhD in Psychology from Friedrich Schiller University Jena, Germany, in February 2010. His research focuses on individual, social and systemic catalysts and barriers of pro-environmental behaviour and the nature-health nexus. He attempts and sometimes succeeds to spend more time outdoors than indoors and he still is a serious competitor in Super Mario Kart.
Markus Luczak-Roesch
Markus Luczak-Roesch is Professor of Informatics and the inaugural Chair in Complexity Science at Victoria University of Wellington’s School of Information Management. He is also one of two Co-Directors of Te Pūnaha Matatini, Aotearoa New  Zealand’s Centre of Research Excellence in Complex Systems. He founded and leads the Complexity & Connection Science Lab, an interdisciplinary group developing theories and computational tools to understand how complex systems unfold over time. His research investigates how structure and meaning emerge in systems - from language and brain activity to online communities and the environment - using models that reveal meaningful coincidences and unexpected system-level behaviors.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Climate Fresk Workshop in Wellington, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Community Planting Belmont Regional Park, Help us reforest the hills of Belmont Regional Park. By planting native trees and shrubs, we will restore the native ngahere/forests and create an ecological corridor for wildlife to travel between Wellington, Porirua, Kāpiti and the Hutt Valley.

We have partnered with GWRC, PCC, and local iwi to restore the hills of Belmont Park. Starting on the west hillside, our aim this year is to plant 5,000 native plants to create a forest for the future! This project aims to bring the community together to restore the hillsides of the Belmont Regional Park.

We provide all the tools and training, no prior experience needed. We can even provide transport to the site. Just bring your energy and lunch. We will provide you with a yummy morning tea.

Come have some fun planting with us and TAKE ACTION FOR NATURE!

This event is part of Conservation Week 2025 - www.doc.govt.nz/conservationweek

Sign up for this event on our website ConservationVolunteers.co.nz or email Wellington@cvnz.org.nz
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
COFFEE & CLAY Hand build your own ceramic butter dish, Join us for a relaxed, hands-on workshop where you'll create your very own ceramic butter dish in a working pottery studio. Over two inspiring hours, you'll learn the basics of hand-building with clay, guided step-by-step by a ceramic artist.
Enjoy fresh coffee and a home-baked morning tea as you get creative with shaping, decorating, and embellishing your piece. You'll finish by choosing your preferred glaze colours, and we'll take care of the firing process. Your finished butter dish will be ready to collect approximately four weeks later.
This small group workshop is perfect for absolute beginners—no experience needed. Come solo and meet like-minded creatives, or bring a friend for a fun and mindful morning.
You’ll be amazed at how calming it is to get out of your head and into your hands!

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.

description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Botany Tours for Conservation Week at Te Papa, Come behind the scenes to visit the Botany collection which houses more than 300,000 plant specimens collected in Aotearoa New Zealand and overseas.
There are two tours available:
Tuesday 2nd September BOH 11.30 – 12.30pm
Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM
You will find out how we store and take care of these valuable collections, and the research they support. There will be a chance to see our precious botanical taonga, including botanical specimens and art, and have a closer look at the very first plants collected by the European naturalists Joseph Banks and Daniel Solander over 250 years ago during Captain James Cook’s first voyage to New Zealand.

description:
Wairarapa Bookshop Hop 2025, The best booksellers in Wairarapa have come together to give you the ultimate book-lovers day out in celebration of New Zealand Bookshop Day.

This year, you can collect stamps from 13 new and used Wairarapa Bookshops and enjoy a range of other bookish events all day long.

One of the (many) great things about Wairarapa is we have 13 fantastic bookshops all within an easy 30 minute drive of one another, so it's entirely possible for you to hop around all 13 bookshops in a single day.

Celebrate NZ Bookshop Day with a Wairarapa wide Bookshop Hop. It's your chance to win lots of prizes and stock up your bookshelf.

STEP 1:
Pick up an official passport from any of the participating bookshops - available from all participating stores from Friday October 10th.

STEP 2:
Collect a stamp from each store you visit and make a purchase. Each stamp is an entry into the prize draws for $1,000 in bookshop vouchers.

STEP 3:
Leave your stamped entry with the last bookshop you visit.

This event happens rain or shine!

Register for free to stay up to date and for an extra chance to win a prize: bookshopday.nz/
label: Markets & Fairs

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Emma La Rocca - Zero waste swimwear, Emma La Rocca is the founder of Emroce swimwear, the world’s first zero-waste swimwear brand.
Her cutting patterns are designed to fit together perfectly- like a puzzle. This innovative technique fuels creativity, reduces costs, and saves up to a quarter of fabric from ending up in landfill.
Now, Emma is on a mission to help other fashion brands embrace Zero Waste Fashion Design (ZWFD). Through fully funded consulting, she’s breaking down misconceptions and showing how sustainability and style can go hand in hand.
Join Emma as she introduces the world of ZWFD, shares her results, and invites you to try out some simple techniques yourself.
Register for this free event, enjoy a complimentary breakfast from our sponsors, and take part in this inspiring conversation about sustainable fashion.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Friends AGM with guest speakers, Join the Friends of Wellington Botanic Garden for our Annual General Meeting and a pair of inspiring botanical presentations. You don’t have to be a member to attend — everyone’s invited!
Programme
Each presentation is 30 minutes, with time for questions.
Paul Bell-Butler
Botanist and PhD candidate, Paul is delving into the hidden world of leafy liverworts (family Lophocoleaceae). His research combines modern molecular techniques with traditional botany to reveal how these overlooked plants shape ecosystems and influence seed germination.
Clare Shearman
Plant Collection Team Manager at Wellington Botanic Garden, Clare brings a career spanning historic English estates to iconic New Zealand gardens. Fresh from the prestigious Longwood Gardens Fellows program in the USA, she shares insights into garden design, conservation, and how public gardens nurture wellbeing and connection.
Come along to hear their stories, celebrate our beautiful gardens, and meet fellow plant enthusiasts.
Located in the Treehouse Seminar Room, Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā.
For more info about the Friends: https://friendsofthewellingtonbotanic.wordpress.com/
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025, EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025
This year’s EBANZ (Earth Building Association of New Zealand) national conference will see industry leaders, innovators and enthusiasts come together to profile the latest ideas, technologies and projects shaping the future of low carbon, high performing, sustainable building in Aotearoa.

Set at Te Wānanga o Raukawa and the Forest Lakes Conference Centre on the Kāpiti Coast, the earth building conference will see builders, designers, researchers and earth-building enthusiasts explore how traditional and contemporary earth construction methods are shaping resilient, sustainable futures in Aotearoa and beyond.

Themed ‘Earth, Culture and Community’, the three-day conference in mid-November will include presentations, hands-on workshops, site visits and kōrero with leading voices in natural building, indigenous knowledge, climate-responsive design and regenerative practice, while also profiling New Zealand’s own set of earth building standards (NZS 4297, 4298 and 4299) 2024.

A ‘Professionals Day’ on Friday 14 November at Te Wānanga o Raukawa is aimed specifically at architects, engineers, inspectors, builders and designers interested in earth and natural building techniques. It will dive into the Tennent Brown Architects-designed Pā Reo campus at Te Wānanga (a Living Building Challenge project) and presenters will include Rau Hoskins of designTRIBE, Verena Maeder of Solid Earth and Sigi Koko, founder of Build Naturally USA.

Friday will be followed by the in-depth weekend conference at Forest Lakes, featuring talks and presentations aimed to inform and empower people on different aspects of earth and natural building as well as hands-on workshops in different methods and materials, including clay-based plasters, cob, rammed earth and adobe, straw bale and hempcrete. House tours will feature different building techniques, including straw bale and rammed earth, adobe, natural plasters and more.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Field trip: Innes Bush, Field trip: Innes Bush
Botanise a 38-hectare area of covenanted native bush, one of the largest private areas of protected conservation land close to Wellington. See 80-year-old regenerating bush, with large rimu and beech trees that were spared from historic felling. Also kāmahi on the higher areas and relict rimu, tōtara, miro and large black beech with a preponderance of kiekie/Freycinetia banksii on the wet gully floor and lower contours. Further information here: https://qeiinationaltrust.org.nz/newprotectioninwainuiomata/

Meet: 9.30 a.m. at 353 Moores Valley Rd. Travel via Wainuiomata Rd to intersection with Main Rd, next to Moores Valley Rd turn-off, then to end of road to no. 353.

Co-leaders: Laura Girvan-West 021 583 934/; Paul Bell-Butler .
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration Navigating Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Perspective, f🌍 Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration
Hosted by UNANZ Wellington in partnership with the British High Commission, Wellington
Join us for an engaging evening of insight and diplomacy as we explore how the United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United Nations are working together to drive global climate leadership.
This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. John Pearson, Deputy British High Commissioner at the British High Commission, will deliver a keynote speech followed by an open Q&A, offering a unique chance for attendees to ask questions and be part of the conversation.
Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.
Why attend?
Learn about climate diplomacy in action
Engage with leaders shaping global climate responses
Network with professionals, students, and changemakers
Enjoy light refreshments in a diplomatic setting
🗓️ Date: Tuesday, 26 August 2025
🕔 Time: 5:00 PM – 6:30 PM
📍 Venue: British High Commission, Wellington
🎟️ RSVP Required – Limited Spaces
Networking Reception: From 6:30 pm with canapes and drinks kindly sponsored by the British High Commission.
FOR ANY DIETARY:
Please email us at ishant.ghulyani@unanz.org.nz
Don't miss this opportunity to be part of a global conversation, right here in Wellington.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) Conference 2026, Kia ora!
Electricity and electrification are seen as the significant enablers for decarbonisation of our nation. The Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) | Te Whatunga Hiko programme aspires to meet the challenges the electrical power system will face as we journey towards sustainable decarbonisation.
Our vision is to provide an infrastructure paradigm through a hybrid AC/DC transmission and distribution system that meets the needs of tomorrow’s efficient, low-carbon, reliable and resilient electrical power system.
Funded as part of the New Zealand Government’s Strategic Science Investment Fund (SSIF) on Advanced Energy Technology Platform (AETP), the research team is investigating what the future electrical power system might look like.
Hear about the team’s latest achievements as we approach the final phase of the programme.
Attendance is in person at Victoria University Wellington.
Ngā mihi nui,
Prof. Neville Watson,
Science Leader
The detailed programme will be circulated closer to the event.
 More information on the research can be found at https://www.fan.ac.nz/
If you have any questions, please contact futurearchitecturenetwork@canterbury.ac.nz

Nicole will be at the Presbyterian Church both days with the immersive 360° video tours of Wellington's Blue Belt and Taputeranga Marine Reserve. Come along, experience Wellington's underwater world, and be inspired to dive into our local marine reserve!

description:
EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025, EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025
This year’s EBANZ (Earth Building Association of New Zealand) national conference will see industry leaders, innovators and enthusiasts come together to profile the latest ideas, technologies and projects shaping the future of low carbon, high performing, sustainable building in Aotearoa.

Set at Te Wānanga o Raukawa and the Forest Lakes Conference Centre on the Kāpiti Coast, the earth building conference will see builders, designers, researchers and earth-building enthusiasts explore how traditional and contemporary earth construction methods are shaping resilient, sustainable futures in Aotearoa and beyond.

Themed ‘Earth, Culture and Community’, the three-day conference in mid-November will include presentations, hands-on workshops, site visits and kōrero with leading voices in natural building, indigenous knowledge, climate-responsive design and regenerative practice, while also profiling New Zealand’s own set of earth building standards (NZS 4297, 4298 and 4299) 2024.

A ‘Professionals Day’ on Friday 14 November at Te Wānanga o Raukawa is aimed specifically at architects, engineers, inspectors, builders and designers interested in earth and natural building techniques. It will dive into the Tennent Brown Architects-designed Pā Reo campus at Te Wānanga (a Living Building Challenge project) and presenters will include Rau Hoskins of designTRIBE, Verena Maeder of Solid Earth and Sigi Koko, founder of Build Naturally USA.

Friday will be followed by the in-depth weekend conference at Forest Lakes, featuring talks and presentations aimed to inform and empower people on different aspects of earth and natural building as well as hands-on workshops in different methods and materials, including clay-based plasters, cob, rammed earth and adobe, straw bale and hempcrete. House tours will feature different building techniques, including straw bale and rammed earth, adobe, natural plasters and more.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify Wellington: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Wellington will show you how.  
Most Wellington homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Wellington has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Wellington.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Wellington is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Emma La Rocca - Zero waste swimwear, Emma La Rocca is the founder of Emroce swimwear, the world’s first zero-waste swimwear brand.
Her cutting patterns are designed to fit together perfectly- like a puzzle. This innovative technique fuels creativity, reduces costs, and saves up to a quarter of fabric from ending up in landfill.
Now, Emma is on a mission to help other fashion brands embrace Zero Waste Fashion Design (ZWFD). Through fully funded consulting, she’s breaking down misconceptions and showing how sustainability and style can go hand in hand.
Join Emma as she introduces the world of ZWFD, shares her results, and invites you to try out some simple techniques yourself.
Register for this free event, enjoy a complimentary breakfast from our sponsors, and take part in this inspiring conversation about sustainable fashion.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
NZIFF: What Marielle Knows, Panic around a new digital Big Brother era underpins a clever, absurdist send-up of bourgeois hypocrisy, as a married couple are put on the spot by their daughter’s all-pervasive telepathy.

Germany has a thorny history with mass intelligence gathering, and a continued vigilance around data privacy – and anxiety. Director Frédéric Hambalek taps into it with satirical, ribald flair and a twist of the fantastical in a sharp domestic parable for a new era of global surveillance paranoia.

Julia (Julia Jentsch) is precariously close to a full-blown affair with the workmate she flirts with on smoking breaks. Her husband Tobias (Felix Kramer) dreams of getting even with a publishing house colleague who undercuts his authority in editorial design meetings. When their teenager Marielle (Laeni Geiseler) is slapped by a school friend over an insult, the impact leaves her with the sudden telepathic ability to see everything her parents do throughout the day – a development that spells disaster for the household, as dishonesty can no longer sustain the veneer of stable marital contentment.

As the family descends into a desperate, riotous war of manipulation, they must experiment with new moral codes. Is radical honesty and defiance the best course of action, or should they stifle egos and instincts in line with their preferred image? Better yet, can Marielle’s new powers be curbed? — Carmen Gray
label: Film & Media

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.

Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration Navigating Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Perspective, f🌍 Global Climate Leadership: UK–NZ–UN Collaboration
Hosted by UNANZ Wellington in partnership with the British High Commission, Wellington
Join us for an engaging evening of insight and diplomacy as we explore how the United Kingdom, New Zealand, and the United Nations are working together to drive global climate leadership.
This timely event brings together perspectives on international cooperation, policy innovation, and the urgent challenges of our climate future. John Pearson, Deputy British High Commissioner at the British High Commission, will deliver a keynote speech followed by an open Q&A, offering a unique chance for attendees to ask questions and be part of the conversation.
Whether you're passionate about sustainability, international relations, or meaningful dialogue, this event offers value, inspiration, and connection.

Learn about climate diplomacy in action

Network with professionals, students, and changemakers
Enjoy light refreshments in a diplomatic setting

📍 Venue: British High Commission, Wellington

Don't miss this opportunity to be part of a global conversation, right here in Wellington.

description:
October Just Sew, Join us for our Just Sew - October edition!

Got a tear, a missing button, or a hem that’s come undone? Don’t toss it - fix it! Our monthly Just Sew sessions are all about giving your clothing and textile items a second life. This is a great way to take climate action in your own life – and learn new skills along the way.

Book online and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight household items (cushion covers etc) for repair. We will have sewing machines, needles, thread, and a selection of patches and buttons ready for you. If you have something special you would like to use, feel free to bring it along.

Our skilled volunteers will be here to help with repairs such as holes, tears, hems and missing buttons. Whether you are completely new to sewing or just need a bit of guidance, we will support you through it.

These sessions are held at Te Aro Zero Waste on the first Saturday of every month, from 1-4 pm.

Bookings are prioritised, but we will do our best to fit in walk-ins if there’s space.

description:
Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate
Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!

Why join us? You will:

LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.

Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.

Permaculture for People & Place, Permaculture for People & Place
🌱 Permaculture for People & Place - New Workshop at Mangaroa Farms. Led by our resident permaculture enthusiast Halina Horn, experience a hands-on learning journey for the whole whānau. Come get your hands in the soil, explore the garden, and grow over a 4 week course alongside your tamariki 🌻

description:
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset, Breathwork: A Gentle Reset
Breathwork: A Gentle Reset

Take a pause from the noise of daily life.

This breathwork journey begins with gentle movement to awaken the body and open the breath. Through slow, mindful stretches, we begin softening tension and grounding into the present.

You’ll then be guided through two styles of breathwork — each offering a unique pathway inward. There’s no pressure or expectation, just the freedom to explore what feels right for you:

A dynamic, connected breath for those who wish to build energy, move emotion, or break through internal blockages

A slow, rhythmic breath for those seeking stillness, calm, and deeper grounding

Both approaches invite a sense of spaciousness — physically, mentally, and emotionally — while supporting nervous system balance and inner clarity.

To gently close the session, we’ll move into a quiet, nurturing meditation to support integration and leave you feeling steady, clear, and connected.

Afterwards, stay and enjoy a nourishing plant-based dinner and dessert, lovingly prepared to complement the experience — because healing is also about how we feed and care for ourselves.

Why Breathwork?

Breathwork has helped so many shift from a state of tension and overwhelm into a place of ease, clarity, and resilience — often after just one session. It’s a simple, powerful practice that reconnects you to your body, your breath, and your inner stillness.

You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more present, and more like yourself again.

Meet Karla, your host
Karla is a breathwork and trauma-somatic facilitator based in Aotearoa (New Zealand), originally from Malta. With over a decade of experience in Reiki and three years facilitating trauma-informed, science-based breathwork, Karla combines holistic tools, meditation, and conscious breathing to support nervous system regulation and deep emotional healing. Her offerings help release stored trauma, reduce stress and anxiety, and activate oxytocin—the “love hormone”—fostering connection, vitality, and a sense of wholeness. She currently holds regular classes, workshops, and transformative retreats that nurture the mind, body, and spirit.

description:
Reimagining Construction: Participatory, Circular, and Open by Design, This presentation examines how the principles of participatory, circular, and open design can transform construction by bringing human and ecological values into the heart of how we build.
Drawing from both ancient timber framing traditions and modern innovations, it demonstrates how modularity and standardisation unlock flexibility, efficiency, and customisation while supporting sustainable, locally-rooted solutions.
A key focus is placed on design for disassembly and reassembly, enabling buildings and their components to be reused and adapted over time—reducing waste, lowering environmental impact, and fostering resilience for current and future communities.

description:
Ruamahanga Farm learning day, At this Toru Trail, we look forward to a day of planting, learning and creativity at Ruamāhanga Farm. Just outside Martinborough, Ruamahanga Farm Foundation are bringing the local community together to help restore wetlands and provide greater access to the awa. The restoration is a foundation for Te Reo o te Wai, an arts and conservation programme for local primary schools.


Our hosts Jane Riddiford and Rod Sugden will share the story of the land and the conversion of a traditional stock and crop farm into a regenerative, community oriented venture. They will involve us in some of the experiential ways they are helping children and young people connect to hidden places along the Ruamāhanga. The day will include planting trees and grasses along a new wetland walk combined with nature based story telling, art and creative writing. We will have a shared lunch by the awa or under canvas if it is wet.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Launching in-store: Capital Trees by Susette Goldsmith, Join us in celebrating the recent launch of Capital Trees: The Arboreal Legacy of Te Upoko-O-te-Ika the Wellington Region by Susette Goldsmith, author/editor of Tree Sense: Ways of Thinking About Trees.
"The significance and meaning of trees engagingly explored through the way they have shaped our capital.
From the fossil forest of Tītahi Bay and the ageing oak on Plimmer Steps, to the karaka grove on Wellington’s waterfront and a threatened stand of lowland beech in the Hutt Valley, Capital Trees journeys across the region to trace the living legacies of the city’s rich tree heritage and the many people who have shaped, protected and challenged it.
These legacies include arguments around heritage tree listing, the native versus exotics debate, biodiversity, attitudes towards heritage authenticity, trees as monuments and more, explored through facts, anecdotes and field notes.
Illustrated with contemporary photography and specimen illustrations of the species and individual trees covered, this book is a must for all who live in the Wellington region."
All welcome! See you at the signing table.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
SEED AND SEEDLING SWAP: Join us for the launch of Seeds to Feeds Island Bay!, We're starting a new group dedicated to building a kai secure Island Bay, and we'd love for you to be a part of it!
When: Saturday, 18th October, 10 am - 2 pm
Where: Seed to Sea, 38 The Parade, Island Bay
What to expect:
Seed and Seedling Share: Bring your extra seeds and seedlings to swap, or just come and pick up some new ones - we have plenty!
Learn & Create: Discover how to create new plants from your seeds and make your own seed packets.
Delicious Treats: Enjoy coffee, fresh herbal tea, and tasty treats.
Garden Open Day: Explore the beautiful garden at Seed to Sea and meet the chooks!
Share Your Ideas: We want to hear your thoughts on how we can create a kai secure Island Bay.
Seed and seedling swaps are an awesome opportunity for gardeners of all skill levels to collaborate and share what they might have an abundance of.
It's a great way to save money on buying new seedlings, an opportunity to learn from others, and can lead to new varietals in your māra.
Bring something to share if you can, but if not, come as you are – we'll have plenty for everyone!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Scaling Sustainably with Brianne West, founder of Ethique and Incrediballs, Part of the Pegasus Startup World Cup and Sustainable Spring Series
 Globally recognised environmentalist and entrepreneur, Brianne West, redefined industry norms with her bold vision and innovation, transforming a kitchen experiment in Christchurch into a global beauty revolution.
Ethique was the world’s first zero-waste beauty brand and named in Time Magazine’s Best inventions of 2020. It expanded rapidly, saving millions of plastic bottles from landfill in over 20 countries.
Brianne has won many awards including being an Obama Foundation Leader (AsiaPac), Exporter of the Year (American Chamber of Commerce), and NZ EY Young Entrepreneur of the Year, and was a finalist in the 2024 Kiwibank New Zealand Innovator of the year award.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her incredible journey on scaling, and later exiting a purpose driven, sustainable business. Learn about her current venture, Incrediballs which is set to disrupt the beverage industry, and gain practical insights on how to enter new markets while remaining true to your values.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her remarkable journey of scaling - and ultimately exiting, a purpose-driven, sustainable business. She’ll introduce her latest venture, Incrediballs, poised to disrupt the beverage industry, while offering practical insights on breaking into new markets without compromising your values.
Brianne West is a judge for the Pegasus Startup World Cup held on 9 October 2025 at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti. Learn more and book a ticket to the Pegasus Startup World Cup here.
Snacks provided, if you would like to order a coffee, please arrive earlier to avoid noise.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:

Whether you’re fundraising, raising awareness, or advocating for change, this workshop will give you the tools to design content that supports your kaupapa and makes an impact.
You’ll learn the basics of Canva, how to bring your posts to life on social media, and ways to work with the algorithm, plus plenty of useful tips and tricks to make your content more effective.
All proceeds from this workshop will go directly towards supporting families in Palestine.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Manage Your Expectations, Created and Performed by Eliza Sanders
Produced by House of Sand
Directed by Charley Allanah

You decide the ending…

Solo performer Eliza Sanders has a simple task: to tell you everything that will happen in the show, so you can decide if you would like to see it. Nothing is ever so simple.

This genre-defying work of dance, theatre, live film, clown and absurd philosophising takes the idea of the ‘trigger warning’ to its absurdist extreme to question how ‘informed’ consent can really be, and asking ‘How much do you really want to know?’

Created and performed by multi-award-winning maverick of the stage Eliza Sanders, Manage Your Expectations helps us to see the limits of the power to communicate and our failures to say what we mean. Through movement, multimedia, and razor-sharp wit, it examines the impossibility of perfect communication, musing on the influence of context, identity and personal history while creating something beautiful from our collective mess.

“Clever, witty, evocative, subversive, immersive, despairing, poignant, personal and universal” — Deirdre Tarrant, Theatreview

“Beautifully vulnerable” – Chloe Jaques, Theatreview, 2024

Full of vigour, energy, chaos and a hint of confrontation, Manage Your Expectations is a mind (and body) bending show about how we connect in an increasingly complex world. And you decide the ending…

Content warning: this show contains explicit content, mild coarse language, heavy nudity, themes of abortion and rape.

WINNER: Best Performer, Whangārei Fringe 2024
WINNER: Outstanding Solo Performance, NZ Fringe 2024
WINNER: San Diego Tour Ready, NZ Fringe 2024
NOMINATION: Best in Fringe, NZ Fringe 2024

description: September Walk and Weed, Come and help support the local awa, and water quality for the harbour. Te Aro Zero Waste Just Sew Repair Cafe, Repairing rather than buying is a great way to take climate action in your own life - and learn new skills along the way!
Book through our website and bring along 1-2 clothing or lightweight items for repair to our September Just Sew!
Our skilled volunteers will be here to assist you with repairs such as missing buttons, tears, holes and hemming. We will supply a selection of patches and buttons, but you are also welcome to bring your own if you have something specific in mind.
