description:
Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day, Rā Tūwhera ki Ōtari | Ōtari Open Day
Once a year, we throw open the gates and invite you behind the scenes at Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush. It’s your chance to explore the only public botanic garden in Aotearoa dedicated solely to native plants. Discover the people, plants, and projects that make it special.

Meet our team, chat with partner organisations, join an activity, and find out how we’re working together to protect and restore our natural environment. Whether you’ve never been to Ōtari before or it’s been a while, come along, get curious, and reconnect with nature!

On the day:

10 am-2 pm: Tū Mātau Ora – Taonga Tākaro (Traditional Māori games) on the lawn

10 am-2 pm: Conservation community partner stalls

10 am-2 pm: Plant sale – native plants grown right here in the Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush Trust Nursery

10:30 am, 11:30 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Behind-the-scenes tours with Ōtari staff (sign up on the day)

10 am -12:30 pm: Rongoā pani (balm) making workshop – learn about traditional Māori plant uses and make a balm to take home. Tickets $10 which goes directly to the Ōtari-Wilton's Bush Trust. Available soon!

10:30 am, 11:45 am, 12:30 pm, 1:30 pm: Author talks – Ruth Paul, Phil Sirvid, Leon Perrie, and Michael Szabo discuss their recent books

11 am: Lions Ōtari Plant Conservation Laboratory staff show and tell – see our orchid conservation work up close

11 am & 1 pm: String Bean Puppets – two shows: Once in a Full Moon (Kiwi adventures) and Tree Friends (W**d-busting fun)

1 pm-2 pm: Learn to weave putiputi (flowers) out of Harakeke (flax) with the Ōtari Raranga Weavers. This is a drop in session, but it's best to drop by before 1:30 to give you enough time to create your putiputi.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Scaling Sustainably with Brianne West, founder of Ethique and Incrediballs, Part of the Pegasus Startup World Cup and Sustainable Spring Series
 Globally recognised environmentalist and entrepreneur, Brianne West, redefined industry norms with her bold vision and innovation, transforming a kitchen experiment in Christchurch into a global beauty revolution.
Ethique was the world’s first zero-waste beauty brand and named in Time Magazine’s Best inventions of 2020. It expanded rapidly, saving millions of plastic bottles from landfill in over 20 countries.
Brianne has won many awards including being an Obama Foundation Leader (AsiaPac), Exporter of the Year (American Chamber of Commerce), and NZ EY Young Entrepreneur of the Year, and was a finalist in the 2024 Kiwibank New Zealand Innovator of the year award.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her incredible journey on scaling, and later exiting a purpose driven, sustainable business. Learn about her current venture, Incrediballs which is set to disrupt the beverage industry, and gain practical insights on how to enter new markets while remaining true to your values.
In this workshop, Brianne will share her remarkable journey of scaling - and ultimately exiting, a purpose-driven, sustainable business. She’ll introduce her latest venture, Incrediballs, poised to disrupt the beverage industry, while offering practical insights on breaking into new markets without compromising your values.
Brianne West is a judge for the Pegasus Startup World Cup held on 9 October 2025 at Te Raukura ki Kāpiti. Learn more and book a ticket to the Pegasus Startup World Cup here.
Snacks provided, if you would like to order a coffee, please arrive earlier to avoid noise.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025, A bioblitz is all about searching for and recording all the species you can over a set time period.
Zealandia is one of the most biodiversity rich places in the motu(show English translation) and the perfect place to come searching for species over the long weekend. You may well find species that we have seldom seen, so this is fun for you and potentially invaluable information for our conservation team. It’s a great reason to go exploring some of the tracks you might not know well, or at all!
All you have to do is upload your observations of species to iNaturalist. It doesn’t have to be done during those four days. In fact, you’ll have a further 14 days to upload and identify all your observations made during the official period.
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025 is run by a network of keen citizen scientists from across the globe.
label: Conservation & Environment

County Lane Fair, County Lane Fair

description:
Social Drama for Seniors, Join us every Thursday for a session of games, storytelling and laughter at the Newtown Community Centre. This is a place for those aged 65+ to connect and learn with professional theatre practitioners sharing their skills and knowledge.

description:
Tip Shop Truck at Te Aro Zero Waste, No vehicle no worries
The Tip Shop Truck will be at Te Aro Zero Waste (formerly EcoCentre) at 2, Forresters Lane on the Last Saturday of every month for the next three months.
The Tip Shop team will be collecting any big, bulky, awkward and other forgotten reusable items.
We will be taking furniture, building and gardening materials, books, and bric-a-brac. If you turn up in your car with a big load, please be prepared that we will end up sending you to the Tip Shop directly.
You can bring your e-waste, tools, metal, bicycles and hard to recycle items at the same time to Te Aro Zero Waste.
Te Aro Zero Waste has heaps of solutions to help you reduce your waste, open 10am - 4pm Wednesday - Saturday.
Can’t make it during these hours? Feel free to drop off your items to Te Aro Zero Waste the week before 10am - 4pm Wednesday - Friday
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Te Āhua o te Haenga | Pollination in Motion, Step into the colourful, buzzing world of pollination! Join the Wellington Gardens Education Team for a day of hands-on fun exploring how plants and pollinators work together to keep nature thriving.

Meet the Beekeepers – Learn how bees keep the hive running, why they’re super pollinators, and try on real beekeeper gear
Sensory Pollination Play Station – Transfer “pollen” between flowers in a fun sensory tray
Outdoor Pollinator Bingo Trail – Explore the gardens to spot different pollinators
Wind Pollination Station – Make mini fans and paper “pollen” to see how the wind carries pollen from one plant to another

Bring the whānau, follow the buzz, and leave with a new appreciation for the small creatures (and breezes!) that make big things happen.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
PADI Advanced Open Water Course, PADI Advanced Open Water Course
“Your Next Step in Underwater Adventure”
Exploration excitement and experiences are what the PADI Advanced Open Water
course is all about. And no you don't have to be "advanced" to take it - it's designed
so both new and experienced Open Water Divers can sign up and develop better
diving skills and techniques straight away!

The Advanced Open Water Diver course helps you increase your confidence and
build scuba skills to become safer and more comfortable in the water. It’s also a great
way to get more diving experience under the supervision of a PADI Instructor.
This course builds on what you've learnt and develops new capabilities by
introducing new dive activities and ways to have fun scuba diving. You will complete
5 different types of dives to build your confidence and develop your dive skills. The
dives include the basics of Deep Diving Underwater Navigation - and your choice of
Peak Performance Buoyancy Naturalist Fish Identification Wreck (weather dependant)
Enriched Air * Photography or Night during winter.

Complete the theory online then join us for a weekends diving. After the 5 dives
over the weekend you will qualify as a PADI Advanced Open Water Diver. This is the
minimum requirement for many of our dive adventures and a prerequisite for the
PADI Rescue Diver course.

If you have any questions please call so we can help you.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms, Tree Planting at Mangaroa Farms
Our native riparian plantings from 2023 have really started to thrive this winter, visible as you drive past the farm, or walking the local farm trail loop.

These native seedlings planted alongside the river, act like living sponges, slowing any farm runoff, filtering nutrients, anchoring soil and shading the water so that beneficial invertebrates & life forms can thrive. Creating cleaner water, richer habitat and less flooding downstream.

Keen to get involved? We have a few tree planting events coming up this season:

🌳 TREE PLANTING DAYS
- Sat 16th Aug 10am - 3pm
- Sat 6th Sep 10am - 3pm with @forestandbirdwellington

EVENT DETAILS
- Meet at 10am, 298 Whitemans Valley Road, Upper Hutt.
- We will walk 5-10mins to our planting site near te Awa o Mangaroa / the Mangaroa river.
- Come for a short time, or a long time, and join us for a kai and refreshments at 2pm after the mahi is complete.

BRING WITH YOU
- A Jacket and warm clothes - be prepared for a range of weather
- Boots or stout shoes
- Gloves - if you have them
- A spade if you have one
- Water bottle

Register at https://store.mangaroa.org/collections/events

#treeplanting #mangaroafarms #riparianplanting #nativetrees #volunteer #alwaysbeplanting

description:
The Made-Up Smackdown, A long-standing Festival highlight, the Made-Up Smackdown is a thrilling, unpredictable competition of late-night improvisational glory.

Wild new combinations of performers from around Pōneke, Aotearoa and the World are assembled in secret, then meet for the first time on stage.

Who will be picked as the audience favourite? That's up to you!

As this show is improvised, we cannot guarantee the presence or absence of specific content or themes beyond what is in the description above. The show may contain mature themes and language, but not gratuitously. The show may contain voluntary audience interaction, such as giving a suggestion for a scene.

description:
Trap-NZ Workshop, Trap-NZ Workshop
Join us for a hands-on workshop that empowers you to make a difference in your backyard and beyond!



Whether you're a seasoned trapper or just starting out, this free community event will teach you how to use TRAP NZ, New Zealand’s leading predator control platform.



Reino Grundling will show you how to track pests, record trap data, and support conservation efforts that protect our precious native species like kiwi, tūī, and kererū.

📍 Where: Carterton Courthouse, Holloway Street Carterton
📅 When: Saturday 20 September 2025 10am -12 noon
🎟️ Cost: Free
🧰 Bring: Smartphone or tablet (if you have one), enthusiasm, and questions!

What you'll gain:

Tips for setting and managing traps effectively

Skills to use TRAP NZ for recording and reporting activity

Knowledge about the impact of predator control on local biodiversity

Connections with like-minded conservation champions

🌱 Let’s work together to protect what makes Aotearoa unique. Light refreshments provided. This workshop is made possible with funding from WBS.

Spots are limited — register now by emailing
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
SEED AND SEEDLING SWAP: Join us for the launch of Seeds to Feeds Island Bay!, We're starting a new group dedicated to building a kai secure Island Bay, and we'd love for you to be a part of it!
When: Saturday, 18th October, 10 am - 2 pm
Where: Seed to Sea, 38 The Parade, Island Bay
What to expect:
Seed and Seedling Share: Bring your extra seeds and seedlings to swap, or just come and pick up some new ones - we have plenty!
Learn & Create: Discover how to create new plants from your seeds and make your own seed packets.
Delicious Treats: Enjoy coffee, fresh herbal tea, and tasty treats.
Garden Open Day: Explore the beautiful garden at Seed to Sea and meet the chooks!
Share Your Ideas: We want to hear your thoughts on how we can create a kai secure Island Bay.
Seed and seedling swaps are an awesome opportunity for gardeners of all skill levels to collaborate and share what they might have an abundance of.
It's a great way to save money on buying new seedlings, an opportunity to learn from others, and can lead to new varietals in your māra.
Bring something to share if you can, but if not, come as you are – we'll have plenty for everyone!
label: Conservation & Environment

MMC Evening Connection! #2
Created in response to requests for more after-hours activities, these evenings gathering is all about community, storytelling, and belonging.
Whether you're new to Marlborough or a long-time local, join us for a relaxed Friday evening of conversation and connection in a welcoming space. This is your chance to meet others, share experiences, and celebrate the diverse cultures that make up our region.

Come along for Kōrero, laughter, and meaningful connection.

description:
Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Wairarapa Farmers' Market, The Wairarapa Farmers’ Market is held every Saturday from 9am to 1pm (rain or shine!) at the Solway Showgrounds Masterton. Entry is off State Highway 2 or the by pass, onto Judds Rd. There is plenty of car parking and a camping ground for NZMCA Members

Picnic tables are situated underneath the majestic Redwood Tree for you to sit and enjoy a coffee and something to eat while listening to live music. Plus you get to take home quality, delicious produce grown seasonally within the Wairarapa region. It makes for a great morning's outing.

Enjoy breakfast, brunch or lunch and pick up your dinner items with locally produced coffee, eggs, meat, berries, bread, jam, fruit, olive oil, pastries, pies, pickles, slices, cakes, soup, vegetables and more. Shop for plants, seedlings, seaweed, artisan goods including wood turning, Māori weaving, children’s and baby clothes, aprons, peg aprons, tea towels, knitted and crochet toys and hand dyed knitting wools.
Sign up for our regular Wairarapa Farmers' Market newsletter here https://mailchi.mp/d99e1ad65a18/newsletter-sign-up or join us on Facebook to get updates on all the Market goodness! Dogs are welcome to the market and a dog bowl can be provided. See you on Saturday!

"From Paddock to Plate Since 2006"

description:
Nui Hui 7, Nui Hui 7
NUI HUI 7 – LIVE AT 14 WAIU STREET
Wainuiomata, Lower Hutt
Saturday 22 November 2025 | 4PM – LATE

Nui Hui is back – louder, prouder, and more unfiltered than ever. This grassroots music series is built for the people, by the people, shining a spotlight on bands who grind it out, carve their own paths, and keep live music alive.

Nui Hui 7 is a one-night-only collision of sounds and scenes, bringing together rock, reggae, punk, grunge, and soul against a true blue-collared backdrop. No industry machines, no corporate gloss – just raw, rising talent backed by the passion of locals and volunteers who believe in the power of music.

This year’s lineup is stacked with unsigned and upcoming artists from across the region and beyond:

4PM – Munkiez

With a sound as cheeky and chaotic as their name suggests, MUNKIEZ is a bluesy, funk-rock explosion that proves good times and great grooves go hand-in-hand. Hailing from Upper Hutt, this crew is all about embracing the raw energy of rock and roll while slathering on a thick coat of soulful, slinky funk.
They're not here to reinvent the wheel, but to make it spin faster, dirtier, and with a whole lot more swagger. With a dash of that no-nonsense, straight-outta-the-garage Kiwi attitude. MUNKIEZ are a band you feel in your bones, a sound that gets your head nodding and your feet moving before you even realize what's happening. They play it like they mean it, because they do.

5PM – The Groundsmen

Scott Paddock and Shane Martin formed The Groundsmen back in the heady days of 2017 and went through various drummers and bass players before finally finding stability with drummer Rowan Carlyle in 2018.

Since then they’ve played numerous gigs (one supporting Head Like A Hole in Gisborne at Smash Palace 30th anniversary) and released 3 singles on Spotify and other streaming platforms - Black Car, Supanova and Achtung Baby (check them out!).

They’ve recorded their debut album and are just about to mix it and release it.

Playing only original earthen rock punk, we always, always, perform at 110% energy levels and put on a great show with hooky uptempo toons!! With songs commenting on contemporary society and life at large all 3 members throw themselves fully into their performance and leave no energy unused. You will leave one of their shows changed.

See the excerpt from a review of a in Whanganui July 2020:

“After a quick change of equipment, The Groundsmen were next on the agenda. Proclaiming themselves to be Taranaki’s premier rock punk band, the trio wasted no time in belting out a hard and fast set of original, classic punk-inspired tunes that were lapped up by the growing gathering of punters. Bass player Scott Paddock is a tour-de-force; full of noise, energy and an appropriate rock-punk swagger. Along with guitarist Shane Martin and drummer Rowan Carlyle, The Groundsmen powered their way though and energetic set, and it was immediately evident that they were ecstatic to be back on stage and performing again after the recent enforced hiatus. The trio powered through a set of classic, no-frills, original punk inspired tracks that had almost everyone in the room either on their feet or gyrating in their seats. Definitely a crowd-pleaser, there is no doubt whatsoever that The Groundsmen were in their element, and clearly love what they do.”

….from Ambient Light, author Bridget Herlihy, 4th July 2020

6PM – Kaletta Band

Kaletta is a Latin rock band that brings together the rhythms of ska punk and gypsy sounds in Spanish. With musicians from Chile, Colombia, Argentina, Italy, the UK, and New Zealand, our sound is a blend of different beats and roots. We've had the privilege of being two-time national finalists in the Battle of the Bands (BOTB 2024 and 2025) and have performed at festivals like Island Bay and toured the top South Island. We're excited about our upcoming tours in New Zealand next year.

What we're passionate about is creating music that's true to ourselves. Each song is a journey, moving from calm to energetic moments that we hope will keep you engaged. Our lyrics touch on social and political themes, and we hope our performances will inspire thought and conversation. We're looking forward to sharing our music with you and creating memorable experiences through our dynamic sound and energy.

7PM – Burning Embers

Accustomed to breaching anything that requires sociable etiquette they still manage to pull off their unique brand of Wainuiomata rock.

From out of nowhere, they regroup, drink a few, set a plan, and do the complete opposite in tasteful fashion. Burning Embers have an uncanny habit of pulling off a great set, usually unscripted but full of the essence that is Rock n Roll. We're not here long enough to care, but we do love a great audience
Reminiscent of Days of the New and Alice in Chains they're definitely genuine entertainment

8PM – Stretch to Mould

Stretch to Mould is a rock band from Wellington New Zealand who formed in 2012. The band was founded by vocalist and guitarist Darrell Vickers, who has been the only constant member throughout multiple line up changes. Since 2024 the line up has consisted of Vickers alongside Chris Fursdon (bass guitar) and Thomas Fuller (Drums). Stretch to Mould are known for their high energy, hard hitting riffs, powerful vocals and all-round solid musicianship. The band released their debut album Shadows in 2012, EP Painting Faces in 2014 and are currently working on their next release.

9PM – Ras Judah and the Culture Embassy

a 10-piece NZ band of varying cultural backgrounds, hence the name.
The cultural diversity of the band is reflected in the sound of the music
a fusion of African styles, Reggae/Ska, Jazz and Afro-Latin rhythms.

We describe our sound as Afrocentric-World Music as much of what we play is based on African rhythms and songs, which is where our lead-singer ‘Ras Judah’ and two of our master drummers come from (Botswana, Ghana and Tanzania respectively), plus Roots Reggae. Though everyone contributes their own culturally inspired sound, with other band members from Cuba, England and Japan, and others with Greek, Kiwiana and jazz backgrounds. Not just a musical treat representing many parts of the world, but also a visual one; a carnival of ethnic diversity and collaboration on stage!

10PM – The Fabulous Pakehas

Were first conceived in London England, way back in the early 90s whilst on O.E's. Currently working on a album, & after 33 years, still in no rush.
With two of us having roots in WOA TFP are honoured to be playing a set of our originals for NUI HUI 7
The T.F.P original line up are, Antony Maddock, Scott McGill, Leslie Tearne, &
Bevan Ritchie.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

From soul-stirring grooves to fist-in-the-air anthems, Nui Hui 7 is more than just a gig – it’s a celebration of musicians who hustle, create, and share their art on their own terms.

Nui Hui: supporting local, celebrating original, and keeping the fire of live music burning

description:
Airhorn Calms Down, Hi [said in a whisper], how are you, are you ready for Airhorn?
PLEASE READ. SHOW WARNING!
This is truly going to be a different Airhorn. Last month was intense, and we love intensity, but felt the need to bring it down. The focus for this month is calm. Chill. Relaxation. This is truly going to be the most gentle Airhorn you have seen.
There will be no flashing lights or threat of epilepsy. There will not be loud noises or gross out humour. There will not be airhorns! This is not a bit. We are sincerely concerned that folks are going to come to think this is a goof and expect the usual madcap, abrasive chaos of our comedy show.
There will be no abrasion. There will be no chaos. We are wanting to do the most experimental show we can do, which in our case is a low-key, cozy, warm-hearted hour of quiet reflection and gentle comedy.This is going to be a soft show for everyone who needs a minute to just breathe. You will laugh, but not enough to hurt your side or upset your neighbor. It will be a laugh held in the liminal space between a deep breath and a long sigh.
For folks in which this amount of calm is too stressful, we will also have a Stimulation Booth (provided by Wattie's) available at any time to provide the classic Airhorn jolt they need.

description:
The Mind, Body, & Climate Change-FREE EVENT AT VIC, The Mind, Body, & Climate Change-FREE EVENT AT VIC
The Mind, Body, & Climate Change

Explore how young minds can drive change by understanding the links between climate change, well-being, and action.

Free kai. Big ideas. Good vibes.

Ready to connect the dots between your own well-being and the planet’s future? We’re talking real talk, fresh perspectives, and a whole lot of inspiration — without the boring lecture vibe.

Devamrita Swami — world-travelling monk, renowned strategist, social observer, and all-round thought-provoker — is back at Vic Uni for the third time. He’s spoken at universities all over the globe, and now he’s here to flip the way you see climate action and mental health.

And yes… free plant-based dinner is on us:

🌮 Loaded nachos (salsa, taco ‘meat’, sour ‘cream’ & ‘cheese’)
🥤 Strawberry & peanut butter milkshakes
🍩 Caramel & chocolate doughnut


Come for the food, stay for the conversation. Connect with good humans, share some laughs, and leave with fresh ideas you’ll actually want to act on.

When: Tues 16 Sept, 5:45 pm

Where: Vic Uni, Kelburn Parade — MacLaurin Building MCLT103 (up the steps from the Hub). We’ll have people outside pointing you in the right direction. Lost? Text us: +64 20 4191 5046

Click ‘Get Tickets’ to save your seat (and your doughnut).

description:
Wellington Rowing Club AGM, Lotto 8’s & Season Opening, The Wellington Rowing Club Annual General Meeting (AGM) and opening of the season will be held on Sunday 24 August 2024, 12 noon, at the WRC Function Centre.
We look forward to seeing you all at the Club at 9:30 for Lotto 8’s (weather permitting).
Following the meetings, a light lunch will be provided. This is also WRC’s opportunity to unveil the Function Space renovations to the membership.

Information about the AGM
The WRC AGM will commence at 12noon, in the WRC Function Centre. There will be provisions for online attendance.
At this year’s AGM, we have several board and committee positions that we will be seeking to fill. Many hands make light work, and we all depend on volunteers to keep the club growing and thriving. A variety of experience levels, skill sets, and perspectives are needed for a well-functioning club.
The positions to be filled this year are:
-Club Captain (2-year term, Officer role)
-Vice President (2-year term, Officer role)
-Club Treasurer (2-year term, Officer role)
-Club Secretary (2-year term, Officer role)
-3 Committee roles (1-year term, non-Officer role)
-3 Board members (2-year term, Officer role)
Officers of the must consent in writing to being an officer and certify that they are eligible and not disqualified from holding office as described under section 36B of the Charities Act 2005.
The Club by-laws outline the current role descriptions, can be found here, note that the roles can be tailored to suit individuals’ skill sets and experience. Mentoring and support can be provided to develop individuals in these positions.
If you are interested, but have further questions- please reach out to the people holding the current role or any of the board or committee members to discuss.

description:
Cooking Classes, Authentic Indian cooking classes in Wellington with panaromic views over Wellington Harbour.

In each class, you will learn 4-5 recipes like: potato stuff roti, roasted eggplant curry, wholemeal, roti, naan; shahi paneer; dhal, samosa; palak paneer; gourmet chickpeas; vegetable korma; gulab jamun; kheer; mango lassi; masala chai, and many more...

The classes start at 6 pm or 10:30 am on weekends and weekdays with a 2-hour session followed by a dinner or lunch afterwards. The ingredients, copies of recipes, organic karma drink will be provided with a full course meal in a banquet setting. Custom made classes available for gluten free, dairy free and any other food intolerance and dietary requirements.The ingredients, recipes, complimentary organic karma drinks will be provided with a full course meal.

There are 2 to 8 people in each class in purpose built cooking studio. Also a private cooking classes available.

The menu for the class can be:

1) Spicy potato stuffed paratha and roti, rajasthani tomato relish, aalu matter or spicy peas- potato curry, roasted cumin yogurt raita and fresh mint- coriander chutney.

2) Shahi Paneer (cottage cheese cubes with spices and rich tomato-cashew gravy), garlic coriander naan, cumin jeera basmati rice and sweet fragrant rice pudding with cardamom. Also I will teach how to make fresh paneer.

3) Roasted eggplant curry, plain whole wheat chapatti or roti, jeera aaloo or potato curry, Tuar dahl (split yellow lentil) and Basmati rice with homemade pickle.

4) Palak paneer (creamy spinach curry with cubes of paneer), jeera rice (basmati rice with fragrant spices, panjabi chhole or spicy chickpeas curry and mango lassi. Also fresh paneer making.

5) Khadi (chickpeas fritters in yogurt and chickpeas flour soupy gravy), Aloo-Gobhi (cauliflower and potato curry),  savoury wraps with herbs and spices, fresh pickle and basmati rice.

The total cost is $130 per person, this includes ingredient cost. (As an alternative we also sell cooking class gift vouchers.The food options are unlimited and the class provides fresh and best ingredients)
Please contact for booking: indiancooking@xtra.co.nz

So just bring your taste buds! and Enjoy!!

description:
Wellington Climate Fresk Workshop, Do you want to be part of the solution to tackle climate change but don’t have the time to become a climate scientist? Join us for a 3-hour interactive workshop to explore the causes and consequences of climate disturbances.
Based on the IPCC report and played by over 2 million people worldwide, this collaborative workshop allows you to understand the key issues of climate change to empower you to take action.
How it works:
The workshop is based on a 42-card game. Each card represents an element, a cause or a consequence of climate change.
In teams, guided by your facilitator, you are encouraged to find the cause-effect relationship between the different components of climate change. Collective intelligence will get you from one deck of card to the next!
This step-by-step reconstruction provides keys to understand the complexity and develop an overview of climate change.
Agenda:
Introduction, 15 mins
Fresk Card Game, 1 1/2 hours
Debrief and Actions, 1 hour 15 mins
Climate Fresk is an excellent opportunity to understand the key elements of climate change and what you can do to be part of the solution. No previous climate knowledge is needed.

Tea, coffee and snacks will be served during the short break. Workshop run by Climate Training Co. Ltd. Donations welcome!
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
The Workplace Rituals Deck Facilitator Masterclass, Build culture by design, not by default - one ritual at a time.
Facilitate meaningful culture change and create connection through the power of workplace rituals.
This masterclass is for people who want to build stronger, more connected workplace cultures — and are ready to turn values and intentions into real, daily action.
Whether you're a leader, culture champion, facilitator, or change consultant, this training will give you the tools and confidence to run your own Workplace Rituals Workshops using the WRD (Workplace Rituals Deck).
Led by the co-creators of the deck, Lotty Roberts and Lorissa Garcia, this is a hands-on learning experience rooted in emotional culture, intentional design, and purposeful leadership.
In this Masterclass, you'll learn:
What rituals are and why they are important
Why rituals matter in workplaces
The difference between habits and rituals
Indepth knowledge of each of the 4 parts of the deck and why they are important
How to use our PARR model to craft rituals that stick
How to run the Rituals Audit
How to guide groups through ideation, crafting and action
Lotty & Lorissa's tips and tricks for using the deck first hand, along with the story and background behind the deck.
You'll walk away as a Certified Workplace Rituals Deck Practitioner, with confidence to run rituals sessions with your own teams or clients.
What's Included:
3.5 hour in person masterclass
Co-led by the WRD creators: Lotty Roberts & Lorissa Garcia
Certification as a WRD Practitioner
Digital Toolkit
Option to purchase with or without a deck.
Who it’s for:
Leaders & Team Managers
Culture Champions
Small business owners wanting to create an intentional culture as they scale
HR, OD, and Change Practitioners
Leadership Development Consultants
Facilitators & Coaches
Anyone who wants to turn values into action and create emotionally intelligent, connected teams and workplaces
Why Join? Because culture doesn't live in a document. It lives in the small, intentional things we do every day. This masterclass gives you the tools and confidence to help others design those moments — and build workplaces where people feel connected, seen and supported.
Culture happens with or without you - rituals help make it intentional.
Presented by the WRD Co-creators:
Lorissa (founder of Assembly Culture) and Lotty Roberts (founder of MiND.U) met through their shared work in emotional culture, leadership, and change - and quickly became friends as well as collaborators.
After years of working with teams and leaders, they kept noticing the same thing: workshops sparked insight, but translating that energy into everyday action was where things fell short.
So they created The Workplace Rituals Deck - a practical, human way to close the gap between knowing and doing. It’s full of simple, powerful rituals to help teams shape a culture that’s not just talked about, but genuinely felt.
Ticket Options:
Masterclass Only – $299 NZD
Masterclass + WRD Deck – $529 NZD (Deck provided on the day at in-person events.)
Will refreshments be provided during the workshop?
Coffee, tea, water and some light snacks will be available during the morning tea break.
Date and time
29th October 2025
9:00 AM – 12:30 PM NZST
Location
Willeston Conference Centre
Level 11  
15 Willeston Street
Call Active House
Wellington 6011
New Zealand 
View Map
What's the refund and cancellation policy?
Unfortunately we do not offer refunds for this workshop.
However, you may send someone else in your place to this workshop if you cannot attend for any reason.
You must notify the host that you will not attend the workshop and the name of the person that will attend in your spot.
If you cannot attend the workshop and have purchased a deck we will send that to you along with the digital toolkit.
If the Workshop Host cancels this workshop, you will be transferred to the next available workshop. You can contact the Workshop host for a refund if you cannot attend the revised workshop date.

description:
Electrify Wellington: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Wellington will show you how.  
Most Wellington homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Wellington has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Wellington.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Wellington is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Public Lecture – Amnesty International Secretary General Dr Agnès Callamard, Public Lecture – Amnesty International Secretary General Dr Agnès Callamard
Global human rights leader Dr Agnès Callamard speaks on humanity, justice, and hope in action. Don’t miss this rare event.

Dr Agnès Callamard is recognised globally as a leading authority on governance, accountability, and international affairs. She has been Secretary General of Amnesty International since 2021, previously served as the UN Special Rapporteur on extrajudicial executions, and was Director of Columbia University’s Global Freedom of Expression project. Her career spans decades of leadership in defending human rights worldwide.
In this public lecture, Dr Callamard will reflect on today’s global challenges and opportunities, exploring how collective action can drive change.

Jonathon Boston ONZM, Emeritus Professor of Public Policy at the Wellington School of Business and Government, and Former Director of the Institute of Policy Studies and the Institute for Governance & Policy Studies will host the session.
This event offers a unique opportunity to engage with global human rights discourse in Aotearoa New Zealand at a time when representation, civic freedoms, and the international rules-based order are being widely debated. It also aims to inspire the next generation of change-makers to connect with both local and global struggles for justice.
Event Details
Date & Time: Tuesday 23rd October, 5:00pm doors with lecture starting at 5:30pm
Venue: Rutherford Theatre, Victoria University of Wellington
Who Should Attend? Students, faculty, civil society leaders, activists, and members of the public interested in human rights, justice, and accountability
Accessibility: The venue is wheelchair accessible
Seats Available: 150 seats open to the public (first come, first served)

description:
Kaukau Skyline Traverse, Olympic Harriers and Athletics Wellington proudly present the Second Edition of the Kaukau Skyline Traverse, incorporating the 2025 Wellington Mountain Running Championships.
The races will take place on the western hills of Johnsonville along the Skyline Track over Mt Kaukau.
Races start and finish at the northern end of the Skyline Track heading south along the ridgeline to Mt Kaukau and beyond. All races are ‘out and back’ each with a turn-around point. The long course includes an additional challenging loop (clockwise) before turning around.
Race distances and approximate ascents are:
· Race 1: 11:00am Long course 12.15km (600m)
· Race 2: 11:10am Medium course 8.75km (400m)
· Race 3: 11:20am Short course 5.75km (220m)
· Race 4: 11:30am Sprint course 1.75km (70m)
Championship runners must be registered with an Athletics Wellington club, wear their club uniform and run in the correct race according to their age grade. Non-championship runners can run in any race. You must be 18 years or older to run in races 1 or 2.
On a good day running the Skyline with views across Wellington and the South Island are amazing! And on a bad day…exhilarating !!!!
Enter Here = https://eventplus.net/2wm25
More Info= https://www.olympicharriers.nz/listcalendar/?eid=3957

description:
Family event: Explore Omnibirding with Giselle Clarkson, We are thrilled and delighted to announce we are going to be hosting a fabulous school holiday event with the multi-award winning Giselle Clarkson to celebrate the release of her latest book Omnibird: An Avian Investigator’s Handbook, a guide to the art and science of omnibirding.
Giselle Clarkson, the author of The Observologist, will be in Tawa for this very special event to explore the inner workings of the book and delights and wonders of the avian world.
Some birds are so commonplace it’s easy to forget how extraordinary they are. These creatures have a secret eyelid, hollow bones and a two-part brain. They dress in feathers. Omnibird, explores what’s remarkable about the birds all around us and the clues we can all use to become avian investigators.
Giselle is an author, illustrator and cartoonist based in Greytown, known for her work on conservation and environmental topics. She has illustrated award-winning picture books and nonfiction and is a 2023 Arts Foundation Laureate, receiving the prestigious Mallinson Rendel Illustrators Award.
This promises to be an unmissable event for bird and nature lovers of any age.
Books for sale thanks to the Children's Bookshop.
We wish to extend our thanks to Gecko Press for helping make this event happen.
This is a free event.
We expect this event to be very popular so to secure your seat early arrival is suggested.

description:
FRUIT LOOP FESTIVAL, Fruit Loop Festival
Marlborough’s freshest music festival!
About the Festival
Fruit Loop Festival is Marlborough’s juiciest new summer gig! A full-blown celebration of music and dance, kicking off under the sun and well into the night. Think open-air energy - blending Marlborough's summer magic with a full-scale music festival. An insane line-up of DJs and live performers with production to match! From the first drop to the final track, it's where the beat hits harder and the drinks taste sweeter.
Fresh, wild, fierce - Fruit Loop is the party Marlborough has been waiting for.
The Line-Up
DICK JOHNSON: The heart of NZ’s electronic scene, Dick Johnson is a true house music heavyweight. With remixes for global icons like Fatboy Slim and Claude VonStroke, plus Kiwi favourites L.A.B and Tiki Taane, he’s spent over two decades electrifying dancefloors worldwide. A relentless force behind the decks - and music director for Synthony - Dick brings the fire every time.
SIN: Co-host of George FM Drive, Sin is plugged into the pulse of the dance scene and has quickly become a revered authority on all things electronica. She’s torn up stages at Rhythm & Vines, Homegrown, Hidden Valley, and international festivals from Fiji to the UK. With supports for legends like Fatboy Slim, Groove Armada, and Netsky, Sin brings high-energy house, techno, and ravey curveballs to every set.
KITA MEAN: Kita Mean is New Zealand’s award-winning drag superstar, known for her infectious charm, razor-sharp wit, and high-camp aesthetic. With a career spanning 15+ years across stages and screens worldwide, she’s wowed audiences from Aotearoa and Australia to London, Canada, the USA, and beyond. Winner of the very first RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under and co-owner of the iconic Caluzzi Cabaret, Kita continues to dazzle with colourful looks, flawless mug, and hilarious timing. Quirky, kooky, kitsch, and quick - Kita Mean isn’t just a queen, she’s an experience.
PETE GREEN: Originally from the UK, Pete is part of the vinyl-digging collective Rare Specimens. His love for deep, worldly electronic sounds brings low-end warmth and an infectious energy to the dancefloor. Along the way, he’s supported artists such as Crazy P, Psychemagik, Audio Jack, and Christopher Tubbs, playing festivals and parties from Creamfields and Rhythm & Alps to Tempo Schmempo. Expect a set seasoned with Italo, ambient, and deep house flavours, dusted with disco, and finished with a splash of techno.
Event Details
Date: Saturday 28 March 2026
Time: 2pm - 10pm
Location: The Fancy Cow, Marlborough
R18 event - Photo identification will be required.
Return Bus Service:
Getting to and from the festival is easy with our return bus service. Pick-up points will include Redwoodtown Woolworths, Seymour Square, and Countdown Springlands. Purchase a return bus ticket when you nab your ticket.
A full timetable and bus information will be announced closer to the event.
Parking is strictly limited at the festival. Drop off recommended.
Tickets
Tickets are limited — don’t wait. Secure yours now!
Door sales may be available.
Have your ticket open and ready to be scanned at the gate.
Kaupapa
Fruit Loop is a safe, inclusive space where everyone belongs. If you can’t celebrate diversity, respect others, and bring good vibes, this festival isn’t for you.
Harassment or discrimination of any kind will not be tolerated. Anyone behaving this way will be removed.
Refunds and Cancellations
Fruit Loop Festival is a rain or shine event. The festival will proceed regardless of weather conditions, except in circumstances where safety is compromised or conditions make it impossible for the event to continue.
No refunds will be given for changes to the programme, line-up, or advertised performers.
Stay Connected
Follow us for line-up drops, updates and key event information: @fruitloopfestival on Instagram
label: Festivals

The Course covers all the foundations you need for an ongoing yoga practice as well as plenty of time for guided relaxation. Loosening your body the joints and your mind the exercises are designed for the complete balance and awakening of energy in body mind and soul. Experience yoga postures breath techniques meditation and relaxation along with knowledge about basic yoga philosophy and a healthy lifestyle. A wonderful course for new beginners and those looking to deepen their practical experience of yoga. 

Some of the many benefits of yoga include: improvement in posture and breathing increased strength and flexibility a greater ability to cope with stress and a feeling of peace and calm. 
This course called "part 1" will cover the second half of Level 1 from the System of Yoga in Daily Life.

description:
Topless Picking Flowers Release Tour // WELLINGTON, Sophie Songbird makes her solo debut this spring, stepping into the spotlight with a voice and vision all her own. Known for her work with the beloved band Dr. Reknaw, Sophie now unveils a fresh chapter — touring in celebration of her first solo release and sharing a collection of unreleased, vintage-inspired originals that blend nostalgic charm with a modern twist.
Drawing from the rich traditions of jazz, blues, and country — with a touch of psychedelic flair — Sophie’s songwriting is both timeless and distinctly her own. Her stories are laced with wit, warmth, and a hint of mischief, offering a refreshing take on classic genres.
Her debut single, “Topless Picking Flowers” — set for release on September 19th — is a dreamy fusion of classic country and smooth Hawaiian tones. On stage, Sophie captivates with exceptional rhythm guitar work and a honey-toned voice that soars effortlessly.

description:
Jewellery Making - Creative Arts holiday programme for teens, Craft your own rings in this introduction to metal-smithed jewellery making! In this quick paced one session workshop you’ll learn some metalworking fundamentals to turn raw silver, copper and brass into shining wearable rings. Use hammers and stamps to add textures and simple lettering to customise your creation!

Techniques covered:

- Use sizers and jeweller’s callipers to measure ring size
- Use files and sanding to refine and smooth metal edges and surfaces
- Use hammers and stamps to texture and form metal
- Use jeweller’s flame torches to solder join metal
- Use Dremel & bench polishers to refine & finish metal casts into wearable jewellery

Minimum age is 13 years. This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, pottery, animation and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

The Annual Hutt Valley Diwali, organised by the Wellington Punjabi Sports and Cultural Club Inc. (WPSCC Inc.), is a vibrant, family-friendly celebration of light, culture, and community. Held each year in the heart of the Hutt Valley, this non-profit event brings together people of all ages and backgrounds to enjoy the rich traditions of Diwali.

The festival features a colourful mix of cultural performances, traditional and modern music and dance, delicious food, local art and craft stalls, and engaging activities for children and families. It offers a unique opportunity to experience the diverse cultures that make up our region while celebrating the universal values of light over darkness, hope, and togetherness.

WPSCC Inc. proudly hosts this event to promote unity, cultural understanding, and community spirit in the Hutt Valley and beyond.

description:
Cooking: Indian Vegan, Indian food is one of the great cuisines of the world and creates robust fully-flavoured vegan dishes. Learn how to create intense and delicious flavours with freshly prepared spices and herbs. All ingredients included in course fee.

Description
Indian cooking expert, Manjula Patel, has assembled a range of vegan Indian dishes for you to learn and enjoy making and eating. In this practical cooking course, you’ll observe dishes being made by Manjula and then work in pairs to create most of these dishes yourselves.

Please note this is a practical cooking class that will not cover vegan philosophy. Not suitable for people allergic to nuts.

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:
- Discuss the flavours and spices used in Indian cuisine
- Know where to purchase ingredients for a selection of vegan dishes and finger food
- Read and follow a range of recipes step-by-step
- Create some classic dishes to try again at home

All ingredients included in course fee. Bring an apron, dishcloth, and a couple of tea towels and containers to take any leftovers home.

Note: Our cooking courses are designed to provide a collaborative and immersive learning experience where learners often work in pairs and/or groups. While we wish to create an inclusive environment for all participants, it is important to note that our courses are unable to accommodate specific food allergies or deviate from the preplanned dishes and menus.

Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Steiner School Fair 2025, Nau Mai Haere Mai ki te Raphael House Steiner School Fair. The School Fair is our major annual fundraiser hosted by the school community. Its purpose is to celebrate the school’s education and culture with the wider Wellington Community.

Each year students, teachers and parents work together to transform the school environment. Activities, displays, artistic presentations, gift stalls and food offerings provide a venue for community engagement that is a highlight on the school’s annual calendar.

Dive into a world of magic and imagination at our Annual Fair! Join us for a day fueled by holistic education, creative adventures and community togetherness.

Throughout the year, parents, students and teachers get together to transform our school into a mystical, sensory wonderland.

Explore and shop from a delightful array of unique, handcrafted crafts, toys, and Seasonal treats. This is where nature, creativity and heartwarming experiences come together to nurture young minds and inspire families.

Kindergarten parents create small gifts, from natural, materials which the young child will receive in the Little Peoples room. The handwork room is lovingly and thoughtfully prepared with the sensory experiences and impressions of the young child in mind.

Other parents are busy with tasks like creating Christmas crackers and decorations and researching new and exciting tantalizing recipes for the two cafes.

The Teaching faculty gathers students' work, from Kindergarten to Class 12 (Year 13), which are on display in the Eurythmy Room. If you have ever wondered what a main lesson book is you are bound to find one, or more, here!

To ensure there is fun for everyone we even create games to play both indoors and out. Then to add to the atmosphere during the day you will hear the sound of music and singing, and even some dancing while enjoying an organic coffee. The School Fair is a great day for all.

Skip the traffic - There is very limited parking around the school area, so please make use of our Fair Shuttle Bus - every 30 minutes to and from Melling Station. Gold coin per person per trip.

description:
NZIFF: Went Up the Hill, An unsettling, sinister slow-burn thriller, Samuel Van Grinsven unites rising star Dacre Montgomery with Phantom Thread’s Vicky Krieps and New Zealand’s own Sarah Peirse for a supernatural chiller like no other.

In the icy, shadow-stricken world of Went Up the Hill’s Christchurch, it would seem that the death of Elizabeth, wife of Jill (Vicky Krieps), has taken with it warmth itself. The unexpected suicide of her partner has left her a hollowed-out shell – that is, until Jack (Dacre Montgomery), Elizabeth’s long-absent son, arrives at the funeral, apparently invited by Jill herself, though she does not remember doing so.

The circumstances of Jack’s long absence are unclear – all that is known is that Jack was given up for adoption at a very young age. Staying the night at Jill and Elizabeth’s oppressive, concrete-clad mountain abode, it quickly becomes clear that the spirit of Elizabeth has not yet departed – instead, she has gained the ability to possess both wife and son and is utilising this ability to linger and address the needs of either relationship. What initially seems to be a gift from beyond, however, begins to sour when long-hidden secrets of the past begin to emerge, and lines between the two begin to be crossed.

The sophomore feature of Samuel Van Grinsven, Went Up the Hill is a wintry, gothic affair, and a showcase for the untapped talents of Montgomery, who most will recognise as the golden-haired, ill-fated muscle mutt Billy from Stranger Things. Essentially a two-hander (with occasional, welcome interjection from Kiwi legend Sarah Peirse as Jack’s frosty, mystery-shrouded aunt), Van Grinsven tracks the trajectory of these two adrift people and the spirit between them – from unexpected refuge, to joy, to dread – with a purposeful, drip-fed escalation of tension. Questions of control, abuse and the lingering weight of past scars take hold, all while the usually pleasantly scenic Christchurch landscape is transformed into a suffocatingly claustrophobic ice prison. Van Grinsven’s muscular direction bears none of the flashy excesses of an emerging filmmaker – his vision emerges, stately, imposing and fully-formed. — Tom Augustine

description:
North Pole Express Kapiti: 1pm - Sunday, 21 December 2025, North Pole Express Kapiti: 1pm - Sunday, 21 December 2025
Be whisked away on the North Pole Express to meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.

About this Event


Public sales commence 1 September 2025.
Nice List presale: 12pm, 25 June 2025 - 5pm, 1 July 2025. Password required.
No tickets will be held during presale, any remaining tickets will be offered to the public from 12pm on 1 September 2025. To join the 'Nice List' visit the .
If you would like to purchase a private carriage for your group on this service, please email prior to 15 June 2025.



Join The Magical Journey to meet Santa!
Your tickets include:
Entertainers
Carolling
Iced cocoa
Cookies
Souvenir Mug
A special souvenir from Santa
Santa
Extra surprises along the way
Our Candy Class and Claus Class Guests travel in comfort and receive extra treats along the way.


Prepare to be surrounded by the magic and wonder of the Christmas season!
Families will love the magical train ride in one of our specially decorated carriages. You’ll meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.
Set to the sounds of carols passengers are invited to join us to be whisked away on the North Pole Express. Delight in the magic of Christmas as the train departs for a journey to collect Santa who has been magically transported to an undisclosed location along the tracks.
From the distance the North Pole Express arrives then the train Conductors invite you and the other passengers to climb aboard shouting “All aboard!”.


All Aboard
During the first leg of the journey wide-eyed children of all ages are invited to engage with characters who are eager to hear what makes the Christmas season special to them.
You’ll meet the conductor, and join in the fun singing and dancing with your hosts and a few other characters who will appear in your carriage on the journey.
At the 'North Pole' Cocoa Class passengers enjoy their iced chocolate from their souvenir mug, and a delicious cookie served by our North Pole Express hosts. Candy and Claus Class passengers will be served aboard the train on the way to the North Pole.
Along the journey Santa appears in your carriage to present each passenger with their very own Christmas ornament. During the trip, characters in each carriage lead passengers in carolling and entertainment as the train makes its way back home.
Children UNDER 2 years (0-23 months) and travelling on the lap of an Adult are FREE. All Passengers 2 years old and over must hold a purchased ticket.

Please note: Seating in our Candy and Claus Classes is strictly limited. Candy and Claus Class Guests receive some extra surprises and treats along the way.
Seating in all carriages is arranged in a configuration of 4 seats as per normal train travel. NPE always endeavour to ensure those who book more than 4 seats are seated in close proximity to each other to ensure they can enjoy the experience together. Children under the age of 2 and travelling on the lap of an adult travel for free.
Wheelchair access: Due to the age and design of the carriages it is not possible to board whist seated in a wheelchair as the entrance is stairs and the doorways are very narrow. However we will be pleased to convey passengers of limited mobility whenever possible provided they can step onto the train from the platform, climbing a step and move to their reserved seats with the help of an able bodied carer. Our crew would assist guiding the passenger up the step onto the train and arrange for the storage of the wheelchair in the guards van. The wheelchair must be able to be folded up and cannot be used on the train. Please let us know when booking if you need wheelchair assistance.

Photo credit: John Bovis

description:
Pre order Thai foods, NEXT WEEK'S THAI COMFORT SPECIAL IS HERE!

Get ready for our Kin Favorite: Beef Mince Pad Kaprao with Fried Egg
!
This is the ultimate Thai street food classic, and here's why you need to pre-order:
Tender, savory beef mince is wok-tossed with a fiery, fragrant blend of fresh chilies, garlic, and aromatic fresh basil. The high heat of the wok creates a spicy-sweet, intensely savory glaze that is totally addictive.
Served hot over jasmine rice and crowned with a crispy-edged, runny-yolked fried egg. Break that yolk and mix it all together for a bite of pure happiness!
PLUS! Our signature Chicken or Tofu Satay is still on the menu for the perfect side.
Delivery Dates:
Dinner: Wednesday, October 8th
Lunch: Friday, October 10th
Order Cut-Off: Monday, October 6th, 9 PM
Pre-order now to secure your Thai feast!
#ThaiFood #BeefLover #thaicomfortfood #supportlocal #toobusytocook #busyparents #wellingtonfood #thaifoodwellington #kineatwellington

description:
🛠️🌿 Hands-On Conservation: Trap-Making with NAWIC🌿🛠️, Join us on Thursday 9th October, from 5:00pm – 7:30pm at MenzShed Hataitai for a hands-on evening of teamwork in the spirit of conservation. Let's protect our local native wildlife by building pest traps to donate to Predator Free Wellington in support of their mission.
With materials and ready-to-assemble kitsets kindly sponsored by Aoraki Construction, we’ll roll up our sleeves and assemble traps at MenzShed Hataitai - all tools and materials provided. No experience required.
After the mahi, we’ll come together to share fish 'n' chips and fizzy drinks on the bowling green, kindly provided by NAWIC. It’s a chance to connect, give back, and make a tangible impact on our environment.

The Otaki Kids Market is a vibrant and creative event that provides a unique platform for young entrepreneurs to showcase their talents and entrepreneurial spirit.

description:
North Pole Express Kapiti: 5pm - Saturday, 20 December 2025, North Pole Express Kapiti: 5pm - Saturday, 20 December 2025
Be whisked away on the North Pole Express to meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.

About this Event


Public sales commence 1 September 2025.
Nice List presale: 12pm, 25 June 2025 - 5pm, 1 July 2025. Password required.
No tickets will be held during presale, any remaining tickets will be offered to the public from 12pm on 1 September 2025. To join the 'Nice List' visit the .
If you would like to purchase a private carriage for your group on this service, please email prior to 15 June 2025.



Join The Magical Journey to meet Santa!
Your tickets include:
Entertainers
Carolling
Iced cocoa
Cookies
Souvenir Mug
A special souvenir from Santa
Santa
Extra surprises along the way
Our Candy Class and Claus Class Guests travel in comfort and receive extra treats along the way.


Prepare to be surrounded by the magic and wonder of the Christmas season!
Families will love the magical train ride in one of our specially decorated carriages. You’ll meet Santa, sing, and celebrate this special time of year.
Set to the sounds of carols passengers are invited to join us to be whisked away on the North Pole Express. Delight in the magic of Christmas as the train departs for a journey to collect Santa who has been magically transported to an undisclosed location along the tracks.
From the distance the North Pole Express arrives then the train Conductors invite you and the other passengers to climb aboard shouting “All aboard!”.


All Aboard
During the first leg of the journey wide-eyed children of all ages are invited to engage with characters who are eager to hear what makes the Christmas season special to them.
You’ll meet the conductor, and join in the fun singing and dancing with your hosts and a few other characters who will appear in your carriage on the journey.
At the 'North Pole' Cocoa Class passengers enjoy their iced chocolate from their souvenir mug, and a delicious cookie served by our North Pole Express hosts. Candy and Claus Class passengers will be served aboard the train on the way to the North Pole.
Along the journey Santa appears in your carriage to present each passenger with their very own Christmas ornament. During the trip, characters in each carriage lead passengers in carolling and entertainment as the train makes its way back home.
Children UNDER 2 years (0-23 months) and travelling on the lap of an Adult are FREE. All Passengers 2 years old and over must hold a purchased ticket.

Please note: Seating in our Candy and Claus Classes is strictly limited. Candy and Claus Class Guests receive some extra surprises and treats along the way.
Seating in all carriages is arranged in a configuration of 4 seats as per normal train travel. NPE always endeavour to ensure those who book more than 4 seats are seated in close proximity to each other to ensure they can enjoy the experience together. Children under the age of 2 and travelling on the lap of an adult travel for free.
Wheelchair access: Due to the age and design of the carriages it is not possible to board whist seated in a wheelchair as the entrance is stairs and the doorways are very narrow. However we will be pleased to convey passengers of limited mobility whenever possible provided they can step onto the train from the platform, climbing a step and move to their reserved seats with the help of an able bodied carer. Our crew would assist guiding the passenger up the step onto the train and arrange for the storage of the wheelchair in the guards van. The wheelchair must be able to be folded up and cannot be used on the train. Please let us know when booking if you need wheelchair assistance.

Photo credit: John Bovis

description:
Tartan Up The Green, Tartan Up The Green
Gather up the clan and join us here at Brewtown Upper Hutt – Tartan Up The Green is back for 2025!

Are you ready to be blown away by the power of the Pipes and Drums as Tartan Up The Green returns this October 4th for another rousing rendition of Bagpiping, Highland Drumming and Dancing!

Our mates from RNZPBA Wellington Hawkes Bay are back to curate their all-new take on traditional pipe and drum comps with some of the finest musicians in the country.

Join us on The Greenspace for our very own family friendly, FREE to attend salute to those earth-shaking instruments of war (literally) and all things Highlands and Islands!

It won’t just be Pipers and Drummers competing for glory. Brewtown is delighted to welcome some bonnie boogying in the form of Scottish Highland Dancing, as dancers from up and down the country wow the crowd with traditional dance.

A true showcase of strength and stamina, Highland Dancing is highly technical and recognised as a sport by the Sport Council of Scotland…waltzing this aint!

So, get behind these incredible young athletes and show your support at this years Tartan Up The Green!

description:
Daniel Champagne (Australia) LIVE at The Little Theatre | Lower Hutt (Matinee Concert), Presented by Nightingale Concerts...
The young virtuoso recently described as “the finest guitar player of this generation” has spent the past few years selling out shows all over the globe and will be bringing his dynamite live act back to New Zealand in 2025 for a series of intimate regional concerts!
Seated show
Family friendly  
Cheaper $15 tickets for under 18s because live music is for everyone!
October 18, 2025 @ The Little Theatre, Lower Hut
Doors open from 2:30pm / show starts at 3:00pm (4:15pm finish) 
Tickets are VERY limited. DON'T miss your chance to see live music at it's finest!
WHAT THE PRESS SAY..
“The word Prodigy seems to entirely fall short of this soft-spoken young man’s skills, he coaxes sounds and melodies out of his instrument that literally drop jaws.”
The Calgary Herald, CANADA

“Today I saw the future of Folk – Festival goers flocking in the thousands towards the main stage to witness a young musical phenomenon from Australia dish out an absolute show-stopper.” The Firefly Column, USA

“Daniel Champagne is a crossroads. Fusing the strong traditions of Blues, Folk and other roots art with pop showmanship and admirable lyrical ability. I firmly believe that he will become an ambassador for roots music in a time where it desperately needs representation.” The Indie Blender, CANADA

“reinventing roots guitar” Rhythms Magazine, AUSTRALIA“Watching Daniel Champagne perform is a once in a lifetime experience. He is a true prodigy that plays like no one else could possibly play unless they spent at least two lifetimes studying the art.” BW Review, NEW ZEALAND

“Daniel Champagne exudes a natural ease on stage, as he sings poignant lyrics and beautifully crafted melodies that invariably whisk the heart up with grand romanticism. Coupled with an exhilarating guitar talent that transcends mere acoustic playing to replicate a whole band, Champagne is just magical” Themusic.com.au, AUSTRALIA

"You feel as if he just invented the instrument yesterday and was discovering its possibilities afresh” Ted Gioia (American jazz critic and music historian)

description:
Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!, Pavilion Open Day – Celebrate Spring with Us!
Wednesday 24 September 2025, 10am – 2pm
Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden
Free
These September school holidays, welcome the season of new life and bright colours at our family-friendly Pavilion Open Day. Tamariki can explore the garden’s spring magic through self-guided, hands-on activities designed to spark curiosity and connection.
Activities include:
• Nature’s Colours Art Table – Create your own “spring colour” bookmark using petals, leaves, and other natural treasures.
• Spring Scavenger Hunt – Follow clues to spot signs of the season: sweet-scented flowers, fresh buds, busy birds and more.
• Spring Reading Nook – Relax on the grass mat with tree-stump cushions and enjoy a basket of spring-themed books.
• Bird’s Nest Discovery Table – Get up close to real nests (ethically sourced), soft bird puppets, and natural playdough to shape “eggs” and match them to their native bird owners.
Perfect for children aged 4–12 and their whānau. Dress for a day outdoors and celebrate te kōanga—the vibrant season of growth!
We’ll see you soon in the Discovery Garden, Wellington Botanic Garden!
label: Family Friendly

description:
Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds — Wild God Tour, Their music has long defied classification. For over 40 years, Nick Cave & The Bad Seeds have delivered a sophisticated mix of post-punk, experimental, gospel, and blues to adoring fans. Now, in a New Zealand exclusive, Wellington gets to hear them live at TSB Arena in February. Renowned for their exhilarating and unforgettable performances, the band is regarded as one of the most thrilling to watch on stage. 
In 2024, they released their eighteenth studio album, ‘Wild God’. Now, Nick and the band are circling the globe on the ‘Wild God Tour’. They have finished the North American and European legs, and TSB Arena on Wellington’s waterfront is the next stop off. The band will perform a setlist drawn from the latest album alongside songs spanning the four decades of a storied career.
Brought to you in association with Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts. 
Tickets will go on sale to the public on Friday, 29 August at 10am.

This magical string puppet adventure that introduces the audience to an intimate encounter with a few of Aotearoa New Zealand's special native creatures.

description:
Conservation Week, Skink and Gecko Live Show Reino Grundling will talk and show slides illustrating the mostly unrealised role that lizards (skinks and geckos) had in our pristine ecosystems, with some 130 or more different species! And what makes this presentation so marvellous is that he will have a number of living examples there for all to see! Great for the kids!

Conservation Colouring Competition The Masterton Library is celebrating the importance of conservation with a colouring competition—and there are some great prizes up for grabs. There will also be an informative display featuring conservation-themed resources you’re welcome to take home with you.

Dr Marie Doole Biodiversity Funding Talk Dr Marie Doole will discuss the pros and cons around nature/biodiversity credits, an emerging option for funding the protection of biodiversity, particularly on private land, by investors, whether corporate or philanthropic. Worth attending if you've been following the media hype.

Think Like a Forest Film Forest and Bird are showing this film, starring Sam the Trap Man, in three locations. The Regent have generously offered to show it where it will have the most effect—on the big screen! The film is produced by Pure Advantage who have an aspirational programme around landscape-scale restoration of native forests called Recloaking Papatūānuku.

Kōkako Morning Hikoi Join us for a special one-off tour and experience the magic of the kōkako at Pūkaha. Follow our expert guide to a kōkako hotspot and enjoy the rare opportunity to possibly see and hear kōkako. After your walk, return to the centre for a hot drink and morning tea.

Waihinga Bridge Planting Morning Ruamāhanga Farm Foundation is hosting a morning of planting and a celebration of children's voices at the start of the soon to be opened Waihinga Bridge Walkway. Tools will be provided and all ages and abilities are welcome!

Exploring Ngahere Under Story and Campfire Talk The Tramping Gently Club Art Collective (TGCAC) takes up temporary residency at Te Whare Whakapapa Raranga to explore human-centred warning systems and ngahere's role in mitigating danger. Join us in bringing the understory into te whare through kōrero and creative exploration.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Paint Time with Rapunzel, Paint Time with Rapunzel
Join Rapunzel for a magical painting session where young artists will create their own flower-filled canvas masterpiece!

About this Event

Paint Time with Rapunzel
Let your creativity blossom in this enchanting art workshop for kids aged 5 and up! 🎨🌸🌼 Join Rapunzel for a magical painting session where young artists will create their own flower-filled canvas masterpiece inspired by her colourful tower garden.
While your artwork dries, enjoy whimsical games with magical prizes and take some fairytale-worthy photos with the princess herself!
Includes:

🎨 Take-home flower artwork

Perfect for young artists, fairy tale lovers and anyone who dreams in pastel! 🌸🖌️✨

Please note that we are not registered childcare providers, which means an adult responsible for each child must remain on the premises. The venue is also a café restaurant with other areas where parents can chill while the workshop is running.

description:
2:22 A Ghost Story, 2:22 A Ghost Story
Do You Believe in Ghosts?

In a rapidly gentrifying part of London, a married couple are renovating their new home. But something strange and frightening can be heard at the same time every night. What forces have they disturbed? Jenny has become convinced the house is haunted. Husband Sam isn’t having a bar of it. Tension builds throughout a housewarming dinner with friends as the clock ticks closer to 2:22… when a shocking truth will be revealed.

📣 “Sharp, quick, and cleverly layered with clues – a thunderous fright night.” - The Guardian

Spine-chillingly funny, scary and filled with suspense, Join us for the New Zealand premiere of Danny Robin's West-End smash hit, directed by stage and screen legend Peter Feeney. Starring the unparalleled talents of:

⭐ Regan Taylor
⭐ Pamela Sidhu
⭐ Jack Sergent-Shadbolt
⭐ Serena Cotton

With otherworldly design by Chris Reddington, Marcus McShane, Daniel Elliott and Shiloh Dobie, 2:22 A Ghost Story is set to be the most spook-tacular event of the year! BOOK NOW!

2:22 A GHOST STORY
🗓️ 13 Sep - 11 Oct | Preview 12 Sep

Step into the enchanted fairy grove for a magical potion-making adventure! Led by a whimsical fairy guide, this hands-on workshop invites young potion crafters (ages 5+) to mix glittery brews, stir up flowery scents, and create their own take-home fairy potions. 🧚‍♀️✨
This 1.5-hour experience is full of sparkly fun, gentle storytelling and a sprinkle of mischief — with fizzy surprises, sweet smells, and lots of giggles.
Includes: 🌸 Potion making with a fairy host 🌼 Take-home fairy potion bottle 🧚‍♀️ Enchanting stories and magical games ✨ Perfect for kids aged 5 and up
A fluttery, fun-filled time for every little fairy and forest friend! 🌿💫

Please note that we are not registered childcare providers, which means an adult responsible for each child must remain on the premises. The venue is also a café restaurant with other areas where parents can chill while the workshop is running.

description:
Celebrate the Fabric, Exquisite pieces of needlework are on display and in use every day at Wellington Cathedral of
St Paul: beautifully decorated fabrics that hang at the front of the altars, spectacular robes and
stoles worn by priests at services, and fine linens used at every service of Holy Communion.

You’ll learn much about this remarkable fabric artistry when Jo Dixey talks to the Friends of
Wellington Cathedral of St Paul and guests on Wednesday, 24 September at 10.30 am.
Jo is an internationally regarded professional embroiderer who graduated from the Royal
School of Needlework and now lives permanently in New Zealand. She teaches, exhibits and sells
her work, as well as accepting commissions from churches, fashion designers and private
individuals. She has also had contracts from the film industry, working on the Disney film Mulan
and most recently on season 1 of Lord of the Rings TV series. Jo’s collection of embroidered
3D viruses, created during the 2020 Covid lockdown, are now on display in The Museum of
New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa.

Venue: Loaves and Fishes Hall, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul.
label: Religion & Spirituality

description:
A free workshop for the General Public: Dying to Know about Dying Matters?, Please note, this is a FREE workshop availble to the public and is not designed for health professionals to attend.
Many people find it difficult to talk about dying, yet dying is an important stage of life and is inevitable.
We plan for the birth of a child, yet when it comes to the end of life, we don’t often want to think , or talk about it.
Come along to our workshop and find out more about dying matters, how an Advance Care Planning (ACP)can benefit you and your family/whānau and what to expect at the end of life.
Having a plan outlines our care preferences for the future. Having an Advance Care Plan (ACP) that aligns with our beliefs and values, is a gift that we can give to our family / whānau.
We will explore:
Why is it hard to talk about death and dying?
What to expect when someone is dying
Supports available
Advance care planning processes
Date: Friday 5 September 2025
Time: 9.00 am - 12.30 pm
Presenters: Mary Ann Hardcastle Advance Care Plannining Facilitator & Chris Dunn Clinical Nurse Educator Nelson Tasman Hospice
Cost: Free
Limited attendees: Registration is essential
Who can attend?: General Public (This workshop is not designed for Health Professionals)
Venue: Nelson Tasman Hospice, 331 Suffolk Road, Stoke, Nelson

description:
Café Scientifique - Space: What Is Our Place In the Cosmos?, Join us for a new Café Scientifique series hosted by Pūtaiao ki te Pāpori—School of Science in Society.

At this first event in September, astrophysicist Dr Yvette Perrott and novelist Dr Tim Corballis will discuss the evolving picture physics gives us about the nature of the universe, and the ways people find their place in it.

Café Scientifique is a place where, for the price of a cup of coffee or a glass of wine, anyone can come to explore the latest ideas in science and technology in a relaxed, friendly environment.

The evening will start with a short introduction from the speakers, followed by a question-and-answer conversation.

Doors open at 5.30 pm, talks begin at 6 pm. All welcome—free entry, nibbles provided.

Please note: anyone under the age of 18 must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
For further information, please contact scienceinsociety@vuw.ac.nz.
