description:
Contact Improvisation with Eliza Sanders & Footnote Dance, Contact Improvisation with Eliza Sanders & Footnote Dance
Five-Day Intensive Workshop with Eliza Sanders

About this Event

This intensive week offers a rare opportunity to dive deep into the practical tools and nuanced territories of Contact Improvisation. Fresh from three weeks of intensive CI training in Thailand, Eliza returns with new wisdom and embodied understanding to share with our community.

A Unique Learning Community
This workshop brings together an extraordinary learning environment where Footnote's four full-time dancers will practice alongside independent dancers and community participants, creating a rich exchange of distinct yet equally valuable body wisdoms. Together, we'll explore the multilayered practice of Contact Improvisation in its depth and complexity.

The Journey: Progressive Deepening Throughout the Week
Through structured explorations and guided improvisation, we'll delve into the physical practice while also discovering the connections between how we move together and how we navigate life with greater ease and joy. As is Eliza’s style, we'll explore both the practical tools of the craft and uncover how this embodied practice offers insights for moving through the world with more presence and connection.
We'll venture into advanced techniques and principles of Contact Improvisation. Each day will build organically on the last, allowing for genuine integration and discovery. The specific focus will evolve from the insights and practices Eliza brings back from the Inspiral intensive in Thailand.



Who This Workshop Is For
This intensive creates magic precisely because it brings together diverse perspectives and experience levels. We welcome:
Graduates of Contact Improvisation foundations workshops ready to deepen their practice
Experienced movers curious about the broader applications of CI principles
Proffesional dancers eager to nuance and expand their practice
Community dancers eager to learn alongside professional practitioners
Anyone interested in exploring movement as a pathway to more effective communication and compassionate action
Those drawn to embodied practices for personal and social transformation
Prior Contact Improvisation experience recommended but not essential—our kaupapa embraces the wisdom that emerges when professional and community dancers share the learning space.

Practical Details
When: Monday - Friday, October 13-17, 2025 Time: 9am - 5pm daily Where: Footnote Dance Studios Capacity: Maximum 10 participants (alongside our 4 Footnote dancers) What to Bring: Comfortable clothes for dancing, long sleeves and socks recommended Included: Tea and snacks throughout each day (lunch not included)

Investment
Early Bird: $300 (until September 12th) Regular Price: $350

About Your Facilitator
Eliza brings years of dedicated Contact Improvisation practice and teaching, known for creating environments where technical skill development and personal discovery flourish together. Her recent intensive training in Thailand with internationally renowned teachers adds fresh depth to her already rich understanding of CI as both movement practice and life practice. Former participants consistently highlight her ability to create space where everyone—from newcomers to experienced dancers—can access new layers of understanding and embodied wisdom.

Come As You Are
The most profound discoveries in Contact Improvisation emerge from the unexpected—from the intersection of different bodies, experiences, and ways of moving through the world. Your unique perspective and embodied wisdom are exactly what this learning community needs. Come ready to explore, to be surprised, and to discover how the dance floor becomes a training ground for creating the more compassionate, connected world we all long for.
No perfection required. Just openness to the movement.

description:
Intro to 2D Traditional Animation - Creative Arts Holiday Programme, This is a beginners course in 2D animation where tweens & teens will learn the time-honoured principles of hand-drawn animation and how to apply them to your own animation project. You may work on a project incorporating your own ideas, or if you'd rather, an assigned a project from your tutor.

You can use any device, ipad or laptop you already own (except a mobile – it's really not big enough to do good animation on). The school does not provide any digital equipment.

Your tutor, Ross Payne, is a 30 year veteran of traditional 2D animation, and loves to share his knowledge about it for you to love it as much as he does.

In each lesson there will be examples and demonstrations of the animation principles with follow up exercises to put your new skills into practice. You'll work on your project both during class and at home, applying the animation principles to your individualised project.

You can choose to draw your animation on paper then scan/capture into your device, or choose to draw your animation digitally, directly into an animation programme. which ever you choose, instructions in class will be provided to give you the skills needed for this step.

Bring a water bottle and snack for morning tea.

This workshop is for ages 10 and above. Tuesday - Friday, 30 September - 3 October, 10 am - 1 pm daily.

This workshop is part of Inverlochy Art School's September School Holiday Programme. For more teen & tween workshops including photography, jewellery making, pottery and sewing head to the 'Tamariki and Teens' section of our website.

description:
Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington, Wesley Huff | Leaders Lunch | Wellington
This September Wesley Huff is joining Thinking Matters for the Truth Matters Tour in Dunedin, Christchurch, Wellington and full-day Conference in Auckland.

While in Wellington, he will be doing his only Christian Leaders Lunch.

Proceedings
Doors will open 11:15 am
11:30 am - the event will begin with a short powhiri/mihi whakatau
11:50 am - Kai
12:20 pm - Wes will present his talk and do q and a
1:30 pm - Conclusion of event
About Wesley Huff
Wesley Huff was born in Multan, Pakistan, and spent a portion of his childhood in the Middle East. After being diagnosed with a rare neurological condition at the age of eleven that left him paralyzed from the waist down, Wes experienced a miraculous recovery for which the doctors themselves had no medical explanation. This experience, along with a great deal of study and soul searching in his later teen years, solidified his interest in faith and in engaging the beliefs and worldview perspectives of others. He spent his high school years in Northern Ontario and currently lives in Toronto, Canada, with his wife and three children.

Wesley is currently the Central Canada Director for Apologetics Canada and has been a guest on a variety of public platforms, from The Joe Rogan Experience and Piers Morgan Uncensored, to Apologia Radio and Daily Dose of Wisdom. He has participated in numerous public dialogues, debates, and interfaith events on issues of belief and religion globally.

He holds a BA in sociology from York University, a Masters of Theological Studies from Tyndale University, and is currently doing a PhD in New Testament at the University of Toronto’s Wycliffe College.

description:
A Very Wellington Sea Shanty Society Xmas, A Very Wellington Sea Shanty Society Xmas
NAUTICAL GAMES /// BEST DRESSED PRIZES /// SINGALONG SHANTIES /// XMAS-TYPE STUFF

Your work Xmas-party is going to be lame or cancelled so put a 2-dollar shop Santa's hat on 2025 and have a sing with Aotearoa's Most Seaworthy Shanty crew.

Prepare to be hit by a wave of joy and merriment as the Full Wellington Sea Shanty Society Experience transform the Abandoned Taproom into a shanty wonderland.

We got shanty booklets for all ye faithful and merch for Xmas presents.

If there's one thing we can all agree on in this country, it's that Xmas needs more sea shanties!

Only Te Upoko o te Ika show for 2025. New EP out in March 2026.

🎅🎅🎅

WELLINGTON SEA SHANTY SOCIETY

Aotearoa New Zealand's Most 'Sea Worthy' Shanty Group™ have been belting out traditional and original sea songs from Aotearoa, France, Spain, the UK and more, since time immemorial (2012).

The W.S.S.S have toured Aotearoa and France multiple times and are known for their rowdy and participatory live shows. They've performed at Paimpol (one of the world's largest shanty festivals), Splore, Albany Folk Festival (Aus), Quebec Sea Shanty Festival (Canada) and a shipload of other festivals in NZ, France & Canada. Their new EP 'Sea Shanties of the 70s, 80s, & Today!' has just recently surfaced to complement their 'Now That's What I Call Sea Shanties' series. Another must-listen is 'Ahoy!' - a French/English album made with Nantes amis Croche Dedans.

🌙✨ Join us for the Hutt City Night Market – a new weekly night market bringing food, flavour, and fun to the heart of Lower Hutt!

Come down to Dowse Square every Thursday from 4–8PM, rain or shine, and enjoy a handpicked line up of local food trucks serving a delicious range of cuisines. It’s the perfect way to unwind after work, catch up with friends and whānau, and support small local businesses.

description:
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025, A bioblitz is all about searching for and recording all the species you can over a set time period.
Zealandia is one of the most biodiversity rich places in the motu(show English translation) and the perfect place to come searching for species over the long weekend. You may well find species that we have seldom seen, so this is fun for you and potentially invaluable information for our conservation team. It’s a great reason to go exploring some of the tracks you might not know well, or at all!
All you have to do is upload your observations of species to iNaturalist. It doesn’t have to be done during those four days. In fact, you’ll have a further 14 days to upload and identify all your observations made during the official period.
The Great Southern BioBlitz 2025 is run by a network of keen citizen scientists from across the globe.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
BOWIE-OKE at The Last Post Restaurant & Bar, BOWIE-OKE at The Last Post Restaurant & Bar
BOWIE-OKE – David Bowie Karaoke 🎤

Calling all starmen, space oddities, and heroes (even if it’s just for one day) — it’s your time to shine! Step up to the mic and unleash your inner Ziggy.

💥 Venue: The Last Post Restaurant & Bar, 57 Fox St, Featherston RSA
💥 Date: Friday 26 September, 7.30 pm ‘til late

Dress loud, sing proud, and channel your favourite Bowie era — from glam and soul to Berlin cool or ‘90s brilliance. It’s karaoke, but make it Bowie. 🌟

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

☆ BOWIETOWN FEATHERSTON ☆
⚡Enter the Bowie universe!⚡

This September, Featherston transforms into BowieTown for the very first time – a full weekend celebrating the music, artistry, and magic of David Bowie. Expect live music, dance, creativity, food, and plenty of ways to let your inner Ziggy shine.
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1A1dp5NUzJ/

📅 Friday 26 – Sunday 28 September 2025
Featherston, Wairarapa


📍 Here’s what’s happening across the weekend 📍

⭐ Bowie-oke
Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🎤 Friday 26 Sept, 7.30 pm ‘til late
Bowie karaoke to kick things off!
Event link https://www.facebook.com/share/1TdhZKFpvH/


⭐ Bowie Cocktails & Desserts
Brac & Bow 🍸🍰 Friday 26 – Sunday 28 Sept
Sweet and stylish, Bowie-style.


⭐ Featherston Library Display
30 Books Recommended by Bowie 📚 Friday 26 & Saturday 27 Sept.
Discover what the Thin White Duke read.

Featherston Library 🎨 Saturday 27 Sept, 10 – 11 am.
Kids (and big kids) welcome.


⭐ Bowie Barkers Dog Party
Dorset Square 🐾 Saturday 27 Sept, 11 am.
Walk & Bark + bring/swap/donate/buy dog gear. Hosted by Madame Mutts.


⭐ Bowie Art Bash + Portrait Exhibition
ANZAC Hal l🎨 Saturday 27 Sept 1 – 3 pm
Life drawing with Bowie models (bring your own gear), $10 cash entry. Plus a Bowie Portrait Exhibition with works for sale (free entry).


⭐ Bowie Pizzas
The Last Post Restaurant & Bar (Featherston RSA) 🍕 Saturday 27 Sept from 5 pm
Thin-crust Ziggy-style deliciousness!


⭐ BOWIE BLASTOFF CONCERT + AFTERPARTY
ANZAC Hall 🚀 Saturday 27 Sept 7 pm
Entry $20 (cash only, door sales)
Live performances from Mad Honey, The Davids, Taza Manaza, Tangle Dance Community, Justine Rose Kingdon, Fräulein Sylvia, and Hugo Del Mar.
Followed by the Blastoff Afterparty – put on your red shoes and dance, dance, dance to Bowie + beyond with DJ Nyx. (Alcohol-free event.)

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

✨ Plus all weekend: check out Bowie-era books in Featherston Booktown and browse vintage Bowie bric-a-brac in local shops.


⚡ Featherston will NEVER be the SAME. Step inside the starman’s world — only at BowieTown 2025.

description:
Chilean Independence Day 🇨🇱🇨🇱, Chilean Independence Day 🇨🇱🇨🇱
UPDATE!!!! We’re moving the event to Sunday the 21st because of venue availability.

Vamos a celebrar este 18 de Septiembre como corresponde! ✨

Los queremos invitar a celebrar estas fiestas con la comunidad en el bowling de Seatoun.
Vamos a tener dos parrillas prendidas, juegos tradicionales (gymkana, carrera de sacos, la silla musical, una pichanga y hasta karaoke), además de música y baile pa’ que no falte el zapateo . 🎶⚽🔥
La idea es que cada uno traiga algo para la parrilla y algo rico para compartir: puede ser un postre, unas empanadas, sopaipillas, ensaladas o lo que se les ocurra. En el local se podra comprar bebestibles varios, incluso terremotos!!! 🍷🍻
Y porque no hay primera sin segunda ni segunda sin tercera… 🎉
Este año vamos a celebrar con varios panoramas:
⦁ Sábado 13 de Septiembre: celebración en el restaurant Puro Chile desde las 12pm a 7pm .

⦁ Sábado 20 de Septiembre en la noche: seguimos la fiesta en el barrio con DJ Descontrol.

⦁ Domingo 21 de Septiembre: en el bowling de Seatoun con nosotros desde 12pm.

También para los que quieran ir a apoyar y ver el show de Puku Rangi Tea (Grupo de danza de Rapa Nui) en Wellington.
⦁Martes 16/09: Performance en Scots College Wellington. FREE 7pm.
⦁Jueves 18/09: Presentacion en el musel Te Papa Tongarewa. FREE 1pm

¡Así que vengan con ganas de pasarlo chancho y celebrar juntos este 18 toda la semana!!!

Nos vemos pronto!!!!!!


Let’s celebrate this Chilean Independence day the right way! ✨

We’d like to invite you to join us for our celebration with the community at the Seatoun Bowling Club.
We’ll have two barbecues going, traditional games (gymkana, sack race, musical chairs, a friendly football match, and even karaoke), plus music and dancing so we don’t miss out on some good cueca steps. 🎶⚽🔥

The idea is that everyone brings something for the barbecue and something tasty to share: it could be a dessert, empanadas, sopaipillas, salads, or whatever you’d like. Drinks will be available for purchase at the venue, including Chile’s famous cocktail, the Terremoto.🍷🍻

And because one party is never enough… 🎉 This year we’ll be celebrating several events:

⦁Saturday, September 13th: Celebration at Puro Chile restaurant, from 12pm to 7pm.

⦁Saturday, September 20th at night: we keep the party going in El Barrio with DJ Descontrol.

⦁Sunday, 21 September at the Seatoun Bowling with us from 12 pm.

Also for those who would like to go and support and watch the show by Puku Rangi Tea (Rapa Nui Dance Group) in Wellington.
⦁Tuesday 16: Performance at Scots College Wellington. FREE 7pm.
⦁Thursday 18: Performance at the Te Papa Tongarewa Museum. FREE 1pm.

So come ready to have an amazing time and celebrate this Chilean Independence Day/Week together, not just once but several times!

See you soon. 🎉🎉🎉

description:
Beginners Sewing Class, Come to our beginners sewing class and you can walk away with your very own handmade patchwork bag! Learning all the skills needed to start sewing right from threading the machine, you need zero prior sewing skills - this is the perfect course for all levels of beginners. You will learn how to handle fabrics, how to use the machine smoothly and effectively, and even get to put in a zip! Making a bag and a cushion cover, you get the chance to take away TWO items that you have made and learn great foundation sewing skills, all while having a blast with a lovely group of people.

Everything needed for the course is provided, just bring yourself and your sewing machine if you have one. If you have a machine we do recommend learning with it as it will help you to become familiar with your particular machine’s quirks, however we also have machines available to borrow.

**Our machine numbers are limited, so please let us know if you will be needing one!**

description:
Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration, Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration
¡Celebra con nosotros el Día de los Muertos con música, baile, comida tradicional y altares conmemorativos!

About this Event

Welcome to the Day of the Dead - Dia de los Muertos Celebration at AWHI Yoga & Wellbeing! Join us for a vibrant and colorful event filled with traditional live music, storytelling, rituals for remembering the dead and delicious prehispanic Mexican cacao drink. Honour your loved ones at our ofrenda, or altar, and learn more from our faciltator, Claudio Escutia, about this rich cultural tradition.
Let's come together to celebrate life and remember those who have passed in a joyful and meaningful way. Don't miss out on this special celebration!
What to Expect:
Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.
An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.
History of the day of the dead celebration.
Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.
Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).
Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged) 
Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones 
Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot
Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments
Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

description:
Carnival of Chaos, Myth, chaos, murder, alchemy, mystery, and devils are afoot in this four-night festival featuring six short retellings of classic works with strange new twists! We invite you to THEA 303’s ‘Carnival of Chaos’ in Studio 77, premiering hybrid works from the House of Echoes (1 & 3 October): The Odyssey, Medea and The Devil is a Lover, and the House of Secrets (2 & 4 October): Rope, The Taming of the Shrew  and  God’s Gift.

Each adaptation has been directed, designed, produced, choreographed and managed by the students.

House of Echoes (Season A): Performs on the 1st and the 3rd of October

The Odyssey – An adaptation of Homer’s The Odyssey
Odysseus just wants to get home to his true love, but the journey isn’t exactly smooth. The streets after 2 a.m. and too many beers are alive with obstacles; cops are grumpy, goth girls are tempting, and the help of the Gods is nowhere to be found. Meanwhile, back home, a dangerous polycule is getting cozy with his Penelope…

Medea – An adaptation of Euripides’ Medea
Medea lives her perfect 1950s white picket fence dream! When her husband starts taking new pills “Conservatol, the wonder drug for traditional love” she learns that traditional love means different to what she thought. Betrayal, hurt, and anger push her to the edge making her act in ways she never thought she would. “Heaven has no rage like love to hatred turned, nor Hell a fury like a woman scorned.”

The Devil is a Lover – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Love Labours Lost and Ben Johnson’s The Devil is an Ass
Satan and two devils, Beelzebub and Pug, make a pact to travel to a 1920s speakeasy on Earth and abstain from corruption for 3 years. As the narrative combines absurdist actions with Shakespearean dialogue, the three devils quickly learn of the difficulties present in avoiding corruption and the effect their devilish meddling has on humanity.

House of Secrets (Season B): Performs on the 2nd and 4th of October

Rope – An adaptation of Patrick Hamilton’s Rope (1929)
Not a whodunnit, but a howdoyahideit? Marion and Melanie are sure they’ve committed the perfect murder by killing their friend Norman and hiding his body in a chest, a chest their select group of friends have been invited over to have a murder mystery games night around. It’s foolproof, until the over analytical Constance comes to play…

The Taming of the Shrew – An adaptation of William Shakespeare’s Taming of the Shrew
In 1970's Aotearoa, sisters Katherina and Bianca find their love lives complicated by their father's order that one may not pursue romance unless the other follows suit. The sudden appearance of a charming factory owner and friend of Bianca's beau could mark a new hope for the two, but will this lead to an ocean of love or does something far more sinister lurk beneath the surface?

God’s Gift – An adaptation of Ben Johnson’s The Alchemist
The Carnival has come to town in 1615 London. Lovewit has gone to see the show, leaving her manor in the hands of Jeremy the Butler, the “Alchemist,” and Dol, a hardworking prostitute. Lovewit’s house becomes a place for schemes, with ample opportunities to take money from foolish men. Will Dol be happy with her split of the money? Or will a surprise visitor shake things up?

Content Forecast: mentions of and implied sexual violence and domestic abuse, mentions of drug use, strobe lighting, violence, coarse language, loud noises, haze, and smoke.

description:
Day of the Dead Celebration - Dia de los Muertos, Join Claudio for this special occasion we will be celebrating one of the most important holidays in Mexico, the day of the dead or “Dia de los Muertos”.

The Day of the Dead is one of the traditions that has remained alive throughout the centuries; the main holidays are November 1 & 2, which UNESCO designated and cataloged as an Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2003.

This special celebration dates back to prehispanic times before the arrival of Europeans to America, and has been alive and widely celebrated over the years.

Expect:

Cleansing copal and herbal welcoming.

An opening ceremony to acknowledge the Tlalmanalli (offering and altar) with the deep sound of the conch shell in the four directions and drums sounds.

History of the day of the dead celebration.

Explanation of the altar, and the main elements for an ofrenda.

Storytelling: learn of Mexican legends like Catrinas and Xoloitzcuintle (the Mexican dog that helps the dead to find their way to Mictlan, the Aztec underword).

Remembering and sharing histories about the loved ones that passed away (optional but encouraged)

Traditional Mexican chants for remembering the loved ones

Atole de Chocolate, a traditional prehispanic drink - amazing in flavour, consumed cold or hot

Music to invoke emotion and imagery of contemplative natural and mystical environments

Finish with a shamanic atmosphere of relaxation and traditional chants.

description:
Asia After Five: Experiences in Taiwan, About the event
The Asia New Zealand Foundation and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office Wellington are hosting an evening of stories and insights from New Zealanders who have studied, worked and lived in Taiwan. Hear from the Foundation's Leadership Network members and Taiwan alumni as they share their experiences and reflect on future opportunities for Kiwis in Taiwan.
Our Asia After Five events are interactive. You will have a chance to ask questions, network with others and learn more about Asia.
Event details
Date:  Thursday 25 September 2025
Time:  5:30pm-7:00pm
Venue:  Asia New Zealand Foundation, Level 16, Fujitsu Tower, 141 The Terrace (access to building via Cable Car Lane before 6pm)
This event is free to attend, but please RSVP for catering purposes.
This event is a collaboration between the Asia New Zealand Foundation Te Whītau Tūhono and Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New Zealand (TECO).
Our speakers
Ema Kato
Ema Kato is a recent graduate from Victoria University of Wellington with a degree in Communication, specialising in intercultural communication and Mandarin. Having lived in Japan, Taiwan and New Zealand, Ema is passionate about cross-cultural exchange and will return to Taiwan next year to pursue advanced language study and a master’s program at National Taiwan University with the Huayu and Taiwan Scholarships.
Tom Durkin
Tom is currently based in Auckland, working in Private Wealth at Craigs Investment Partners. Having studied Mandarin as a part of his degree at the University of Otago, he has long held an interest in Chinese language and culture. Tom spent two months travelling in Taiwan at the end of 2023. During this time, he joined parts of the Taipei Hui with the Asia New Zealand Foundation Leadership Network, worked with a farmer in Chiayi and spent two weeks at Fo Guang Shan Buddhist monastery in Southern Taiwan. His participation in the recent Shanghai Hui with the Asia New Zealand Leadership Network sparked a desire to re-engage and immerse in Chinese culture. Tom has recently been accepted to study at the National Taiwan Normal University - Mandarin Training Center from later this year. He's looking forward to sharing his experiences and hearing more on others' perspectives of the New Zealand-Taiwan relationship.
Lauren Pattermore
Lauren Pattemore is an early-career journalist based in New Zealand, with contributions to Stuff, the Otago Daily Times, Crux and Radio New Zealand. She recently completed a media internship with the Asia New Zealand Foundation in Taipei, working with TaiwanPlus. In 2024, she was named runner-up for Best Up and Coming Journalist at the Voyager Media Awards. She holds a Bachelor of Communication from Massey University, where she specialised in expressive arts and journalism.
Rob Eland
Rob was the sole New Zealand recipient of the Taipei City Chinese Learning Scholarship in 2018, selected by Mayor Justin Lester. With the scholarship, he took a sabbatical from work and travelled to Taipei, where he lived from mid-2018 to early 2019. During this time, Rob studied full-immersion Chinese at NTNU's Mandarin Training Center (MTC) and took part in several New Zealand–Taiwan cross-cultural activities, including supporting then-Deputy Mayor Jill Day and a group of New Zealand performing arts students during their visit to Taiwan. Rob returned to New Zealand in 2019, but he looks forward to heading back to Taiwan again soon.

description:
FRUIT LOOP FESTIVAL, Fruit Loop Festival
Marlborough’s freshest music festival!
About the Festival
Fruit Loop Festival is Marlborough’s juiciest new summer gig! A full-blown celebration of music and dance, kicking off under the sun and well into the night. Think open-air energy - blending Marlborough's summer magic with a full-scale music festival. An insane line-up of DJs and live performers with production to match! From the first drop to the final track, it's where the beat hits harder and the drinks taste sweeter.
Fresh, wild, fierce - Fruit Loop is the party Marlborough has been waiting for.
The Line-Up
DICK JOHNSON: The heart of NZ’s electronic scene, Dick Johnson is a true house music heavyweight. With remixes for global icons like Fatboy Slim and Claude VonStroke, plus Kiwi favourites L.A.B and Tiki Taane, he’s spent over two decades electrifying dancefloors worldwide. A relentless force behind the decks - and music director for Synthony - Dick brings the fire every time.
SIN: Co-host of George FM Drive, Sin is plugged into the pulse of the dance scene and has quickly become a revered authority on all things electronica. She’s torn up stages at Rhythm & Vines, Homegrown, Hidden Valley, and international festivals from Fiji to the UK. With supports for legends like Fatboy Slim, Groove Armada, and Netsky, Sin brings high-energy house, techno, and ravey curveballs to every set.
KITA MEAN: Kita Mean is New Zealand’s award-winning drag superstar, known for her infectious charm, razor-sharp wit, and high-camp aesthetic. With a career spanning 15+ years across stages and screens worldwide, she’s wowed audiences from Aotearoa and Australia to London, Canada, the USA, and beyond. Winner of the very first RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under and co-owner of the iconic Caluzzi Cabaret, Kita continues to dazzle with colourful looks, flawless mug, and hilarious timing. Quirky, kooky, kitsch, and quick - Kita Mean isn’t just a queen, she’s an experience.
PETE GREEN: Originally from the UK, Pete is part of the vinyl-digging collective Rare Specimens. His love for deep, worldly electronic sounds brings low-end warmth and an infectious energy to the dancefloor. Along the way, he’s supported artists such as Crazy P, Psychemagik, Audio Jack, and Christopher Tubbs, playing festivals and parties from Creamfields and Rhythm & Alps to Tempo Schmempo. Expect a set seasoned with Italo, ambient, and deep house flavours, dusted with disco, and finished with a splash of techno.
Event Details
Date: Saturday 28 March 2026
Time: 2pm - 10pm
Location: The Fancy Cow, Marlborough
R18 event - Photo identification will be required.
Return Bus Service:
Getting to and from the festival is easy with our return bus service. Pick-up points will include Redwoodtown Woolworths, Seymour Square, and Countdown Springlands. Purchase a return bus ticket when you nab your ticket.
A full timetable and bus information will be announced closer to the event.
Parking is strictly limited at the festival. Drop off recommended.
Tickets
Tickets are limited — don’t wait. Secure yours now!
Door sales may be available.
Have your ticket open and ready to be scanned at the gate.
Kaupapa
Fruit Loop is a safe, inclusive space where everyone belongs. If you can’t celebrate diversity, respect others, and bring good vibes, this festival isn’t for you.
Harassment or discrimination of any kind will not be tolerated. Anyone behaving this way will be removed.
Refunds and Cancellations
Fruit Loop Festival is a rain or shine event. The festival will proceed regardless of weather conditions, except in circumstances where safety is compromised or conditions make it impossible for the event to continue.
No refunds will be given for changes to the programme, line-up, or advertised performers.
Stay Connected
Follow us for line-up drops, updates and key event information: @fruitloopfestival on Instagram

description:
Film screening: GAGA, Film screening: GAGA
Join us for a special screening of the 2022 Taiwanese comedy-drama film GAGA, featuring a Q&A with the award-winning Director, Laha Mebow

About this Event

Gaga《哈勇家》(2022)
Directed by Laha Mebow 112 mins, Mandarin/Atayal/Taiwanese, English subtitles
Among the Atayal indigenous people of Taiwan, gaga is the traditional law and custom, the way of living with the land and organising society, the source of values. When Hayung, the patriarch of an Atayal family, and the senior knowledge-keeper, dies, his oldest son Payang decides to run for election as head of the local district. The film Gaga follows this election, in its raw democratic, and occasionally corrupt, form and the ways – sometimes serious, sometimes hilarious – that it affects the extended family. A groundbreaking film, Gaga is mostly in Atayal language and presents the life and social interactions of these contemporary indigenous Taiwanese people unsentimentally, with humour, with compassion, and with the sharp eye of a brilliant film-maker.
Gaga won Best Director and Best Supporting Actress at the 59th Taipei Golden Horse Film Festival in 2022. Beyond Taiwan, it won the Best Director at the 2022 Singapore International Film Festival - Asian Feature Competition and has been screened at film festivals in Hawaii, Los Angeles, Melbourne, Auckland and New York.

Q&A with Film Director Laha Mebow
We are delighted that Film Director Laha Mebow, Taiwan's first indigenous female director, will be attending the screening and take part in Q&A afterwards.


Laha Mebow is the first female director from Taiwan to win Best Director at the Golden Horse Awards, the most prestigious film award in the Chinese-speaking world. An Indigenous filmmaker of the Tayal people, she is also the first Indigenous woman in Taiwan to direct a narrative feature. Her films explore spiritual inheritance, family trauma, and Indigenous identity through a deeply personal yet cinematic lens.
She has directed three feature films. Finding Sayun (2011) reimagines a colonial-era legend from an Indigenous perspective. Lokah Laqi! (2016), a coming-of-age tale of three Indigenous boys, was selected as Taiwan’s official submission for Best Foreign Language Film at the Academy Awards. Her third feature, Gaga (2022), won Best Film at the Singapore International Film Festival and delves into generational shifts and cultural survival within an Indigenous family.
Laha’s body of work continues to break new ground for Indigenous representation in Asian cinema. Her unique voice bridges traditional storytelling and contemporary filmmaking, making her one of the most important and anticipated directors from Taiwan today.

https://cdn-az.allevents.in/events10/banners/8cd1bb10-7456-11f0-994e-1dce379af11a-rimg-w570-h740-dc090807-gmir.jpg

Entry is free and the opportunity to walk away with glory is priceless. An independent jury will be awarding prizes for "best riding" and "most creative edit" and we'll be running a "people's choice" award as well. Prizes will be announced on the night 🎁

description:
24-hour Squash Marathon for Wayne, 24 Hours on Court for Wayne.
This time I’m picking up my squash racket for a challenge like no other: 24 hours of nonstop squash. Why? Because someone I care for has been facing a far tougher battle.
My father-in-law was recently diagnosed with Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). For years he lived undiagnosed, pushing through symptoms without answers. Now that we finally know what he’s fighting, I want to turn my energy into something that can help him—and others—on their journeys.
According to CLL Advocates NZ, only 10-15 people out of 250 on average per year benefit from the budget allocation. And many are not even able to receive the same treatment options here in NZ.
Squash has always been a sport of endurance, resilience, and determination. Playing for 24 hours is my way of honoring his fight, raising awareness, and bringing people together to support the cause.
You can help by:
Donating: Any amount you would like to.
Predicting: Predicting how many points and games will be played in 24 hours.
Joining me on court: Book a slot to play a game, cheer from the sidelines, or come be part of the atmosphere.
Buy raffle tickets, or sponsor a prize towards the raffle.
We would like to give a shout out to our current sponsors;
Hair Phoria,
Aimee Photography,
X-Potential,
Mitchells,
Meaters,
CBD Eatery,
Forrest Wines and
Fat Tony's
No matter how small, your contribution will make a difference. Together we can transform his story of late diagnosis into one of community, awareness, and action.
I’ll be pushing myself through the night, but I won’t be alone—your support will keep me going with every serve, rally, and game. Let’s make this 24 hours count.

description:
Heritage Festival Open Days, Heritage Festival Open Days
Join us for an open day in the bell tower of Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, where you can uncover its unique history and see the bellringers come out to play.

Take a tour through our ringing chamber and belfry, and see our 140-year-old bells up close. You will have a chance to watch the ringers in action, and maybe even have a go at chiming our 1500kg tenor bell, the largest swinging bell in New Zealand! Discover the secret world of bells and bellringing, something the public doesn't normally get to see. You may have never known that people are pulling on the ropes to make the bells ring! *One of the few towers in the world accessible by lift!

**Entry by donation**

Health & Safety
Please be aware that touching the bell ropes and access to the bells outside of the designated viewing areas is strictly prohibited. You will only be permitted to handle a bell rope under the guidance and supervision of a bellringer. Hearing protection is not required in the ringing chamber, but earmuffs will be provided whilst in the belfry viewing gallery if the bells are going to be rung.

Location
James Thomas Bell Tower, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, 2 Hill Street, Thorndon 6011

The Annual Hutt Valley Diwali, organised by the Wellington Punjabi Sports and Cultural Club Inc. (WPSCC Inc.), is a vibrant, family-friendly celebration of light, culture, and community. Held each year in the heart of the Hutt Valley, this non-profit event brings together people of all ages and backgrounds to enjoy the rich traditions of Diwali.

The festival features a colourful mix of cultural performances, traditional and modern music and dance, delicious food, local art and craft stalls, and engaging activities for children and families. It offers a unique opportunity to experience the diverse cultures that make up our region while celebrating the universal values of light over darkness, hope, and togetherness.

WPSCC Inc. proudly hosts this event to promote unity, cultural understanding, and community spirit in the Hutt Valley and beyond.

description:
Eastbourne Garden Show, Step into a world of six acclaimed private gardens each a living canvas of colour, design and inspiration from lush natives to sculpted landscapes. Each garden tells a story and provides a visual image of wonderful creations.
One garden, allegedly with the best vista, has not been opened to the public before. One garden has previously featured in the House and Garden magazine. The tour (self-guided) will begin with lunch and an opportunity to buy potted plants in the tranquil St Alban's church garden, 11 Ngaio St Eastbourne, Lower Hutt, Wellington. The tour will end with hors d'oeuvre, wine and live music in the last garden.
This is a chance not just to visit amazing gardens but support the earthquake strengthening of St Alban's historic church and hall for a rejuvenated community hub.
St Albans church garden
The six private gardens all lie within a less than 100 m walk of the 83 Metlink Marine Parade bus route, but a car or bicycle would be more convenient.
A glimpse of the six separate gardens (a-e).
a
a
b
c
d
e
f
f
The garden show is in support of earthquake strengthening of the de Jersey Clere designed St Alban's church and adjacent hall to remake this a community hub.
For the last hundred years and more, this beautiful church designed by acclaimed architect Frederick de Jersey Clere has been the heart of Anglican parish life for people in the eastern bays of Wellington. People have rejoiced, prayed and wept in it through happy family milestones and sad occasions, through two world wars and countless celebrations and crises. Along with its parish hall and tranquil garden, it has been the base for social and community services and outreach, and its memorial wall houses the ashes of local residents.
But in 2016 the congregation had to suddenly leave the church, which was deemed an earthquake risk.
Since then, the parish has explored alternatives for continuing its life and service to the people of the eastern bays. In that process it has kept its ministry and worship going through borrowed premises in local schools and other churches. Now, however, the parish has decided it needs to go back to its original base and strengthen both St Alban’s Church and the parish hall so it can continue to serve the community from its heart and home in Ngaio Street, for the next hundred years and more.
Detailed plans for strengthening the church and hall to meet acceptable safety standards have been drawn up, and fund-raising is under way. The parish is a registered charity (CC22188) and tax-deductible receipts will be issued for all donations.
Postponement by 1 day to 30 Nov if weather were to dictate and would be announced on this web site.

description:
Celebrate the Fabric, Exquisite pieces of needlework are on display and in use every day at Wellington Cathedral of
St Paul: beautifully decorated fabrics that hang at the front of the altars, spectacular robes and
stoles worn by priests at services, and fine linens used at every service of Holy Communion.

You’ll learn much about this remarkable fabric artistry when Jo Dixey talks to the Friends of
Wellington Cathedral of St Paul and guests on Wednesday, 24 September at 10.30 am.
Jo is an internationally regarded professional embroiderer who graduated from the Royal
School of Needlework and now lives permanently in New Zealand. She teaches, exhibits and sells
her work, as well as accepting commissions from churches, fashion designers and private
individuals. She has also had contracts from the film industry, working on the Disney film Mulan
and most recently on season 1 of Lord of the Rings TV series. Jo’s collection of embroidered
3D viruses, created during the 2020 Covid lockdown, are now on display in The Museum of
New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa.

Venue: Loaves and Fishes Hall, Wellington Cathedral of St Paul.

description:
Paraparaumu Makeup Masterclass - 1.11 @9.15 am, About this event
Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.
As we journey through life, our skin and style evolve. The best way to update your look and learn techniques that suit your unique face shape, style, and colouring is to attend one of our masterclasses. Whether you're a performer on stage, a busy professional, or a multitasking mum, this class will teach you how to apply your makeup quickly, flawlessly, and with confidence.
During the class, Nikki will demonstrate step-by-step techniques on a model while you get to apply your own makeup. You'll have access to professional products and tools to follow along and create your flawless everyday look. It’s fun, interactive, and designed for all skill levels.
"I can’t wait to share my knowledge with you and help you create a makeup routine that leaves you feeling fabulous and confident every day!" – Nikki
What You Need to Know:
No equipment required! We’ll provide all makeup products, brushes, and mirrors.
Bring a willingness to learn and a positive attitude.
Classes are capped at 12-15 participants to ensure personalised guidance.
Arrive 10–15 minutes early to get settled.
Please come with a clean, makeup-free face so you can get the best results.

description:
NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash, NZ Brewers Fest - Monster Mash
🦇A Day of Decadence, Darkness and Delights 🕷️

Join us from midday until the shadows stretch long, as Brewtown transforms into a haunted haven of unholy delights for NZ Brewers Fest 2025 – Monster Mash!

🍻Fiendishly good Beer!
It wouldn’t be NZBF without great beer, and this year 20 of Aotearoa’s best breweries will descend on Brewtown to pour every style you could possibly desire, from crisp Lagers, cold IPAs and hoppy Pale Ales, to funky Sours, smoky Porters, rich Pastry Stouts – and everything in between!

Visit Brewtown’s own custom Unimog Bar for 13 beers handpicked by our craft beer experts, but get in quick – we only have 1 keg of each, and they won’t last long!

🍸Haunting Spirits & Wine!
New for this year! Step into our haunted cocktail bar for some seriously spooky spirits! Our mixologists have been hard at work creating some devilishly delicious drops just for you.

We’re bringing in some of the best wines the Wairarapa has to offer, so whether you prefer a crisp Sauv, a fruity Pinot or a refreshing Frosé there will be something to enjoy.

Still not enough for you? Then head down to the Everything Else Bar, for NZ crafted ciders, as well as bourbon, rum, gin and vodka alongside a range of low and no alcohol beers, cocktails and soft drinks.

🌮Monstrously Good Kai!
The NZBF food court hosts the region’s top foodies, bringing you big, bold, flavour-packed festival eats that’ll satisfy both the living and the undead.
Watch this space as we announce our festive foodie lineup!

⚔️Enthralling Entertainment!
Lose yourself in a cabaret of the bizarre, where the performances are as dark as they are dazzling. Expect sultry burlesque, twisted characters and moments that will thrill, chill, and have you begging for more.

Witness the brutal thrill of buhurt armoured combat, as warriors face off in full medieval kit in a raw display of might and mayhem.

Dance the day away at the main stage, as Welly’s top talent smash out tune after tune, all building up to a headline show from Brewtown favourites, The Blueprint – as they bring a special set just for Monster Mash! Trust us, you haven’t seen them like this before…

Grab your mates and get stuck in at the Games Zone, where a bit of friendly rivalry meets festive fun, and the loser buys the next round.

Enjoy dressing up? Go all out in your most terrifying, theatrical or jaw-dropping costume — and you might just take out the crown in our epic Best Dressed Competition, with spooky-good prizes up for grabs.

With affordable return coaches from Welly and Petone and great discounts for group tickets it's scarily easy to get involved!
🎃 R18

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Award Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!


Footprints on Katmai (22 mins) Max Romey, USA. Following his grandmother's footsteps to one
of the most remote and bear-strewn beaches in Alaska, painter Max Romey discovers that an
ocean of problems is closer to home than he could have imagined. BEST FILM ON THE ENVIRONMENT
Alone Across Gola (20 mins) Jude Kriwald, UK, NZ Premiere. Stranded in Liberia’s Gola
rainforest, filmmaker Jude Kriwald faces hunger, isolation, robbery and disappearing trails. A raw
tale of one man’s solo, self-filmed journey chasing a childhood dream. With only a bike and a
tent, Jude pushes the limits of survival and self-discovery. BEST ADVENTUROUS SPORTS & LIFESTYLES
Zahir (36 mins) Julien Nadiras, Switzerland, subtitles. Katherine and Eline take on an iconic rock
route, accessing it by bike. Their all-eco ascent tests endurance, nerve, and friendship, with long
runouts and tiny holds pushing them to the edge.
Body of a Line (10 mins) Henna Taylor, subtitles, USA. A cleverly animated short film that
morphs into real life as Madaleine undertakes an intimate and creative journey to climb a difficult
rock route, with original music and poetry. BEST SHORT FILM
Trango (46 mins) Leo Hoorn, USA. After a two-year attempt, ski mountaineers ski the first
descent of the Great Trango Glacier. They navigate risk, grapple with grief, and face physical
danger as they push the limits of human experience. Unspoken trust and support within their
expedition team allows them to face the unimaginable together. GRAND PRIZE FILM


Total running time: 120 minutes + 15 minute intermission.
label: Festivals

description:
NZ Drum & Dance Camp, NZ Drum & Dance Camp
Join us this 24th to 27th October for a West African musical immersion at our annual NZ Drum Dance Camp.

Set amidst 38 acres of native bushland just a short drive from Wellington, this weekend is a celebration of unity, rhythm, and the soul-stirring power of African drum and dance, curated for the NZ African drumming community.

We are excited to announce that Epizo Bangoura will be back to join us again in 2025!

Epizo Bangoura is a celebrated master musician from Guinea, West Africa, known for his extraordinary versatility on the Kora (African harp), Balafon (African tuned percussion), and Djembe/Duns.

Epizo will be joined by Ghanaian Master Drummer Yaw Asumadu and special guest Jimi Dale.

Camp Highlights:

♪ Djembe and Dunun Workshops: Suitable for all skill levels, from enthusiastic beginners to advanced drummers, guided by our awesome team of teachers.
♪ Traditional Dance: with the effervescent Epizo Bangoura.
♪ Group Jams and Musical Sessions: Strengthen communal bonds through captivating group jams and impromptu musical sessions.
♪ Tranquil Setting: Enjoy the native bushland environ - build mind, body and spirit whilst enhancing our weekend of music and togetherness.
♪ Catering – Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included on Saturday and Sunday, as well as breakfast Monday. Please bring a shared (pre-prepared) plate for Friday evening kai.

Featured Instructors:

Epizo Bangoura: A master of the djembe and traditional dance, Epizo brings profound knowledge and vibrant energy, embodying the essence of West African music and dance.

Yaw Asumadu: A Master Drummer from Ghana, Yaw has performed globally and taught African drumming for 25 years, collaborating with legendary artists.

Jimi Dale: A pioneer of African music in NZ, Jimi has been teaching African Drum and Dance classes since 1995 and formed the world music and dance group, Tamani. We are excited to have Jimi back again teaching us a dun dance piece.

Pricing Details:
♪ Early Bird: $450 (Reserve by Sunday 31st August 2025)
♪ Adult rate: $495
♪ Kids 9 – 14 years old: $250
♪ Kids 8 and under: $175
♪ Family Packages available on request
♪ Single Day & night $220 (includes 3 meals and full day tuition)
♪ Drum Hire: $15

Event Schedule Snapshot:
♪ Friday, 24th October: Arrive from 4pm - A warm welcome sets the stage for a weekend filled with rhythm and learning.
Bring a share plate for dinner.
♪ Saturday, 25th October: Engage in enriching drum and dance workshops. Participants will be grouped into their appropriate levels.
♪ Sunday, 26th October: Continue your musical journey with drum and dance sessions, leading to a group performance that encapsulates the weekend’s shared experiences.
♪ Monday, 27th October: Morning All in Drum & Dance ceremony, then it's time to hit the road.

FAQs
♪ Getting Ready: Bring your drum (if available), snacks for the weekend, dance-appropriate shoes, sleeping gear (pillowcase & sheet, sleeping bag/ doona), warm clothes, and an eager spirit.
♪ Beginners are warmly welcomed – our camp is a nurturing space for newcomers to discover the joy of African drumming and dance, bolstered by a supportive community.

For more information and tickets -
https://africandrumming.co.nz/tours-and-retreats/nz-drum-dance-camp/

More questions?
Contact - Tulletha at or call: 028 474 1123

description:
Kaiwhakaataata Māra | Garden Performers, Kaiwhakaataata Māra | Garden Performers
Keep your eyes and ears open for pop-up performances scattered across two of Wellington’s most beautiful gardens. Talented artists will appear spontaneously as you wander through Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush and the Botanic Garden ki Paekākā, bringing music, storytelling, and theatre to life in unexpected places for Te Wā o te Kōanga, Spring Festival 2025.


Botanic Garden ki Paekākā - Love Birds
Brought to you by the Shakespeare Globe Centre New Zealand
Join us at Puriri Lawn for interactive readings celebrating Shakespeare and spring at 11:30am and 2:30pm, with roaming performers delighting visitors in between.

Come dressed to impress for our bird costume competition, with judging at 12pm and 3pm following the readings. Feathers, colours, and creativity encouraged!


Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush - Meet the Moa
With String Bean Puppets
Come meet Nunu, the friendly moa puppet! Nunu will be roaming the garden during two special sessions: 11:00–11:45am and 12:15–1:00pm. Feed him some leaves, give him a cuddle, and enjoy this fun, interactive experience bringing Wellington’s prehistoric past to life.


This event is part of the Wellington Gardens Te Wā o te Kōanga - Spring Festival 2025. Join us in celebrating spring with free events throughout September. Full line-up on our website.

description:
Mental Health Awareness Week at The Gallery Tattoo, Taking care of your mental health and expressing yourself through art and body modification often go hand in hand, so this year we are fundraising all Mental Health Awareness Week to help bring awareness to something that affects so many people in Aotearoa.

If you want to help us support this very worthy cause but you can’t make it to the studio between October 6th and 12th, you can make a donation directly to our MHAW fundraising page through a QR code that will be available on our instagram and facebook pages from Monday October 6th. The fundraising page will be up all week.
There will also be a donation box in the studio if you want to come in and say hi.

What’s happening:

Tuesday 7th - 5% of proceeds go to MHAW

Wednesday 8th - 5% of proceeds go to MHAW

Thursday 9th - 5% of proceeds go to MHAW

Friday 10th - 20% off all scar cover ups or incorporations - Bookings essential.
Consultations must be booked before September 30th

Saturday 11th - 20% off all scar cover ups or incorporations - Bookings essential
Consultations must be booked before September 30th

Sunday 12th - ‘All you can handle’ lucky dip flash day.
How much can you take in one 3 hour sitting?
No breaks, no stopping, no moving. A race against the clock.
Bookings essential & full payment on booking.
Bookings must be made before September 30th
All proceeds go to MHAW
Email info@thegallerytattooart for more details and to book a spot

description:
POP Go the Festival Singers: Island Bay Presbyterian Church, The Festival Singers invite you to a enjoy unforgettable music in POP go the Festival Singers – a dazzling celebration of popular songs from the 1920s right through to today. Expect energy, variety, and entertainment as we journey through swing, rock ’n’ roll, Motown, disco, soft rock, and contemporary pop.
The programme sparkles with classics and favourites: a Beach Boys Medley full of surfside sunshine, Ruru Karaitiana’s iconic Blue Smoke, Elvis Presley’s Hound Dog, and Bobby Darin’s Beyond the Sea. We’ll groove with Pharrell Williams’ Happy, cheer to Survivor’s Eye of the Tiger, and celebrate Kiwi pride in Crowded House’s Weather with You. Heartfelt beauty shines through Simon and Garfunkel’s Bridge Over Troubled Water and Billy Joel’s And So It Goes, while fun abounds with The Lion Sleeps Tonight and Gershwin’s sultry Summertime.
Swing makes its mark with Glenn Miller’s Chattanooga Choo Choo and In the Mood, while a rousing Queen Medley and an exuberant ABBA Medley bring the concert to a thrilling close. Along the way, enjoy contemporary sparkle with Dua Lipa’s Levitating and the timeless artistry of these unforgettable hits.
With the incomparable Jonathan Berkahn at the piano, every piece shines with character and style. This concert promises nostalgia, joy, and toe-tapping fun – a true trip down memory lane with something for everyone.
Join us and be part of a celebration of music that entertains, connects, and uplifts.
label: Festivals

description:
NZ Mountain Film Festival 2025 - Pure NZ Night, A collection of New Zealand-made mountain films - brought to you by the Vic Uni Tramping Club, Wellington Tramping and Mountaineering Club, and of course the New Zealand Mountain Film and Book Festival!


Pedals To Powder (28 mins) Nick Kowalski, NZ. Two women cycle to every ski field in Aotearoa
in one wild season, braving storms and exhaustion—uncovering a hidden world of independent
ski culture along the way.
All in or Nothing (24 mins) Gordon Duff, NZ. Up against 120 riders with full support crews, a
young athlete only has himself to rely on. Follow his gruelling six days as he attempts to win the
overall title at the NZ MTB Rally. BEST DOCUMENTARY
Riverbound - The Storybook Has Just Begun (13 mins) Dylan Gerschwitz & Deane Parker,
NZ, World Premiere. Yak, a former pro kayaker now paraplegic, takes on Class 3 rapids in the
Upper Buller Gorge. Can packrafting restore his freedom—and redefine who gets to run wild
rivers? FESTIVAL SPIRIT AWARD
As One - The MHS Adventure Racing Team (15 mins) Louie Burger, NZ, World Premiere.
This uplifting documentary follows nine Motueka High students on a wild, 40-hour adventure
racing from the West Coast home—raising funds for World Vision with grit, laughs, and heart.
Spirit of the West (12 mins) Pedro Pimentel, NZ, World Premiere. Set against New Zealand’s
wild West Coast, this film captures the spirit of the Old Ghost Ultra—where community, resilience,
and grit collide in a transformative celebration of people and place. COMMUNITY SPIRIT
AWARD
Rakiura Solo (13 mins) Michael Beckmann, NZ. A tough solo hike around the 130km North West
Circuit on Stewart Island/Rakiura. Beyond the challenge, what makes this island truly special is
its rich wildlife. An ambient film without dialogue.
Waiatoto (20 mins) Josh Morgan & Jasper Gibson, NZ. This film tells the story of a traverse
across the Southern Alps through packraft, skis and tramping. Starting at the Matukituki, the route
went via Tititea, the Volta Glacier, and the Waiatoto, to the Tasman Sea. BEST NZ MADE FILM


Total running time: 125 minutes + 15 minute intermission.

description:
Newtown Festival 2026, Rātapu, Tuawaru o Poutū-te-rangi
Waiata | Kai | Ahurea | Mahi Toi
Aotearoa’s biggest and best free music festival and street fair returns for its 32nd year! A shining calendar highlight, Te Whanganui-a-Tara’s most colourful suburb invites everyone to come along to their favourite street party. From dawn to dusk, the streets are packed with people of all ages, stages, backgrounds, cultures, locals, visitors, whānau and friends. The beloved Newtown Festival brings you more than 420 stalls, 200 artists, 1000 performers, 16 stages, and heaps of activities for the whole whānau. Join us in a celebration with a mass concentration and extravaganza of local cultural identity, creative expression, and a day of community togetherness and joy.

The 2025 theme for Papua New Guinea Pidgin Language Week is 'Lukautim, strongim na kirapim tokples na pasin blo tubuna - Preserve, revitalise and promote our language and culture'.

You are invited to join the formal flag raising ceremony, at the Performing Arts Centre inside Pātaka Art + Museum.

There will be morning tea and refreshments following the ceremony.

Intro to Self Defence Workshop, Our Intro to Self Defence workshop is designed for anyone who wants to learn effective defensive skills and escapes from grabs and holds.
Our Intro to Self Defence workshop is designed for anyone who wants to learn effective escapes from grabs and holds as well as simple self defence skills that could save your life.
We encourage parents and children to do this workshop together so you can reinforce the learning at home. You get to benefit from the skills Sensei Patricia has gained from over 40 years training in karate delivered to you in a fun package!
You will learn how to:
- Stay safe
- Build awareness and confidence
- Defend yourself effectively
Cost: $29
NOTE: Family concessions available on request to patricia@familyfitkarate.co.nz. Ask about our gift vouchers for our Self Defence workshops and Karate memberships.
Time: 12:15PM to 3:15PM.
Venue: Brooklyn Community Centre Hall, 18 Harrison St, Brooklyn

description:
Rathkeale College Christmas Fête 2025, Rathkeale College Christmas Fête 2025
Welcome to the Rathkeale Christmas Fête 2025!
Now in its 22nd year, the Fête offers shoppers loads of inspiration. Stallholders will be selling festive decorations, clothing, arts and crafts, as well as flowers, toys and plants – there is something for everyone.
Gourmet food is also a highlight – with freshly made gourmet burgers, lamb & mint sausages, wraps, curry, salads, and the ever-popular berries and icecream available for purchase. Devonshire Tea served in the Rathkeale Homestead rose garden is a time-honoured tradition while refreshing cold drinks can be sipped on as visitors listen to live music performed by students at various times throughout the day. The popular home baking stall features again this year, and visitors are encouraged to get in early as the Christmas cakes, in particular, often sell out by midday.
The beauty of this Fête is it is a day out for the whole family. In addition to the 120 plus indoor and outdoor stalls, there is plenty to entertain the children with face painting and three magic shows during the day to round out the fun.
Visitors can meander around the beautiful campus and enjoy the unique surroundings including the school gardens designed by Alfred Buxton, the Greek Amphitheatre and the 3km eco-trail which weaves through large stands of native trees, including ancient kahikatea.
The Christmas Fête is the school’s biggest fundraiser of the year and comes about thanks to an amazing collaboration between the Friends of Rathkeale College, staff and students.
Koha/gold coin entry
Eftpos available but we strongly recommend bringing cash.
More information: https://rathkeale.school.nz/community/#friends-of-rathkeale

description:
Rave to the Grave - Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS and RadioActive.FM, 30+ DJs - 3 Stages - 1 Fundraiser

Two epic Wellington institutions – BATS Theatre and RadioActive.FM – are teaming up this Halloween to deliver an unforgettable night of music, energy, and community spirit, all while raising essential funds to keep these local legends alive.

Rave to the Grave – Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS Theatre and RadioActive.FM will transform the Kent Tce into a pumping, all-night celebration on Halloween night. With three unique dance spaces across all of BATS’ venues, ravers can choose their vibe, from blissed-out chill, to deep grooves, to high-energy bass.

TICKETS ARE STRICTLY LIMITED SO BE QUICK!

VIP tickets include a free drink and snack on arrival, plus a mystery goodie bag!
More than 30 RadioActive.FM DJs will be behind the decks, from all your favourite shows, including The Jewel School, Midnight Marauders, The Floor, Homebass, The Session, and more!
Following the resounding success of last year’s fundraiser, Flight of Fancy – BATS Turns 35, hailed as one of the city’s most exhilarating parties, the need for ongoing community support remains critical.

That event raised significant funds for the theatre, highlighting the essential role Wellingtonians play in sustaining the city’s arts and music scene.

Both BATS and RadioActive.FM, as charitable organisations, must continually raise funds to keep their doors open and their creative voices alive, ensuring that audiences can continue to enjoy bold, independent theatre and iconic local broadcasting.
label: Festivals

description:
Rathkeale Christmas Fete 2025, Welcome to the Rathkeale Christmas Fête 2025! Walk through the gates of Rathkeale College on 1st November and be welcomed by a diverse range of colourful stalls, the aroma of freshy cooked food and plenty of festive inspiration.

Now in its 22nd year, the Christmas Fête has become a must-do event on the Wairarapa spring calendar. Stallholders travel from around the North Island to sell their wares and offer Christmas shoppers loads of inspiration. From festive decorations, clothing, arts and crafts, to flowers, toys and plants – there is something for everyone.

Gourmet food is always a highlight at the Fête - think freshly made gourmet burgers, lamb & mint sausages, wraps, curry, salads, and the ever-popular berries & ice-cream - there is always a huge variety of flavours to tempt the taste buds. Devonshire Teas and home baking served in the Rathkeale Homestead rose garden is a time-honoured tradition while refreshing cold drinks can be sipped on as visitors listen to live music performed by students at various times throughout the day. The popular Christmas cake stall features again this year - but visitors are encouraged to get in early as the cakes often sell out by midday.

The beauty of this Fête is that it’s a day out for the whole family. In addition to the 120 plus stalls, there is plenty to entertain the children including facepainting and magic shows throughout the day.

Visitors can also explore the beautiful, expansive grounds of Rathkeale College including the school gardens designed by Alfred Buxton, the Greek Amphitheatre and the 3km eco-trail which weaves through large stands of native trees, including ancient kahikatea.

Eftpos is available, but we strongly recommend that visitors bring cash.

Koha/gold coin entry.
Rathkeale College is a five-minute drive north of Masterton in the Wairarapa.
label: Festivals

description:
Dance with Janni - 21 September, Dance with Janni - 21 September
Dance with Janni is part free form dance and part relaxation. The ritual of dance promotes creative self-expression, has some great health benefits and is for everyone to enjoy.This is a safe and inclusive space to move and dance while having the opportunity to relax, stretch and be your true self.There are no steps to learn, instead there will be minimal guidance to help you during the session.Bring water, a small blanket, socks or dance barefoot and wear comfy clothes move in. Come as you are and as you feel.This initiative has the support of Creative Communities NZ.Koha appreciated.

description:
Foxton | Food Lovers Masterclass, Foxton | Food Lovers Masterclass
Come along and learn about why we waste food and how to stop it. There will be a few face-palm moments and lots of laughs as Kate takes you through the reasons we waste food and what we can do about it.

This is a fun but informative session and you will leave inspired with a cool goodie bag full of samples to get you started.

VIP Ticket price - $10, get a goodie bag worth $40
FREE Ticket - No Goodie Bag included

description:
Round The Vines 2025, Round The Vines 2025
Join us for Martinborough School’s iconic fundraiser fun run & walk through scenic vineyards!

Date: 1st November 2025

Location: Martinborough, New Zealand

Distances: 10 km Run or Walk | 21 km Run or Walk

Bring your friends and family for a 10 or 21km fun run or walk around vineyards that are only open to the public for Round The Vines 2025.

Wear your best activewear or fancy dress and enjoy the live music and themed hydration stations dotted around the course. Then head to the prize-giving for delicious food & wines, live entertainment and amazing prizes generously donated by local businesses.

Stay the weekend for great eateries, cellar doors, boutique shopping and more!

New course for 2025
We are planning a new course for 2025 that will take you through vineyards never seen by the public before! Keep an eye out for the new course map coming soon.

Visit our website for more information and to register: www.roundthevines.org.nz

📸 Follow us for the latest updates and share your Round the Vines moments using #RoundTheVines

#RTV2025 #RoundTheVines #MartinboroughRTV #FunRun #MartinboroughSchool #VineyardRun

description:
Rave to the Grave - Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS and RadioActive.FM, 30+ DJs - 3 Stages - 1 Fundraiser

Two epic Wellington institutions – BATS Theatre and RadioActive.FM – are teaming up this Halloween to deliver an unforgettable night of music, energy, and community spirit, all while raising essential funds to keep these local legends alive.

Rave to the Grave – Fund-Raise the Dead for BATS Theatre and RadioActive.FM will transform the Kent Tce into a pumping, all-night celebration on Halloween night. With three unique dance spaces across all of BATS’ venues, ravers can choose their vibe, from blissed-out chill, to deep grooves, to high-energy bass.

TICKETS ARE STRICTLY LIMITED SO BE QUICK!

VIP tickets include a free drink and snack on arrival, plus a mystery goodie bag!
More than 30 RadioActive.FM DJs will be behind the decks, from all your favourite shows, including The Jewel School, Midnight Marauders, The Floor, Homebass, The Session, and more!
Following the resounding success of last year’s fundraiser, Flight of Fancy – BATS Turns 35, hailed as one of the city’s most exhilarating parties, the need for ongoing community support remains critical.

That event raised significant funds for the theatre, highlighting the essential role Wellingtonians play in sustaining the city’s arts and music scene.

Both BATS and RadioActive.FM, as charitable organisations, must continually raise funds to keep their doors open and their creative voices alive, ensuring that audiences can continue to enjoy bold, independent theatre and iconic local broadcasting.

Witamy | Ласкаво просимо | Добро пожаловать | Добродошли | Добре дошли | Vítejte | Dobrodošli | Добредојдовте | Сардэчна запрашаем

This year’s festival is bigger than ever! Enjoy live music from Ish, Vox Ethno, Balkany, Klezmer Rebs, Krackerjack, Cosmonauts, Wososi, and Mehana — plus traditional Polish, Ukrainian, and Bulgarian dancing.
Come and try yummy food from our Slavic and Balkan stalls (pierogi, borscht, burek, kielbasa (Polish smoked sausage), Hungarian fried bread, Blini, pirozhki), artisan crafts, kids’ workshops, and hands-on cultural fun.

description:
THREE JOYFUL HOUSES - AOTEAROA FESTIVAL OF ARCHITECTURE - SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER, THREE JOYFUL HOUSES by IAN ATHFIELD
SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER @ FUTUNA CHAPEL - KARORI
Three joyful houses, three families and three client stories about the commissioning, designing, building and living in homes designed by Ian Athfield.
SPENCER and DIANE LOGAN
1974 - 1978
WINDY POINT – EASTBOURNE
Photographer unknown
Spencer Logan and his wife Diane will talk about the commissioning of their first new home, its design, construction, the cleaning of thousands of bricks, and living in this unique collection of a pair of recycled brick towers with timber clad ‘saddlebags’. 
ROSS, CUSHLA and TESS JAMIESON
1974 - 1978
MAHINA BAY
Ross and Cushla have lived in their home on the Eastern hills above Mahina Bay for 48 years. They will, along with their youngest daughter, recount their experiences of working with Ian Athfield in the commissioning of the design of their home, the construction process and then living in this hillside hugging collection of building, and how this home may have influenced their living and the raising of a family of four children.
JONATHAN CUSTANCE   - THE CUSTANCE HOUSE 1981 – 1982
HAVELOCK NORTH
“The Custance House replaced an early modern home that burnt to the ground in 1981 leaving only the swimming pool unscathed.  Ray and Ann Custance, who were friends of the Athfields, sought a bold replacement.  With their son, industrial and interior designer Jonathan Custance, they prepared a four page brief for a new building….. “
Text taken from Athfield Architects by Julia Gatley 2012 AUP.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. 
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when registering for Architect tickets

description:
Mostly Music Soundscape Series | Rameka Tamaki, Mostly Music Soundscape Series | Rameka Tamaki
People can expect a level of artistry and mastery over the guitar. Rameka will be playing a selection of Classical Guitar pieces which include places like Spain, Japan, South America, and also his own compositions. These will range from Baroque, to Romantic, and Modern, with elements of different genres that encompass different cultures and time periods from around the world.

Rameka Tamaki (Tūhoe, Maniapoto, Samoan, Tongan, Irish) is a Classical Guitarist from Aotearoa, New Zealand who has performed in festivals and shows around the world. With a passion for the guitar and Māori culture he completed his Bachelor of Music with First Class Honours at The New Zealand School of Music, Victoria University. His performances include ASIA Topa, The New Zealand Opera Company, Performance Space at Carriageworks Sydney, the Matariki Ahi Kā Festival, Gardens Magic, and Los Angeles for Kapa Haka.


About the Mostly Music Soundscape Series

A curated series of intimate live music experiences showcasing the depth, texture and emotion of sound. Each performance invites you to immerse yourself in a new soundscape, informed by genre, sonic craft, and music as an art form. Designed for music lovers who want more than a background soundtrack, this series celebrates live performance with a diverse range of acclaimed performers.

Saturday 21 June — Nick Granville Trio

Saturday 26 July — Seth Boy Trio

Saturday 30 August — Michelle Velvin Harpist

Saturday 20 September — The Weather Machine

Saturday 27 September — Rameka Tamaki

Saturday 25 October — Danica Bryant

Doors at 7:30pm, with events starting at 8pm. Each event will be 60—90 minutes in two sets.

These events will take place inside at The Bond Store, Paraparaumu and are seated with general admission. As a season pass holder you will be reserved seats near the front of the audience.

The Bond Store is located at 21 Birmingham Street, Paraparaumu. It operates as The Tasting Room which serves food and beverages.

With thanks to support from Creative NZ's Creative Communities Fund administered by Kāpiti Coast District Council.

It’s time to shake off the winter blues and celebrate kōanga/spring at Wellington Gardens!

Join us throughout September for Te Wā o te Kōanga, a month-long festival bursting with flowers, fresh beginnings, and lots of ways to connect with nature and community.
Explore both Wellington Botanic Garden ki Paekākā and Ōtari-Wilton’s Bush with events for everyone — from self-drive floral tours and roaming performers, to interactive family fun, art exhibitions, and behind-the-scenes experiences.

Bring your friends, whānau, and neighbours to celebrate the season of new life in Aotearoa’s special native and cultivated gardens.
Stay tuned for event highlights and come discover the joy of kōanga!

Te Papa Foundation Gala, Te Papa Foundation Gala
Wellington’s premier fundraising event, the Te Papa Foundation Gala brings together Aotearoa New Zealand’s leading supporters of arts and culture for one spectacular night in the museum.

🖼️ Enjoy handcrafted cocktails, discover new favourites in the Toi Art galleries, savour an exquisite three-course dinner paired with premium local wines, bid in our live charity auction, and then dance to live performances from acclaimed local musicians.

👋🏼Thanks to Webb’s, the Gala features a special live auction of once-in-a-lifetime experiences, including Sake & sushi with Dick Frizzell, a stunning carving by Tim Steel (Ngāi Tahu), and luxury escapes.

🎟️Tickets cost $3,000 for a table of ten, or $300 per person.

🌱All proceeds from the Gala supports Te Papa’s work across art, culture, history, science, and nature, ensuring that our much-loved national museum continues to thrive for generations to come.

💸Can’t make it? Our digital auction will be hosted by Webb’s from 28 August until 10 September. More information at tepapa.nz/gala.

description:
Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: Dimebag and Ozzy Memorial Show, Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: Dimebag and Ozzy Memorial Show
Ultimate Tribute Fest 2: A Memorial for Metal Legends
Rail Records, Wildkiwi Distillery, Women's Refuge, and Rockstock present a monumental night of heavy metal in honor of two of the genre's most important and beloved figures: the legendary guitarist "Dimebag" Darrell Abbott of Pantera, and the recently departed Godfather of Metal, Ozzy Osbourne.

Join us on Saturday, December 6th, 2025, at Wildkiwi in Upper Hutt for a memorial show that will shake the foundations. This date holds a special importance to us metal heads, falling just three days after what would have been Ozzy's 77th birthday (December 3rd) and just two days before the anniversary of Dimebag's tragic passing (December 8th, 2004), giving us all a chance to raise a glass and celebrate both legends in the loudest way possible.

This is a night to pay tribute to the artists who defined a generation of heavy music. From Dimebag's revolutionary groove and unmistakable harmonic squeals to Ozzy's haunting vocals and iconic stage presence, their impact is eternal. We invite the metal community to come together for an unforgettable evening of remembrance, unity, and blistering riffs.

The Lineup
Prepare for a full-throttle sonic assault from four of New Zealand's premier tribute acts, performing the anthems that have become the soundtrack to our lives:

•Hell's Wrath delivering the ferocious power of Pantera

•Zombie Stomp (ft. Danny Rascal) channeling the madness of Ozzy Osbourne

•Angel Dust performing the eclectic genius of Faith No More

•Demon Fetal Harvest unleashing the thrash mastery of Megadeth

(More bands to be announced!)

Event Details
•Date: Saturday, December 6, 2025

•Venue: Wildkiwi, Unit 13/27 Blenheim Street, Maidstone, Upper Hutt

•Time: Doors open at 6:00 PM

•Age Restriction: This is a strictly R18 event. ID will be required.

•Charity: We will be accepting donations at the event and at point of sale on behalf of Women's Refuge. Your support is greatly appreciated.

Ticket Information
Secure your spot to witness this massive tribute event. Tickets are on sale now!

•$20 Early Bird (+GST/BF) - Limited quantity available! Grab them before they're gone.

•$30 General Admission (+GST/BF)

•$40 Door Sales/Lates (If not sold out prior)

VIP Table Experience - Only 6 Available!
For the ultimate night out, gather your crew and secure a VIP table.

Price: $240 per table (includes 6 tickets - works out to $40 per person)

Perks:

•Guaranteed reserved seating for your group of 6.

•Early venue access from 4:00 PM to settle in and have a meal.

•10% discount on delicious bar food from the Wildkiwi kitchen.

•First dibs on the merch table.

•Check out soundcheck and meet the bands (where possible).

Limited Edition Merchandise
•Exclusive Event T-Shirt: $30

•Commemorate this special night with a limited edition T-shirt. There are only 20 of these shirts being made, so this is a true collector's item. Available as a ticket add-on. Don't miss out!

This show is a tribute, a memorial, and a celebration. Get your tickets now and be part of a historic night for New Zealand's metal scene.

LINK TO SIZING AND DESIGN HERE:

https://www.railrecords.net/utf2-tee
