description:
Southeast Asian Perceptions of New Zealand – Report Launch, Join us for the presentation and discussion of the Asia New Zealand Foundation’s latest report, Southeast Asian Perceptions of New Zealand.
Co-hosted by the New Zealand Institute of International Affairs and the Asia New Zealand Foundation Te Whītau Tūhono, please join us for the presentation of the Foundation’s inaugural Southeast Asian Perceptions of New Zealand report.
After 28 years of surveying New Zealanders’ perceptions of Asia, the Asia New Zealand Foundation has turned the lens back on New Zealand, for the first time asking 200 subject matter experts across Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines how they view New Zealand and its foreign policy.
 Highlights:
Which country feels the warmest towards New Zealand?
How is New Zealand depicted in local media?
Is New Zealand seen as upholding its independent foreign policy?
Do our Southeast Asian neighbours think New Zealand lives up to its claims and promises?
What areas should New Zealand be investing more in and increasing cooperation?
Join us for this in-person presentation and panel discussion and the chance to ask questions and learn from informed experts on Asia on 13 November from 5:30pm - 7:00pm at Government Building Lecture Theatre 1 (GLBT1), Victoria University of Wellington Pipitea campus, 33 Bunny Street, Pipitea, Wellington.
This event is free to attend, but please RSVP for catering purposes
label: Government & Politics

description:
Alexandr Misko - The International Guitar Sensation LIVE at St Peter's Village Hall | Paekākāriki, The international guitar sensation brings his groundbreaking stage show to New Zealand shores for the very first time!
May 30 at St Peter's Village Hall, Paekākāriki
7:00pm doors / 7:30pm show
Seated Concert
FAMILY FRIENDLY with $20 tickets for under 18s
Hailed as “the future of guitar” (Total Guitar), Misko is a globally renowned virtuoso known for his jaw-dropping technique, emotional depth, and genre-defying style. Fusing classical precision with elements of jazz, rock, and modern fingerstyle, his performances are both technically astonishing and deeply moving.
Misko’s self-taught, boundary-pushing approach has captivated millions online, earning him a massive global following and praise from some of the world’s top music publications. With lightning-fast fingerpicking, percussive tapping, and masterful arrangements, he transforms a single acoustic guitar into an entire musical universe — live and without loops.
A must-see for fans of instrumental brilliance, next-level guitar playing, and world-class musical storytelling!
WHAT THE PRESS SAY
“Misko is the future of guitar.” — Total Guitar
“A one-of-a-kind performance that will leave you speechless.” — The Guardian
“Alexandr Misko redefines guitar playing with every note he plays.” — MusicRadar
“A mesmerizing display of technical brilliance and raw emotion.” — Rolling Stone “A true guitar prodigy.” — Guitar World
“An artist who combines virtuosic technique with deep musical expression.” — Guitar Player
Tickets are VERY limited for these intimate concerts — don’t miss out on seeing live music at its finest!
St Peter’s Hall in Paekakariki is a welcoming community space that combines timeless charm with practical versatility. Its bright, open interiors and flexible layout make it perfect for a wide range of events—from concerts and theatre to meetings and celebrations. The main hall offers a stage area with quality sound and lighting, creating a comfortable setting for performances of all kinds. Additional rooms provide space for smaller gatherings or workshops, making the venue adaptable to many needs. Whether you’re attending a lively show or a community meeting, St Peter’s Hall offers a warm, inviting atmosphere that truly brings people together.

description:
WineDogs - Martinborough, We’re back – and it’s going to be better than ever.
Love Wine?
Love Dogs?
Then Winedogs is a must-do on your calendar this spring.

After selling out in 2023 and again in 2024, we’re heading to Luna Estate in Martinborough for our Wairarapa debut on Sunday 26 October 2025 – and we’re bringing the full winedogs experience with us.

Whether you're a past guest or brand new to the pack, this is your chance to join a community of dog lovers, wine drinkers, and people who know how to spend a Sunday in style.

Date: Sunday 26 October 2025
Time: 10am – 5pm
Location: Luna Estate Winery, Martinborough

What to expect:
Sip stroll and socialise with your pup this Spring at Luna Estate Vineyard! Enjoy a walk around Martinborough’s most picturesque vineyard with wine and dog treats along the way, followed by a dog friendly festival!
And the fun doesn’t stop after the walk.

We’ll have:
Fashion parades (yes, for the dogs too)
Prizes for best-dressed dog and best matching human/dog pair
Photo booths
Food trucks, music, wine, and chill zones to kick back for the afternoon
You don’t need to own a dog to come – you just have to love dogs.

Ticket Options:
Early Dog Admission: $50 – SOLD OUT
General Admission: $65
VIP Ticket: $150 – includes exclusive area, VIP menu, Luna Sparkling Wine, premium dog treats and a few surprises

Book now and don’t miss out →
A round of a-paws to our hosts, Luna Estate, for welcoming the winedogs crew to their incredible vineyard. This is one event you’ll want to be part of – whether you’re returning for another round, or joining us for the first time.

description:
ChoctoberFest, Porirua is the home of New Zealand’s favourite chocolate — Whittaker's. So it's only fitting it has a festival celebrating all things chocolate. During September and October, the city is serving up a range of tasty treats for ChoctoberFest, all featuring Whittaker’s chocolate.
More than 30 local businesses will be competing in the Whittaker’s Bake Off and Top of the Chocs. Head in to participating spots, and try unique chocolate drinks and amazing baked goods. You can then vote for your favourites.
Indulge your tastebuds and try special drinks such as a whipped white choc biscoff latte, or a coldbrew shot choc maltini. For a sweet snack, how about a molten embrace, kunafa chocolate croissant, or a banoffee flossy pie? There are plenty of options for all chocolate lovers, including vegan and gluten free items.
As well as voting for your favourite items, you can join the fan club, share reviews, and be in to win. Up for grabs are 100 Whittaker’s Peanut Slabs, an exclusive tour of the Whittaker’s factory, and ChoctoberFest vouchers for local cafes and bars.
The festival has been running since 2022, and is a highlight of the local hospitality scene.
label: Festivals

description:
NZIFF: The President’s Cake, A young girl scrambles to prepare a high-stakes birthday cake for a dictator amidst the dangers and deprivations of the Gulf War in this irresistibly scrappy Caméra d'Or-winner from Iraq.

Nine-year-old Lamia (Banin Ahmad Nayef in a spectacular debut) lives with her grandmother and beloved rooster in the impoverished but tranquil Iraqi Marshes. Despite barely being able to feed themselves due to crippling food shortages caused by international sanctions, the family is randomly selected to prepare a cake as part of the forced national spectacle observing Saddam Hussein’s birthday.

From bucolic wetlands to bustling city streets, Lamia embarks on an ingredient-hunting odyssey that mixes equal parts sweet absurdity and bitter reality. Bartering with hawkers, dodging authorities, and begging the kindness of strangers, the young girl encounters the full gamut of humanity, from good to grotesque, as she approaches her ludicrous mission with innocent determination.

Director Hasan Hadi deftly evokes humour and open heartedness against a bleak background of oppression and war. Cinematographer Tudor Vladimir Panduru summons rich texture from the gorgeous locations, beautifully backed by a flowing soundtrack of traditional strings. — Adrian Hatwell
label: Film & Media

description:

Mac 'n' Cheese pop-up! Kaibosh X Everybody Eats collab for Welly On A Plate, We

Welly! Celebrate comfort food & community on the last day of winter
where every bowl makes a difference. Kaibosh X EE team up to serve 2,000 bowls of mac 'n' cheese on the final day of Visa Wellington On a Plate. Help us set a record for Welly while enjoying a bowl of the ultimate comfort food
At just $10 per serve, every bowl will help raise funds for Everybody Eats and Kaibosh - two of Wellington’s legendary food rescue and community dining champions. Help us hit our target of 2,000 bowls in one day!

description:
Book Launch - Isaac Featherston 'Petatone': A Colonial Life, Join us next month to launch Isaac Featherston 'Petatone': A Colonial Life by John E Martin. The book will be launched by Charlotte MacDonald.

Tuesday 7 October, 6pm
Unity Books Wellington
All welcome!

'Existing views of Featherston are fragmentary, negative and not very satisfactory. He was the “little Doctor”, a single-minded despot wielding tyrannical power and casting an oppressive shadow. As I began to understand more of his life, I realised that there was little appreciation of a man who had contributed so much.’ —John E.Martin

Isaac Featherston was at the heart of some of the most significant developments in New Zealand from the 1840s colonisation by the New Zealand Company to the abolition of the provinces in 1876. A doctor, newspaper editor and politician, he advocated for the provinces against the domination of central government, while also being primarily responsible for the relocation of the capital from Auckland to Wellington in 1865.

Known amongst Māori as ‘Petatone’ and with a reputation for directness and honesty, he was at the very centre of Pākehā–Māori relations, and in his 1857 official portrait is depicted alongside leading rangatira Te Puni and Wi Tako.

About the author: Dr. John E. Martin has researched and written about New Zealand history since the 1980s, teaching in universities and employed as a historian in the public sector. He was parliamentary historian in the 2000s and 2010s. His publications include rural and labour history, the history of science and engineering, and social and political history. His books include The Forgotten Worker (1990), People, Politics and Power Stations (1991 and 1998), Holding the Balance (1996), The House: New Zealand’s House of Representatives, 1854–2004 (2004), Parliament’s Library (2008), Honouring the Contract (2010), Illuminating Our World (2017), A Colonist’s Gaze (2018) and most recently Empire City: Wellington Becomes the Capital of New Zealand (2022).

description:
After 5: Wellington Free Ambulance, Most sudden cardiac arrests happen at home in the community, would you know how to instantly help a family member or neighbour?
Go beyond regular networking and learn vital skills in this special session with Wellington Free Ambulance. You’ll learn about our region’s uniquely free emergency ambulance service, their incredible heritage story, and connection to the community that continues today.
You’ll be able to learn CPR – a vital and potentially lifesaving skill that will give you the confidence and skills to help your community when it matters most. You’ll also get to see how an AED works!
Most importantly, this event will showcase the range of ways you or your business can keep the FREE in Wellington Free Ambulance. Your support is vital to ensure ambulance services stay free of charge in our community, so make sure you secure your spot at this potentially life-saving evening.
Click here to secure your spot.

description:
The Racket Lounge: Session Three, Grab a spot on our couch and enjoy the noise at The Racket Lounge, a chill classical music series featuring up-and-coming Pōneke classical and jazz musicians.

Last year the NZSQ Trust launched the Racket Lounge, a concert series for classical and jazz musicians with experience ranging from students to pros to freely express their creativity in a non-traditional concert setting. It was a huge success, with over 250 audience members and 52 artists over our four sessions. Audiences were raving about the musical variety and great talent they found at the Racket Lounge, and as one audience member commented; “Well done…do it again!” So, we listened, and the Racket Lounge is back for round two! Once again hosted at Bedlam & Squalor (above the Rogue & Vagabond), we welcome audiences, composers and performers back for another four concerts full of innovative, fun, and chill music. From classical to pop covers, video game soundtracks to original compositions, there's something for everyone to sink their teeth into at The Racket Lounge!

Even if you've never been to a classical music concert before, this one is for you. With a 'Choose your price' model you can afford to give it a go - and you might even find something you like!

A Flexible Price, So You Can Take A Chance on Something New:
Our prices range from $5 to $100, just pick the ticket price you feel like paying. At The Racket Lounge, we believe everyone should have access to high-quality but affordable art. If you're a bit strapped for cash right now, but still want a good night out, no worries! Just book yourself a $5 ticket! If you can afford to pay a little more and want to do some good for your community, then pick one of our higher ticket prices and rest assured that your dollars are going towards funding great, accessible art in your city.

All proceeds from ticket sales will go directly into presenting the next Racket Lounge, including paying musicians and artists, hiring instruments and marketing costs. Plus, by choosing a higher price point, you're ensuring that we're able to continue to offer tickets at a lower price point for those who need it.

Please note: Bedlam & Squalor is a licenced venue, so under 18s must be accompanied by a parent or legal guardian. Everyone must bring ID.

description:
Affordable Healthcare for All: Wellington, Luxon’s cuts are making our health system worse. His choices mean it’s getting harder and more expensive to see a doctor or nurse. 
National has found hundreds of millions for tobacco companies while New Zealand’s hospitals go understaffed and nurses are left without jobs. 
It's Luxon's fault GP fees are heading towards $100. Under National, you’re paying more, waiting longer and getting less. 
Labour believes that every New Zealander should be able to access world-class healthcare, no matter where they live. 
We will make it cheaper and easier to get care close to home, and make sure hospitals are there when you need them.  
Join Labour Leader Chris Hipkins and Health Spokesperson Dr Ayesha Verrall for a public meeting on getting the healthcare you deserve.

description:
Gloria, Witness a show in honour of the renowned choreographer and dancer, Douglas Wright. The New Zealand Dance Company and Co3 Contemporary Dance Australia will restage his masterpiece, ‘Gloria’. Set to Vivaldi's legendary score, performed live by the New Zealand Symphony Orchestra and Voices New Zealand. A celebration of life, dancers will fly, twist, and turn among the grandeur of the historic St James Theatre.
‘Gloria’ was originally performed at the 1992 Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts. This contemporary trans-Tasman collaboration honours one of Aotearoa's most prolific dance talents. Producing more than 30 major touring works in his life and dancing across the globe, Douglas Wright was a celebrated performer and creative until his death in 2018.
The evening will also feature two new creations. ‘A Moving Portrait’ by Raewyn Hill is an intimate, meditative reflection on ageing and grace. ‘Lament’ by Moss Te Ururangi Patterson will take audiences on a powerful journey through memory and resilience. The performance honours the whakapapa of contemporary dance in Aotearoa.
‘Gloria’ is exclusive to Wellington. It's presented as part of the Aotearoa New Zealand Festival of the Arts 2026.

description:
Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days, Advanced Flush Setting in Two Days
This workshop is ideal for advanced students who have already learned how to set cabochon stones. Over two three-hour sessions, 20 and 27 September, 10am-1pm, you will be given an understanding of the technique of setting faceted stones using a setting burr, hammers, punches and burnishing tools. This is the first step in learning to flush set facet cut stones so they sit below the surface of the metal.

Session 1 will cover the technique, demonstrations and the basics of preparing and cutting the setting. Students will be shown how to set their stones, and may begin to do this in class, but will then go on to repeat and practice the technique in their own time.
They can do this at home, or for a small extra cost, can stay on at the studio to practice setting for the afternoon.

Session 2 will pick up on the setting techniques, reminding and refining essential steps in the process. Troubleshooting can be covered in this class, as well as learning to clean up the settings. The principles of this setting technique will be covered in a few different scenarios, as some students may wish to take this skill into different styles or directions.

The option for students to have a half-day bench hire after class will also apply to this session.

What is provided: class fees cover your practice metal (copper) and stones (CZ) and detailed handouts that are useful for you to take away to refer to when practising and honing your skills.

Correctly sized drills and setting burrs will be provided in class, but students must purchase their own burrs for practice after class and any future bench hires. These are available for purchase in the studio.

What to bring: Advanced students can bring projects to set stones into, but please note the metal must be at least 2mm thick and we do not allow brass to be used as a project or practice for beginners. The metal must be copper or sterling silver.

Students should bring either a craft magnifier or magnifying lenses/glasses. If you have your own flex shaft tool you plan to use at home for drilling and setting, please also bring this along so that your tutor can advise on the best way to use it. We have two drilling machines in the studio, and these must be shared between the students, so if you have a machine, do bring it.

Practice bench hire after class $20 per person (till 4pm) must be booked in advance.

Workshop fee $195, Early bird $175 till 24 August.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Government Digital Transformation in Latin America - what can we learn?, We are excited to announce the latest in our series of talks on Digital Transformation, in partnership with Silverstripe.
María Inés Baque will be joining us online from Argentina to share her expert insights and experiences on the key goals, capabilities, opportunities and challenges for government digital transformation - with a range of use cases from around Latin America.
María Inés Baque is Government Transformation Advisor for Latin America, Canada, and the Caribbean (LCC) at AWS. She served as secretary of digital government and technology innovation in Argentina from 2016 to 2019. She coordinated the Digital Agenda 2030 and led the transformational efforts in the areas of digital services, digital inclusion, open government, open data and new technologies adoption.
Global awards and recognitions she has received include Innovation Lab, Tel Aviv, 20 exceptional GovTech Leaders (2020), Women Corporate Directors 2019 and The 100 Most Influential People in Digital Government, Apolitical, 2018.
She was co-chair of the G20 Digital Economy Taskforce for Gender Inclusion in 2018 that issued the Bridging the Digital Gender Divide report.
Before government, her career was in global IT and financial services enterprises. She focused on process reengineering, startups, IT management, outsourcing and business process operations.
You may attend in person at the MBIE offices (limited to 40 people - there will be some food courtesy of Silverstripe), or you may tune in online via Microsoft Teams (the link will be at the bottom of your order confirmation email). If you choose to attend in person please arrive at 11.50am so there is time for you to sign in, pick up some food, and be seated before we begin. There will be time for questions after the presentation.
label: Government & Politics

description:
From Europe to the Indo-Pacific: Finnish views on strategic partnerships and security in times of uncertainty, Finland, which shares a 1300km land border with Russia, has had its strategic circumstances dramatically impacted by the war in Ukraine. In this talk, State Secretary Pasi Rajala will discuss Europe’s evolving security landscape and its implications for Finland and NATO. He will share Finnish views on enhancing security and national resilience in response to shifting dynamics across Europe, the Indo-Pacific, and the global stage. He will also speak to the importance of deepening cooperation between Finland and New Zealand, two like-minded partners committed to democratic values, multilateralism, and the rules-based international order.
Mr. Pasi Rajala is State Secretary to Foreign Minister Elina Valtonen and Defence Minister Antti Häkkänen. He has previously served as Special European Affairs Adviser to the Finnish Prime Minister, Special Adviser to the Minister for Trade and Development, and Press Counselor and Spokesperson at the Finnish Embassy in Washington, D.C. Prior to that he held a number of communications positions, including in development finance company Finnfund, PR agency EuroRSCG, and the UN Development Program. Mr. Rajala holds a Master of Social Sciences degree from the University of Helsinki where he majored in International Relations.
label: Government & Politics

description:
HRCA 50yrs Misuse of Drugs Act: What impact? What next?, Rutherford House (by the train station)
Room RHLT2
Bunny Street
Wellington
1.30-4.30pm
Free Admission
Light refreshments afterward
The NZ Misuse of Drugs Act 1975 (MoDA) has failed to deliver. Data from the United Nations Office for Drugs and Crime indicated the demand for drugs is greater than ever, while the supply of drugs knows no bounds.
A failure acknowledged globally and one we witness first hand here in Aotearoa NZ.
Back in 2011 a comprehensive review of the MoDA conducted by New Zealand Law Commission had already concluded the MoDA “should be repealed and replaced by a new Act …administered by the Ministry of Health”.
The Harm Reduction Coalition of Aotearoa wants to see that recommendation enacted.
We are delighted to have assembled a group of respected independent thinkers in the field, with vast experience of drug policy in Aotearoa and beyond, to reflect on the impact of the MoDA and to identify the principles and values needed to underpin new drug laws.
Warren Young
Professor of Law & Former Deputy President New Zealand Law Commission
Kirsten Gibson
Chair of Harm Reduction Coalition Aotearoa and Qualitative Researcher
Fiona Hutton
Associate Professor, Institute of Criminology, Victoria University of Wellington
Adam Dorsett
40 Years Living Experience of Prohibited Drug Use, in Prison for 25 years
Julian Buchanan
Former UNODC Advisor and Criminology Professor
New Zealand has a history for world leading innovative policy reform: Woman’s Right to Vote; Decriminalisation of Sex Work; National Needle Exchange, Same Sex Marriage and most recently Drug Checking.
This half day symposium will provide clear evidence why major law reform is necessary and detail the foundations upon which Aotearoa NZ can once again lead the way with new drug laws based on evidence, research and experience.
We look forward to seeing there!
Do pass on to anyone who might be interested.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Watercolour Paint and Wine Night in Wellington - Midnight Kitty, The concept is simple - take a brush in one hand, a drink in the other and let’s paint a masterpiece!

Join us for a creative night of drinking and painting in the heart of Wellington! No previous painting experience necessary. Get your creative juices flowing and your brush strokes going!

Drinks: NO DRINKS are included in the ticket price, but drinks are available for purchase.

Food: A delicious menu will be available to purchase throughout the event.

What is Paintvine?
It’s a fun social painting class where our artists will run you through step-by-step instructions on how to create your very own masterpiece in a fun and relaxed bar setting. Perfect for dates, catching up with mates or for meeting new friends!

We provide all the materials you need (high-quality canvas, acrylic paint, brushes). All you need to bring is your creative spirit (or find some at the bottom of a glass). At the end of the night you will leave with your own painting ready to hang up on your wall.

For tickets, future events, FAQs and more info head to the Paintvine website.

description:
Gorgeous Texture Earrings and Pendants Taster, A quick taster class that’s ideal as a festive outing for friends, or as a treat for you! In three short hours, learn to craft an amazing pair of textured metal earrings - from scratch!

Over this taster class, you’ll be guided through the process of heating and texturing metal, cutting and shaping with traditional jewellery tools. After completing this class, you will have one pair of beautiful earrings to wear away or gift to someone special!

You will practice on smaller texture samples to work out what texture and what metal you want to go with, and then move on to creating your earrings in warm copper, yellow brass and sterling silver - with solid sterling silver earring hooks or posts.

The earrings will be made with silver bonded onto copper, giving the bright flash of silver on one side and the dark tone of copper on the other.

Your class materials pack includes everything you need for the class to make a super cool pair of beautiful earrings. You are welcome to purchase extra materials for larger pieces at the studio.

We use quality pre-made sterling silver earring wires, or earring posts with silicone stud backs for these taster classes so that you can focus on making the main part of the earrings and know that your findings will be just perfect.

Kids aged 12 (or so) are welcome to attend the class, but an enrolled parent or caregiver must accompany anyone under the age of 16.
label: Classes & Workshops

In this course you will learn to:

- learn slab, pinch pot and coil construction techniques
- learn how to glaze your creations
- learn techniques to create art that will withstand the firing process.

Creations will be fired at the end of each term and ready to collect at the beginning of next.

Mondays after school, 13 October - 8 December (no class on Labour Day, 27 October), 3:45 pm - 5:15 pm.

description:
Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY, Kapiti Crop Swap PUKERUA BAY
THIS INVITE IS FOR THE PUKERUA BAY SWAP😁🌱
Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!
1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4pm)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)
To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.
The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.
This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:
3-2.15pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.
3.15-3.45pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
3.45-4pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.
The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month in Raumati and the last Saturday of every month in Waikanae.
Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.
2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!

description:
CMNZ Series Four Last Songs, Composed in the year before his passing, the 'Four Last Songs' are held by many to be Richard Strauss’ most beautiful, sensuous, and moving composition. They are songs of farewell and of gentle heartbreak. The words of the final song, 'Im Abendrot', speak of an elderly couple walking hand in hand, at rest from their wanderings, away from life. The final verse:

O weiter, stiller Friede! O vast and silent peace!
So tief im Abendrot So deep in sunset glow,
Wie sind wir wandermüde- How weary we are with wandering-
Ist dies etwa der Tod? Could this perhaps be death?

For this special premiere performance, Salina Fisher has arranged the 'Four Last Songs' for NZTrio and celebrated Australian soprano Emma Pearson.

description:
Roger Hall’s Easy Money -final night, Roger Hall’s Easy Money -final night
A comedy plot driven farce loosely based on Ben Johnson’s Jacobean Tale The Alchemist, set in the current day. A laugh a minute tale of greed, described by Hall as having “no moral, no message – just entertainment”

An Australian couple is based in a swanky Auckland harbourside Airbnb, armed with a loose plan to shake down as many self-satisfied cashed-up “neighbours” as possible; in the hope of a quick payday and an early retirement. All about greed and how a fool and their money are soon parted; with double crosses, dirty tricks and dodgy dealings….It’s so audacious, you can see the dollar signs flickering in the eyes of their marks.

(Revised in 2022 to update and change ethnicity)

DATES
Wed 27 Aug 2025 - Sat 6 Sep 2025

description:
Kazakhstan and Central Asia: Leveraging International Partnerships in an Uncertain World, Kazakhstan’s strategic location between Europe and Asia, combined with the sweeping political and economic reforms, substantial energy, critical minerals, transit, and sustainable agriculture potential, increasing AI and digital profile, makes it a hotspot for international investors and pundits alike.
Meanwhile, amid the shift towards an increasingly multipolar order, Kazakhstan has also been emerging as an important middle power contributing to regional and global governance, stability, inter-faith dialogue, and sustainable development. But bold ambitions and increasing global fragmentation raise big questions:
How will Kazakhstan and the region of Central Asia, as a whole, navigate a world increasingly shaped by great-power rivalry and competing alignments, while sustaining regional cohesion and driving growth and innovation? What new opportunities might global decision-makers and investors uncover as
Kazakhstan develops its strategic sectors and promotes a well-balanced and pragmatic foreign policy?
Kazakhstan's regional Ambassador His Excellency Askar Kuttykadam based in Singapore will be in Wellington on 4 November and is a great opportunity for members, students and guests to learn about a region we don't hear too much about in New Zealand!
Event details
Date: Tuesday 4 November, 12:30-1:30pm
Venue: RHMZ03, Mezzanine Floor, Rutherford House, Pipitea Campus
Doors Open: 12:10pm
Event commences: 12:30pm
Event concludes: 1:30pm
Terms and Conditions
-One ticket per person. Each ticket must contain your full first and surname, email address and phone number that matches your ID. This event is for registered members of the NZIIA or non-members who pay the registration fee. We reserve the right to cancel any tickets registered as a NZIIA Member if you are not a 2025 NZIIA member. Walk ups are not allowed- you must be registered in advance.
-In keeping with NZIIA practice, unauthorised recording of this event (either audio or video) is not permitted.
-As a courtesy to others given limited availability of seats please only book if you can definitely attend.
Biography - HE Askar Kuttykadam
Ambassador of the Republic of Kazakhstan to the Singapore, Australia and New Zealand
General information, education
1998 - Graduated from Al-Farabi Kazakh State National University, Almaty, Kazakhstan.
Career
He began his diplomatic service in 1998 as the Referent (Assistant Attache) at the Europe and America Division of the Department of Bilateral Cooperation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Kazakhstan.
From 1999 to 2001 – Attache, Third Secretary of the Department of Bilateral Cooperation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Kazakhstan. In 2001- 2004, he was the Attache, Third Secretary at the Embassy of Kazakhstan in Lithuania.
In 2004-2005, he worked as the First Secretary in the Department of Europe and America and the Department of Information and Analytical Work and Forecast Assessments.
In 2005, he was the head of the Department of Information and Analytical Work and Forecast Assessments of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Kazakhstan.
From 2005 to 2007, he was the Counsellor of the Embassy of Kazakhstan in Malaysia, and in 2007-2009 – Counsellor of the Embassy of Kazakhstan in China.
In 2010-2011, he worked as the Head of Division, Deputy Director of the OSCE Department, in 2011-2012, Deputy Director of the Department of Pan-European Cooperation of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Kazakhstan.
From 2012 to 2013 he held the position of Minister-Counsellor of the Embassy of Kazakhstan in Canada, in 2014-2015 – Counsellor of the Embassy of Kazakhstan in Malaysia.
From 2016 to 2018, he worked as the Deputy Director of the Department of Foreign Policy Analysis and Forecasting of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Kazakhstan. In 2018-2019 – Counsellor to the Embassy of Kazakhstan in Poland.
Prior to his appointment as Kazakhstan's Ambassador to Singapore, Australia and New Zealand concurrently, he was Deputy Head of the Department of Foreign Policy and International Relations of the Executive Office of the President of the Republic of Kazakhstan. The Ambassador presented his credentials to the Governor General in Wellington on 8 August 2023.
Askar Kuttykadam has the diplomatic rank of Envoy Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of the I class.

description:
Track Day- 2025, Track Day- 2025
🚗💥 START YOUR ENGINES! 💥🚗

We are beyond excited to announce Forged Development's First Ever Track Day at Manfeild Motorsport Park-Circuit Chris Amon!

📅 SAVE THE DATE: 27th September 2025!

In celebration of our founder and owner, Sameer Kumar’s 40th birthday, we’re kicking things into high gear with an action-packed PlayDay on Track event!
Forged Development, in collaboration with PlayDay on Track, we’ve been working tirelessly to deliver an unforgettable track experience. Whether you're a seasoned track enthusiast or just looking to enjoy a fun day on the tarmac, we’ve got you covered.

What’s in store:

A thrilling day on the iconic Manfeild Motorsport Park.

Designed for all skill levels, with three distinct Speed Groups to ensure a safe, exciting experience for everyone.

Maximum track time with minimal racing traffic, so you can make the most of every lap!

Track Entry Tickets now available:

Show and Shine Entry: Now Live

Spectator entrance free!


Competitor Information:

WOF or Reg aren't required, however 3rd Party insurance is preferred as Forged Development Limited and PlayDay on Track takes no liability for any damages or loss at the event.

What you need to bring: (You will not be allowed on track without the minimum safety requirments)
- Driver’s license
- Overalls (minimum 1 layer Cotton)
- Closed top shoes
- Helmet

Not mandatory however highly recommended:
- Neck Restraints/Hans device
- Fire extinguisher

No passengers unless a full MSNZ approved caged. (Expect in familiarization laps for non-caged vehicles)
Passengers wishing to go in a caged car must sign an indemnity form available from the documentation/registration area.

Garage sheds are on a first come, first serve basis.

Pitlane Garages are available for hire, limited available for purchase along with your ticket.

Vehicle Safety:
Participants are responsible for ensuring their car is safe. This includes:
- No fluid leaks (oil, fuel, coolant, brake fluid)
- Brakes in good working condition with sufficient pad material
- Tires in good health
- Lug nuts torqued to spec; all must be present
- Battery securely mounted
- Seat belts or harnesses in working condition
- No loose items inside the vehicle (tools, bottles, etc.)
You will be asked to sign a self-tech form during registration.

On-Track Rules:
- Passing allowed only in designated zones (straights) and with ownership on the driver overtaking to execute a safe pass.
- No hard-overtaking under braking/corners.
- Yield to faster vehicles; use mirrors frequently.
- If you spin or leave the track, rejoin only when safe or return to the pits.
- When on track, do not leave your vehicle unless if fire.
- Aggressive driving, unsafe behaviour, or reckless manoeuvres (e.g., drifting, tailgating) will result in ejection from the event.
- Obey all flag signals and track officials immediately.
- Pitlane Speed limit: 10 kph
- No tire burnouts, speeding, or aggressive driving in paddock/pit areas.

Weather Policy:
- Track day runs rain or shine unless deemed unsafe by organizers.
- Participants must adjust driving style to suit conditions.

Liability Disclaimer:
- All participants must sign a waiver of liability.
- You are responsible for any damage you cause to your vehicle, other vehicles, or track property.
- The track and organizers are not liable for injuries, mechanical failures, or accidents.

Refunds:
There are no refunds but you can transfer your entry to someone else (You can do this via contacting us directly)

Advertising release:
As a condition of entry, each entrant for themselves, as agent for accompanying adult and as parent or guardian for an accompanying child, grant the event promoter, Forged Development Limited, the exclusive right to photograph, video or film, or portrayal without names or credits as the event promoter may in their absolute discretion think fit.

description:
Nuclear Disarmament in a Nuclear Free New Zealand: Why it still matters, New Zealand is recognised as a global leader in nuclear disarmament, with its 1987 Nuclear
Free Zone, Disarmament, and Arms Control Act becoming a defining feature of the country’s
national identity. The establishment of a nuclear free zone has served as inspiration
worldwide, yet, despite this, the nuclear issue remains relevant to New Zealand. As long as
nuclear weapons exist, their environmental, humanitarian and geopolitical impacts extend far
beyond the borders of nuclear weapon states.
This panel and fireside chat seeks to situate New Zealand’s position within the global
nuclear landscape, exploring why the issue continues to matter to a nuclear free country,
highlighting the interconnected impacts of these weapons, whilst also considering New
Zealand’s role as a disarmament leader.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Public Lecture – Amnesty International Secretary General Dr Agnès Callamard, Public Lecture – Amnesty International Secretary General Dr Agnès Callamard
Global human rights leader Dr Agnès Callamard speaks on humanity, justice, and hope in action. Don’t miss this rare event.

Dr Agnès Callamard is recognised globally as a leading authority on governance, accountability, and international affairs. She has been Secretary General of Amnesty International since 2021, previously served as the UN Special Rapporteur on extrajudicial executions, and was Director of Columbia University’s Global Freedom of Expression project. Her career spans decades of leadership in defending human rights worldwide.
In this public lecture, Dr Callamard will reflect on today’s global challenges and opportunities, exploring how collective action can drive change.

Jonathon Boston ONZM, Emeritus Professor of Public Policy at the Wellington School of Business and Government, and Former Director of the Institute of Policy Studies and the Institute for Governance & Policy Studies will host the session.
This event offers a unique opportunity to engage with global human rights discourse in Aotearoa New Zealand at a time when representation, civic freedoms, and the international rules-based order are being widely debated. It also aims to inspire the next generation of change-makers to connect with both local and global struggles for justice.
Event Details
Date & Time: Tuesday 23rd October, 5:00pm doors with lecture starting at 5:30pm
Venue: Rutherford Theatre, Victoria University of Wellington
Who Should Attend? Students, faculty, civil society leaders, activists, and members of the public interested in human rights, justice, and accountability
Accessibility: The venue is wheelchair accessible
Seats Available: 150 seats open to the public (first come, first served)

description:
Haunted Hop & Halloween Bar Crawl Weekend Pass – Wellington 2025, Haunted Hop & Halloween Bar Crawl Weekend Pass – Wellington 2025
Party all weekend in Wellington! The Haunted Hop & Halloween Bar Crawl Weekend Pass gets you into the best bars on Oct 31 & Nov 1.

About this Event






👻🎃Haunted Hop + Halloween Bar Crawl Weekend Pass – Wellington 2025 👻🎃
Two nights. One ticket. The ultimate Halloween takeover. The Weekend Pass gives you entry to both of Wellington’s biggest Halloween crawls — the Haunted Hop Bar Crawl on Friday, October 31st, and the Halloween Bar Crawl on Saturday, November 1st. Back-to-back nights of costumes, cocktails, and chaos, all across the Wellington’s hottest bars and nightclubs.
Friday kicks off with the Haunted Hop, a massive crawl where costumed partygoers pack the streets and every venue becomes a Halloween hotspot. Saturday turns up the volume with the Halloween Bar Crawl, bringing out DJs, dance floors, and spooky specials to close out the weekend in style.
Why settle for one night when you can crawl through both?





WEEKEND PASS HIGHLIGHTS
🎟️ Two Crawls, One Wristband – Admission to both Friday + Saturday events.
🎶 Live Music & DJs – Halloween hits, party anthems, and dance-floor energy all weekend.
🍸 Exclusive Drink Specials – Spooky cocktails, eerie shots, and bar-only deals.
👻 Costumes Everywhere – From scary to sexy to over-the-top — your outfit gets two nights to shine.
📍 Multiple Venues Each Night – 4+ bars and clubs, all within walking distance.



HOW IT WORKS
1️⃣ Check-In: Collect your weekend wristband at the designated starting venue (7:30–10:30 PM, both nights).
2️⃣ Crawl the City: Explore participating bars and clubs between 8:30–11:30 PM at your own pace.
3️⃣ Final Party: Join the crowd at the closing venue from 11:30 PM–2 AM for the ultimate send-off.





WHAT’S INCLUDED
🎟️ Admission to both Friday + Saturday crawls
🚫 No cover charges at any participating venues
📱 Digital crawl maps for both nights
🎶 DJs & live music at every stop
🍹 Themed drink and shot specials
🕺 Huge closing parties each night



PARTICIPATING VENUES
The full lineup of bars and nightclubs will be revealed closer to the event. Each venue offers its own Halloween theme, entertainment, and drink specials for crawl guests.


🎃 Hundreds of Halloween lovers, back-to-back nights, and the best nightlife Wellington has to offer. Whether you’re creeping through the Haunted Hop on Friday or shutting it down at Saturday’s finale, the Weekend Pass is your ticket to experience it all.
🚨 Early bird passes start at just $25. Lock in your plans now before prices rise.



18+ EVENT / GOVERNMENT ISSUED ID REQUIRED


TIPS FOR OUR CRAWL
Pick Up Wristbands On Time: Collect your wristband(s) during the designated check-in time at the scheduled location before 10:30 PM. Late arrivals will not be accommodated — no wristband, no entry.
Assign a Proxy if Needed: Can’t make check-in? Have a friend pick up your wristband for you so you don’t miss out.
Check Venue Schedule: Each venue’s crawl time is listed in the Digital Bar List. Wristbands and drink specials are valid only during these scheduled times.
Day-Of Updates: Review the Digital Crawl Map on the morning of the event for any last-minute changes or venue updates.
_______________________________________


IMPORTANT DISCLAIMERS
Age Requirement: You must be 18+ years of age with a valid government-issued ID to participate in this event. No exceptions.
Wristbands: Your wristband is your key to entry. You must present your ticket or QR code at check-in to receive your wristband. Wristbands must be worn at all times to access participating bars and venues. Wristband pickup location and time are listed on the crawl map. If you do not pick up your wristband at the designated location and time, it may not be available, and you will not be able to access crawl venues. No wristband, no entry.
Ticket Policy: All sales are final—no refunds, exchanges, or transfers. In case of event cancellation without a rescheduled date, a refund (excluding fees) will be automatically issued. Event lineup, venues, and specials are subject to change without notice.
Admission & Venue Rights: Participating venues reserve the right to refuse service or entry to any attendee based on intoxication, dress code, inappropriate behaviour, or venue capacity. If refused entry at one venue, you may visit alternative crawl venues available at that time. No refunds will be given if you are denied entry for any of these reasons.
Capacity and Late Entry: Some venues may hit capacity during the event. If a venue reaches capacity or you arrive late, you may have to wait in line to gain entry. There is no guarantee of immediate access or entry to any specific venue once capacity is reached, and no refunds will be provided due to waiting times or access issues.
Self-Guided Crawl: This is a self-guided event with no host leading the group. You must use the digital crawl map to navigate between venues.
Venue Awareness: If bar staff are unaware of the crawl, you must contact the venue representative listed on the crawl map. If you cannot reach them, consider that venue unavailable and proceed to an alternative crawl venue open at that time. Nightlife venues may reach capacity or close early, and not all staff members may be aware of the crawl.
Drink Specials: Drink specials are offered by participating venues and may be modified or discontinued at any time without notice.
Event Time Restrictions: Your ticket is valid only for crawl venues during the scheduled crawl times listed on the crawl map. It is not valid for entry outside these times. If you arrive late or at the wrong venue, refunds will not be issued.
Security Checks: Wristbands do not entitle you to skip venue security checks. All attendees must comply with security screening before entry.
Costume Policy: Do not wear costumes that include items which could be considered or used as weapons. Highly offensive costumes are not tolerated and may result in denial of entry without refund.
Crawl Notifications: Sign up for crawl notification texts to receive updates about when to move to the next venue. There is no host to notify you in person.
Respect & Conduct: Treat others and the event venues with respect. Disorderly conduct, inappropriate behaviour, or damage to the venues will result in removal from the event without a refund. The participating bars reserve the right to refuse entry or remove attendees for inappropriate behaviour at any time.
Liability Waiver: By purchasing a ticket and participating in the crawl, you understand and agree that you are attending entirely at your own risk. You voluntarily assume all risks and dangers incidental to this event, including but not limited to: personal injury, illness, disability, property loss, theft, damage, accidents, death, alcohol-related incidents, and actions of other participants, staff, or third parties. You, on behalf of yourself and your heirs, executors, and assigns, hereby fully release, waive, and discharge Events Per Se, its owners, officers, directors, employees, contractors, volunteers, affiliates, sponsors, participating venues, and their respective representatives from any and all liability, claims, demands, actions, or causes of action whatsoever arising out of or related to any loss, damage, injury, illness, or death — whether caused by negligence, gross negligence, breach of contract, or otherwise — that may occur before, during, or after the event. You agree to indemnify and hold harmless Events Per Se and all released parties from any claims, costs, or expenses (including legal fees) brought by you or on your behalf, or by any third party as a result of your actions during the event. You acknowledge that you have read and understood this waiver, that you are participating voluntarily, and that this waiver is intended to be as broad and inclusive as permitted by applicable law.
Event Changes: Bars and venues may change, but the event will continue rain or shine. Always check the digital crawl map for the latest venue list and updates. Be sure to check your email for any last-minute updates.
*By purchasing a ticket, you confirm that you have read, understood, and agreed to all disclaimers, terms, and conditions stated above, and accept full responsibility for your participation in the event.

description:
Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Hutt Art Society Inc, Kintsugi Workshop in Wellington // Hutt Art Society Inc
After several SOLD OUT workshops in Wellington here is the next one... Oct 2025

Learn the magical art of Kintsugi with Artist Ema Frost in this new Workshop. You can bring along a piece of your own pottery to restore in this beautiful style. (I'll also have a few as back up if you don't have your own piece) (All Levels)

Saturday 11th October - 10:30am - 12:20pm or 2 - 4pm


Ema has been teaching Kintsugi for 5+ years and regularly travels to Japan to study and learn new techniques. Ema's illustrations and ceramic works sit in many of our countries best galleries, and whose products and merchandise sell in the most stylish design stores and gallery shops. Her style is enchanting - quirky, feminine and colourful, and clearly influenced by her travels throughout the world, usually off the beaten track.

Have you ever wanted to try Kintsugi.... It's an ancient Japanese art form where you fix broken pottery with gold - making its imperfections its beauty. - A truly wonderful philosophy to live by. Nothing is ever really broken but new life and meaning is brought back making your piece a work of art and truly something special. You can also apply this technique on various materials like glass, wood, greenstone and shells.

Kintsugi
It's called kintsugi (金継ぎ), or kintsukuroi (金繕い), literally golden (“kin”) and repair (“tsugi”). This traditional Japanese art uses a precious metal – liquid gold, liquid silver or lacquer dusted with powdered gold – to bring together the pieces of a broken pottery item and at the same time enhance the breaks.

You will take away your wonderful finished work, plus your new skills which will enable you to further your own Kintsugi in your own time.

What you will take away:
A finished artwork piece
A understanding of Kintsugi
Knowledge and History of this beautiful art form.

Join Jake Baxendale and friends as they delve into new approaches to composition and improvisation in the beautiful seclusion of Mount Victoria's Innermost Gardens.

description:
Re-imagine Pōneke: Co-design our city, What would Wellington look like if it truly reflected our hopes for a just, sustainable, and thriving city – not in 30 years, but right now?
Join us for Re-imagine Pōneke, a half-day unconference where Wellingtonians will come together to dream big, share ideas, and co-create a bold vision for the future of our city. Through participant-led breakout sessions and live illustration, we’ll collectively map out what a better Wellington could be – from housing and climate action to transport, community spaces, and beyond.
This event is part of Stronger Together, a youth-led campaign making local democracy real and relevant in Pōneke. As local elections approach, it’s time to reimagine how our city works for us all and explore the power of community-driven ideas.
Why come along?
Connect: Meet others who care deeply about the future of our city.
Create: Contribute your vision to a live, visual representation of a better Wellington.
Collaborate: Join participant-driven sessions on issues that matter most to you.
Inspire change: Leave with practical ideas and energy to take forward.
Whether you’re a seasoned organiser, new to local politics, or simply passionate about Wellington’s future, this event is for you.

description:
Guided tour of the historic Bolton Street Cemetery - Tiptoe Through the Tombstones, Guided tour of the historic Bolton Street Cemetery - Tiptoe Through the Tombstones
Explore historic Bolton Street Cemetery in central Wellington (just off The Terrace) with experienced guides. Hear entertaining and surprising stories with Tiptoe Through the Tombstones.

Tiptoe Through the Tombstones, starting at the Seddon memorial on Sundays at 2.00pm. A fascinating tour of Wellington's early history. The stories go far beyond well-known names from history, giving glimpses of ordinary people who made their home here.

Seize this opportunity to learn more about NZ’s oldest town cemetery and the lives of some of its many and varied occupants, people who lived in nineteenth-century Wellington. Hear wonderful stories from our colonial past as well as a reminder of the disruption caused by the construction of Wellington's Urban Motorway. Settlers and Māori were buried in this beautiful heritage cemetery, and their headstones can give us intriguing information.

All Sunday tours leave from the Kinross Street entrance to the Cemetery. The tours finish at the little museum in lower Bolton Street, just off the Terrace.

Children 12 & under: free (no ticket required).

Well-behaved dogs on leads welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $10
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/guided-tour-of-the-historic-bolton-street-cemetery/


Health & Safety:
Follow the directions of your tour guide, and stay on paths. Old headstones and railings around graves can be unstable.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
Southeast Asian Perceptions of New Zealand – Report Launch, Join us for the presentation and discussion of the Asia New Zealand Foundation’s latest report, Southeast Asian Perceptions of New Zealand.
Co-hosted by the New Zealand Institute of International Affairs and the Asia New Zealand Foundation Te Whītau Tūhono, please join us for the presentation of the Foundation’s inaugural Southeast Asian Perceptions of New Zealand report.
After 28 years of surveying New Zealanders’ perceptions of Asia, the Asia New Zealand Foundation has turned the lens back on New Zealand, for the first time asking 200 subject matter experts across Singapore, Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines how they view New Zealand and its foreign policy.
 Highlights:
Which country feels the warmest towards New Zealand?
How is New Zealand depicted in local media?
Is New Zealand seen as upholding its independent foreign policy?
Do our Southeast Asian neighbours think New Zealand lives up to its claims and promises?
What areas should New Zealand be investing more in and increasing cooperation?
Join us for this in-person presentation and panel discussion and the chance to ask questions and learn from informed experts on Asia on 13 November from 5:30pm - 7:00pm at Government Building Lecture Theatre 1 (GLBT1), Victoria University of Wellington Pipitea campus, 33 Bunny Street, Pipitea, Wellington.
This event is free to attend, but please RSVP for catering purposes

description:
Treasury Guest Lecture with Michael Keen: IN-PERSON attendance, Join us for our special Fiscal Policy for the Future seminar
New Zealand faces significant long-term fiscal challenges, including the rising costs associated with an ageing population, increasing demand for public services, and the need to adapt to a changing global economy. These pressures will require careful planning to ensure the sustainability of government finances while maintaining fairness and efficiency in the tax system.
Inland Revenue’s draft Long-Term Insights Briefing explores these issues by asking critical questions about the future shape and scale of our tax system. Similarly, the Treasury’s Long-Term Fiscal Statement highlights the importance of future-proofing our tax framework and other broader policy settings to address these challenges.
Join us for this seminar delivered by a highly regarded economist and expert in tax policy and administration, and a prolific author, Michael Keen, as he shares his insights on future proofing our tax system.
This will be a hybrid event, and we encourage you to attend it in person for an opportunity to engage in a discussion on all those issues with our guest speaker.
About this event
This will be a hybrid event. Please use this site to register if you plan to attend it in person.
If you would like to attend it virtually, please use THIS LINK to register.
The Tax Policy Charitable Trust has arranged Mick’s visit to New Zealand. The Trust was established to support leading tax policy thinking in New Zealand. You can read about the Trust’s work here.
About the presenter
Michael (Mick) Keen is a former Deputy Director of the Fiscal Affairs Department at the International Monetary Fund, where for over twenty years he played a central role in shaping and delivering IMF policies and advice on tax matters.
He has advised finance ministries in all parts of the world, including missions to over forty countries, and led the preparation of influential papers for the G20 and the Executive Board of the IMF.
Before joining the Fund, Mick was Professor of Economics at the universities of Essex (UK), Queens (Canada) and Kyoto, and is now Ushioda Fellow at the University of Tokyo.
Mick was the keynote speaker at the 2014 conference on the Future of Tax Administration in New Zealand and has provided peer review for Inland Revenue’s previous Long-Term Insights Briefing.
Mick has jointly authored, with Joel Slemrod, Rebellion, Rascals and Revenue – an entertaining account of how history illuminates the perennial challenges and timeless principles of taxation—and how the past holds clues to solving the tax problems of today.
About this seminar series
New ideas, innovative concepts, research evidence and expert advice are all crucial to stimulate and inform the Treasury’s economic analysis and advice. Our current theme for guest lectures - Fiscal Policy for the Future - explores the role of stabilising, sustainable and effective fiscal policy. Speakers provide insights into how fiscal policy can be designed to support government to meet its current and future objectives and obligations while adapting to changing circumstances and delivering value to the New Zealand public.
Fiscal policy has a stabilising role in helping to smooth the business cycle, while sustainability in fiscal policy is foundational for resilience to both shocks and longstanding challenges, such as climate change, technological advancements, and demographic trends. Ensuring effective and value for money expenditure is important so that fiscal policy contributes to the living standards of New Zealanders, both now and in the future.
Please note that the views, opinions, findings, and conclusions expressed in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series are those of the individual presenters. They do not necessarily reflect the views of the New Zealand Treasury or the New Zealand Government.
For updates and our latest research visit: www.treasury.govt.nz
Keep in touch
If you would like to be the first to hear about our upcoming events in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series, please SUBSCRIBE to stay up to date.
label: Government & Politics

description:
Waikanae drop-in session | Reserve Management Plan, Waikanae drop-in session | Reserve Management Plan
Drop- in to Waikanae Park by the old skatepark to chat to us about the Reserve Management Plan.

Council manages over 130 parks and reserves on your behalf – from playgrounds, sports grounds, and esplanades to scenic and native reserves.

We’re drafting an omnibus Reserve Management Plan to set out objectives, polices and rules that guide their use, management, protection and development and want your help. Tell us what you value about your favourite parks and reserves, what might impact their use, protection and enjoyment, and what ideas do you have for their future.

There's lots of ways to have your say - online, on paper and in person.

description:
Treasury Guest Lecture with Michael Keen: IN-PERSON attendance, Join us for our special Fiscal Policy for the Future seminar
New Zealand faces significant long-term fiscal challenges, including the rising costs associated with an ageing population, increasing demand for public services, and the need to adapt to a changing global economy. These pressures will require careful planning to ensure the sustainability of government finances while maintaining fairness and efficiency in the tax system.
Inland Revenue’s draft Long-Term Insights Briefing explores these issues by asking critical questions about the future shape and scale of our tax system. Similarly, the Treasury’s Long-Term Fiscal Statement highlights the importance of future-proofing our tax framework and other broader policy settings to address these challenges.
Join us for this seminar delivered by a highly regarded economist and expert in tax policy and administration, and a prolific author, Michael Keen, as he shares his insights on future proofing our tax system.
This will be a hybrid event, and we encourage you to attend it in person for an opportunity to engage in a discussion on all those issues with our guest speaker.
About this event
This will be a hybrid event. Please use this site to register if you plan to attend it in person.
If you would like to attend it virtually, please use THIS LINK to register.
The Tax Policy Charitable Trust has arranged Mick’s visit to New Zealand. The Trust was established to support leading tax policy thinking in New Zealand. You can read about the Trust’s work here.
About the presenter
Michael (Mick) Keen is a former Deputy Director of the Fiscal Affairs Department at the International Monetary Fund, where for over twenty years he played a central role in shaping and delivering IMF policies and advice on tax matters.
He has advised finance ministries in all parts of the world, including missions to over forty countries, and led the preparation of influential papers for the G20 and the Executive Board of the IMF.
Before joining the Fund, Mick was Professor of Economics at the universities of Essex (UK), Queens (Canada) and Kyoto, and is now Ushioda Fellow at the University of Tokyo.
Mick was the keynote speaker at the 2014 conference on the Future of Tax Administration in New Zealand and has provided peer review for Inland Revenue’s previous Long-Term Insights Briefing.
Mick has jointly authored, with Joel Slemrod, Rebellion, Rascals and Revenue – an entertaining account of how history illuminates the perennial challenges and timeless principles of taxation—and how the past holds clues to solving the tax problems of today.
About this seminar series
New ideas, innovative concepts, research evidence and expert advice are all crucial to stimulate and inform the Treasury’s economic analysis and advice. Our current theme for guest lectures - Fiscal Policy for the Future - explores the role of stabilising, sustainable and effective fiscal policy. Speakers provide insights into how fiscal policy can be designed to support government to meet its current and future objectives and obligations while adapting to changing circumstances and delivering value to the New Zealand public.
Fiscal policy has a stabilising role in helping to smooth the business cycle, while sustainability in fiscal policy is foundational for resilience to both shocks and longstanding challenges, such as climate change, technological advancements, and demographic trends. Ensuring effective and value for money expenditure is important so that fiscal policy contributes to the living standards of New Zealanders, both now and in the future.
Please note that the views, opinions, findings, and conclusions expressed in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series are those of the individual presenters. They do not necessarily reflect the views of the New Zealand Treasury or the New Zealand Government.
For updates and our latest research visit: www.treasury.govt.nz
Keep in touch
If you would like to be the first to hear about our upcoming events in the Treasury Guest Lecture Series, please SUBSCRIBE to stay up to date.

description:
Healthy Hospo Building Resilience Wellington, We're pleased to invite you to join us for this workshop on Building resilience and unlocking the power of the mind.
Why this matters:
In our rapidly changing world, resilience emerges as a fundamental skill. It's not just about bouncing back from adversity but confidently navigating change. Resilience enables individuals to navigate uncertainty with confidence and adaptability. This 90-minute workshop delves into the profound significance of resilience, offering participants practical insights and actionable strategies to cultivate resilience and harness the potential of the mind. By equipping individuals with these tools, the workshop empowers them to not only weather storms but also thrive in dynamic environments.
What to expect:
During this interactive workshop, participants will explore the core concepts of resilience and the mind-body connection through engaging discussions, experiential exercises, and practical demonstrations. They will learn evidence-based techniques to enhance their resilience, manage stress effectively, and cultivate a positive mindset amidst adversity. By the end of the session, attendees will emerge with a comprehensive toolkit to fortify their mental resilience and embrace change with confidence.
Who this is for:
This workshop caters to individuals across all organisational levels who are eager to enhance their resilience and cultivate a resilient mindset. Whether you're an owner, manager, chef, senior staff member, or junior employee, this workshop offers invaluable insights and practical strategies to bolster resilience and thrive in today's fast-paced world.
About the presenter, Sarah Robb
Sarah is a certified coach, counselor, and Master Practitioner of NLP (neuro-linguistic programming) holding a Bachelor's degree in Psychology.
With a passion for transformation, she guides individuals through retraining their brains and breaking free from limiting beliefs and patterns. Drawing on her extensive lived experience, Sarah has collaborated with over 200 clients and organisations, empowering them to apply practical tools and strategies for significant improvements in their mental health.
Sarah is motivated to continue creating positive change and to educate people about the power of the mind and how to use life's challenges as an opportunity for growth.

description:
Behind the Headlines: Talking Books with Mike McRoberts, Mike McRoberts (Ngāti Kahungunu ki te Wairoa) is one of New Zealand's most respected journalists and broadcasters, with an award-winning career spanning four decades. Join us to hear him talk about the books that have shaped his life at this special fundraising event for Katherine Mansfield House & Garden.
After anchoring Newshub's 6pm bulletin for 20 years and reporting from conflict zones and natural disasters worldwide, Mike is a familiar face in New Zealand homes. His work involves telling other people’s stories, but what stories have influenced him? Books have played an important role in Mike’s life, taking him from student librarian to author of two books himself.
Mike’s latest book, 'Speaking My Language | Te Kōrero i Tōku Reo', explores his deeply personal journey into Te Reo Māori and Te Ao Māori - captured in his acclaimed documentary, 'Kia Ora, Good Evening'.
The evening will begin with a glass of Hunter’s Wines’ award-winning MiruMiru™ and delicious canapés. A non-alcoholic option will also be available.
This event is being held to raise funds for our Category 1 Historic Place and writer’s museum in Thorndon, which is open six days a week. We offer an annual programme of events and activities designed to encourage creativity and we host school and tour groups to share the life, literature and legacy of Katherine Mansfield.

Meet at the Cable Car Entrance Lookout, Upland Road, Kelburn.
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
Join the Friends for only $30 a year and all the walks will be free, as well as other great benefits.

description:
Christmas Race Day, Christmas Race Day at the historic Tauherenikau Racing and Event Centre, 1498 SH2, Featherston, 1pm – 6pm, Sunday. Get your families and friends together for an afternoon of thrilling horse racing and fun at the historic Tauherenikau Racecourse. Free entry. For more information, go to: https://www.tauherenikau.co.nz/

The Wairarapa Racing Club was officially formed on the 21st of April 1864. For ten years the club held meetings in other parts of the Wairarapa and in 1874 shifted to its current location at Tauherenikau.

Work began on the Tauherenikau Racecourse in 1866 and was completed in 1874, with the first meeting being held at Tauherenikau on January 26th/27th, 1874. The first buildings were erected in 1892 with the building of a Grandstand, Weighing Room, Stewards Room, 4 boxes and 8 stalls.

A Featherston Heritage Festival Event.

description:
The Life of Henry the Fifth, A young man, once revelling in freedom and reckless camaraderie, is thrust into the role of a king, burdened with the fate of England.
Victory or ruin rests on his shoulders, yet his newfound power isolates him, leaving him lost, uncertain, and deeply unsettled.
Betrayed by friends, mistrusted by his men, and taunted by those who seek his downfall, Henry’s journey is both severe and profoundly relatable.
Shakespeare crafts a world where soldiers fight without knowing why, where the battlefield sees vagrants and children stand shoulder to shoulder, where uncertain rulers navigate a landscape devoid of guidance from the past. It is a world that, despite its historical setting, feels unnervingly close to our own.
With only ten dynamic performers, this is Henry the Fifth like never before: stripped back, sharp, and driven by the raw intensity of Shakespeare’s text.
Expect fast-paced storytelling, immersive staging, and a production that puts the audience at the heart of the battle.
Full show duration: 95 min including a 15 min intermission.
“This production epitomises what can be achieved when talent, teamwork, hard work, opportunity and passion combine.’”
NZ Herald on The Tragedy of Macbeth

description:
Brank Bjork Trio: Christchurch, Brant Bjork has spent over a quarter of a century at the heart of California’s desert rock scene. From cutting his teeth as the drummer and songwriter for Kyuss’s legendary early albums to carrying the torch for fuzz-driven rock with Fu Manchu from 1994 to 2001, Bjork’s impact is undeniable. Over the past two decades, he has produced albums for other artists, launched numerous side projects, built an extensive solo career as a singer, guitarist, and bandleader, and founded his own record label. His story is one of relentless, boundary-pushing creativity.

In 2024, Bjork re-formed the Brant Bjork Trio, teaming up with Michael Amster (Nebula, Mondo Generator) on drums and longtime friend—and desert rock pioneer—Mario Lalli on bass.

In 2025, the trio heads to New Zealand for three exclusive shows celebrating their latest album, Once Upon a Time in the Desert. This is a rare chance to catch a true icon of desert rock live—an experience not to be missed.

Joining them on all three dates are Australian rockers Full Tone Generator. Born on the beaches of Australia by Andy Fernando and brought to life in the Californian desert, Full Tone Generator brings the heat with a powerful blend of riff-heavy rock and raw energy.

Secure your tickets today!

Info about the teacher:

Guinean percussionist Sibo Bangoura grew up in Matam – the heart of Conakry’s arts precinct – surrounded by a family of griots. His mother was a singer and his father abalafon player. Sibo absorbed the rhythm from his infancy and began to study percussion formally at the age of 12. At 14, he joined Boka Junior ensemble and then played with Ballet Matam for many years, until he moved to Australia.

Sibo currently resides in Sydney and travels to China, Japan, Singapore and Thailand to teach and perform. He plays with his brothers Mohamed and Epizo Bangoura and has a successful 8-piece band Keyim Ba

description:
Mystery 35mm Movie Marathon, Details
UPDATE - We have added some Half Marathon ticket options for those can't make the whole event. You can either select 'Daytime' or 'Evening' which will let you watch three features total. Daytime tickets are from 1:30pm until the dinner break (around 7:00pm). Evening are from the dinner break until the end of the last film.

Surprise we are running a 35mm Mystery Marathon very soon! We have had some exciting news that we cannot share for now but as a result we must move our beautiful 35mm from its usual location into storage for a bit. We are not sure when it will be set back up so to celebrate we are running a marathon of six 35mm features across one Saturday!

We will kick off the first film at 1:30pm sharp on Saturday and will have a short dinner break after the third film. All going to plan we should be done by around 12:30am.

In terms of the features, we have films from the 1960s through to the early 2000s with a mix of comedies, sci-fi, horror and cult classics! Granted not all of these films would be considered masterpieces but there is nothing more fun than sitting in a crowd not knowing what could be coming next!

We will have a snack menu you can pre-order before the first film so aim to arrive around 1:00pm to order. The breaks between films will be very short (probably just enough time for the projectionist to thread up the next film) so make sure you come prepared for back-to-back screenings.

This event has strictly no digital projection, it’s all film all the time. Now in theory it should all playback without a hitch as we are bringing in some of the best projectionist’s Wellington has. But 35mm is a strange beast that can sometimes throw up the odd issue.

Full marathon tickets (Admit) are $50
Half Marathon - Daytime are $30
Half Marathon - Evening are $30

Seating is general admission and cinema entrance will be determined by earliest ticket purchase times.

Our Leadership & Management - Part 3 workshop is a practical skills training course designed for people already in a leadership/management position, or those about to take up a new role, who want to explore the latest thinking and models for effective management and leadership and build on the techniques acquired in our Part 1 and 2 workshops.

In today’s world, emotional Intelligence is a critical and powerful component of effective leadership. description:
Destination Earth, Expect your senses to be stirred in a new art installation. Destination Earth aims to inspire climate action through art. It incorporates satellite data, real-time generative music, and responds to audience movement in real-time. Using video and immersive sound, audiences will be challenged to reconsider the rhythm of living as humans. 
You are invited to dive into the flow of the Southern Ocean and explore the pulse of the Antarctic circumpolar current. Participate by adjusting your walking patterns and breathing to ‘regenerate’ the world around you. Motion sensors will pick up your activity and adjust the environment to suit. At a sensorial level the effects of climate change will come to life. 

Destination Earth is a collaboration between Cellule Studio (UK) and Victoria University of Wellington. The work, by artist Salome Bazin, mixes art, science, and technology. It emphasises the urgent need to slow down human activity.  

A bi-cultural perspective is also central to the experience. Māori symbolic views of the ocean are included, offering a richer narrative of the global climate.
 
Image credit: Cellule Studio, directed by Salomé Bazin.
